PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Douglas McClelland) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

PETITION.TITLE: Education
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:
Education

To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens, teachers and parents working in and for the interests of the pupils in government schools and colleges throughout Australia respectfully showeth that:

1. We deplore the unprincipled and self-interested attacks being orchestrated by minority sects and groups against the policies and person of the Commonwealth Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, the Hon. Senator Susan Ryan.
2. We fully support the Federal Government's actions in reducing funds for the wealthiest private schools, and in breaking the nexus between government and non -government school costs.

3. We endorse the Federal Government's principled opposition to the provision of 'base grants' to all non-government schools, as a positive step towards fulfilling their commitment of primary obligation to Australia's government schools.

4. We call upon the Federal Government however to recognise that its failure to create an adequate general recurrent resource base for government schools through providing increased recurrent grants, will undermine its own Special Programmes and thus frustrate its own stated educational objectives of greater equity and participation.

5. We support the Federal Government's stated policy of entering into direct negotiations for joint agreements on these grants with State/Territory Governments, to ensure a planned programme of improvements in government schools throughout the coming decade.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Robertson (from 40 citizens), Ryan (from 16 citizens) and Zakharov ( from 24 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain elected representatives and officers of Local Governments in Australia shows that:
General revenue grants to local government under personal income tax sharing entitlements have increased by 8.2 per cent in 1983-84 over 1982-83,
The inflation rate over the same period was 11.2 per cent,
The increase in grants to State Governments over the same period was 11.8 per cent,
Increased demands are being made on Local Government Authorities to participate in Federal Government programs e.g. Community Employment Program,
The Labor Party made a pre-election commitment to allocate not less than the real value of the previous year's allocation in General Revenue Grants to Local Government.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Government will amend the Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act of 1976, to provide a real term minimum guarantee to Local Government general revenue sharing arrangements in 1983-84, and in future years.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Dame Margaret Guilfoyle (from 14 citizens), Jessop (from six citizens) and Lewis (from 25 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
That the Commonwealth Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 could be used to support the provision by the Commonwealth Government of funding, counselling, etc. for deliberately procured abortions.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled:
should amend the Sex Discrimination Bill so as to prevent it from being used in support of deliberately procured abortions.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Sir John Carrick (from 185 citizens), Chaney (from 300 citizens), Dame Margaret Guilfoyle (from 15 citizens) and Robertson (from 312 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium Mining
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament house assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
We urge the government to declare a moratorium on uranium mining and treatment in Australia;
We urge the government to repudiate any commitment of a non-labor government to the mining, processing or export of Australia's uranium;
We urge the government to not permit the mining, processing or export of uranium pursuant to agreements entered into contrary to ALP policy; and
We urge the government to discontinue the Roxby uranium mine development.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every child in Australia is entitled to government financial support for their education whether they attend government schools or non-government schools .

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that urgent consideration be given to a favourable decision for the continuation of Federal Government per capita grants payable in respect of all children in non-government schools at a rate calculated as a percentage of Government Standard Costs at a level not less than that prevailing in 1983.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Robertson (from 26 citizens) and Ryan (from 64 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that:

The Universal Declaration of Human Rights affirms the principle of the inadmissibility of discrimination and proclaims that all human beings are born free and equal in dignity and rights and that everyone is entitled to all the rights and freedoms set forth therein, without distinction of any kind including distinction based on sex.

However extensive discrimination against women continues to exist. It is an obstacle to the participation of women on equal terms with men, in the political , social, economic and cultural life of this country. It hampers the growth of the prosperity of society and the family and makes more difficult the full development of the potentialities of women in the service of this country and of humanity.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government will act to ratify the convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination against Women.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: School Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled we, your petitioners, do humbly pray that:
1. This Government re-affirms its needs based funding policy for non-government schools and continue to pursue its mandate in this regard
2. the Government re-affirm its primary obligation to the needs of government schools
3. we support the Schools Commission Community Resource Standard as a basis for funding government schools
4. the recommendation of the Australian Schools Commission, in respect to the funding of non-government schools, be accepted.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-In the Australian newspaper today on the feature page there is an article discussing the proposed increase in the number of parliamentarians. The article, in its heading, said:

SPEECH.PARA: The ALP, Australian Democrats and the National Party support the increases, guaranteeing the passage of the legislation.

Honourable senators will remember that I introduced a Bill into this Parliament in an attempt to break the nexus between the Senate and the House of Representatives. In the second reading debate on that Bill some four or five weeks ago I stated very clearly that the Australian Democrats would oppose any increase in the number of parliamentarians and believed that the effective way was first to put to the people the possibility of their agreeing to break the nexus, so that a moderate increase in numbers in the House of Representatives would be able to be undertaken.

It seems to me that the person who wrote that article-since it has no name to it I am unable to find out who wrote it-was in fact relying on the New South Wales Branch of the Institute of Public Affairs. An advance copy of its document , entitled 'More Federal Parliamentarians-Can They Be Justified?', was sent to me on 2 November. I read that article on the same day and immediately rang the Director, Alec Simpson, to point out to him the error in that it had been suggested that the Australian Democrats would support the legislation. Mr Simpson informed me that the person who had written that section was Mr Chris Puplick, who has been a senator in this place. Mr Puplick also attributed to the Australian Democrats a particular position in relation to the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform. I pointed out to the Director of the Institute of Public Affairs that senators, when they appear on any Senate committee, do so at the behest of the Senate and not as representatives of their own political parties. I said that to so attribute that position was incorrect and in fact extremely damaging to the way that not only that Committee but all Senate committees operate. They operate in such a way as to enable all senators to put aside that very tight party allegiance and to look at issues on their merits. I am surprised that Mr Chris Puplick, who has been a senator, did not know that fact. I believe it is important that those matters be put on the record.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

DEBATE.TITLE: OPERATION OF THE SPECIAL EMPLOYMENT-RELATED PROGRAMS ACT 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Fourth Report

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

As is indicated on the list which was incorporated in Hansard by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button), this report has not been available prior to tabling and hence I have not read it. But I want to take this opportunity to make a couple of comments about the special employment-related programs which are relevant to the matters which would be dealt with in the report. The report is tabled pursuant to the desire of the Senate, which was evidenced in its resolution of 16 December 1982, that we should get some check on the effectiveness of the expenditure of the wage pause moneys. Some hundreds of millions of dollars were saved, or potentially saved, by imposing a freeze on Public Service salaries-that applied also to the salaries of senators-and the moneys were to be disbursed in various ways, including the building of welfare housing. An amount of $100m was allocated for that purpose, and $200m was to be made available for programs which were to be conducted through the States and which would provide employment for the long term unemployed, with special consideration being given to disadvantaged groups in the employment market, including women.

It is an unfortunate fact that the administration of that program did not result in the expenditure of the moneys in the efficient way in which the Parliament and the Commonwealth Government might have hoped. Indeed, the present Government has made a number of remarks about the inability of States to expend moneys, and there have been delays in making money available to the States because they have not been able to expend the moneys already given to them. That , in a time of high and, for most of that period, rising unemployment, is a matter for concern. Undoubtedly, the experience of the States in the administration of this program needs to be studied very carefully so we can avoid similar difficulties in the future if we are put in a position of wanting to create employment by these means.

The particular point I want to raise today-I suggest to the Government that it might reconsider this-is the element of the program which was discontinued by the present Government when it came into office. A very small amount of money-I think it was a couple of million dollars-was set aside to enable States, through local government, to experiment with providing work in lieu of unemployment. The general proposition was that local authorities would make available employment at award rates for the number of hours per week required to make up the amount of unemployment benefit those people would otherwise be paid, plus an amount of $35. The additional amount of $35 was to ensure that in undertaking part time work there was no financial loss for the people concerned. If they undertook part time work while receiving the unemployment benefit they could supplement their income up to a certain level and then there was a gradual withdrawal of the benefit. Under this scheme they would be at least as well off as people who were on the unemployment benefit and getting some small amount of part time work .

The Government's prediction is that we will have a continuing rise in unemployment. I think it is the Government's prediction that as many as one in three young Australians could be unemployed by early next year. I do not blame the Government for that. We have had a difficult situation for some years now. That difficulty has worsened over the last year, and the Government itself says that unemployment will continue to rise. My plea is that the Government should reconsider some experimentation in this area. The Government has shown itself ready to consider something as esoteric as a kibbutzim movement in Australia. I believe there would be a lot of support around Australia for at least a voluntary trial of enabling unemployed people to get access to part time work at award rates which would enable them to earn the money they receive, to get work experience, and for the community to get some return.

I think the estimate was that we expect to expend over $3 billion this year on the unemployment benefit. Happily, the most recent figures show a decline in the number of people claiming unemployment benefit. We all welcome that, but is is a sad fact that there will be hundreds of thousands-probably in excess of 600,000- of Australians out of work. An amount of $3 billion will be expended. I believe there is room for at least a start in trialling some work provision in that way. I understand all the theoretical and administrative problems involved, but I believe the Government is being doctrinaire in dropping that experiment. I ask it to reconsider its decision.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Annual Report

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

Again, this is a report which has not been available to us prior to tabling. Hence, I wish to make a couple of preliminary remarks on matters that we might address in more detail in a later debate on the report. During the debate on the Appropriation Bills I drew the attention of the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) to the fact that there had been a failure on the part of the non-political arm of government to assess the impact of certain excise increases on important elements of the resource industries. That failure to measure the impact led the Government to make decisions in the Budget which it withdrew or changed within seven or eight days of bringing down the Budget.

I believe that that experience, which I do not suggest is unique to the present Government, is one which ought to teach us that there is a need for some additional mechanisms within the bureaucracy and within the process of Budget formation which will avoid that sort of error. It is not always possible for a government to recant on errors of that sort. I am quite sure that at times governments of my own persuasion, as with governments of the Labor persuasion, do make decisions in the Budget which, on seeing the actual impact, they feel they perhaps should not have made, or wish they had not made, but of course they cannot go on rewriting the Budget indefinitely. For that reason, I again draw the attention of the Senate to what I think would be the wisdom of ensuring that within the Budget process, and particularly with departments such as the Department of Resources and Energy which have some responsibility for major areas of industry, there should be a very careful assessment of the impact of proposed new Budget taxing measures before those measures are finally accepted by government.

I have absolutely no doubt that had information been clearly placed before the present Minister for Resources and Energy that the excise changes would have impacted on, say, the operations of Nabalco at Gove in the way that they did or that they would have impacted on the operations of the Northern Territory Electricity Commission in the way they did, he would have successfully argued that those measures should not have been in the Budget. Senator Walsh was gracious enough in the Appropriation debates to say that his personal knowledge of the high use of fuel oil at the Greenvale nickel project was such that he could have realised that the measure was unwise.

I do not believe that it is possible for any Minister to apply all of his knowledge to the enormous volume of material that goes before him at Budget time . I suggest that there is a deficiency, which again I do not wish to sheet home to the Government-I think it is simply part of the way the whole system is structured-in that there is a lack of concern about the actual impact of some of these measures when they are put before government for adoption in a Budget. I am sure there are other matters within the report of the Department of Resources and Energy which will excite the attention of the Senate and attract some debate . I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Report

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present the report of the Australia/ Korea Parliamentary Group's delegation to the Republic of Korea. I seek leave to make a short statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the then President of the Australia/Korea Parliamentary Group I was privileged to lead a delegation from the Group which visited the Republic of Korea from 5 to 12 June 1983. An invitation for the visit, both verbal and written, was received by the Australia/Korea Parliamentary Group from the Vice Speaker of the National Assembly and President of the Korea-Australian Parliamentarians Friendship Association, the Hon. Kim Eun-Ha. The visit represented the breaking of new ground as it was the first time a delegation from a particular parliamentary friendship group of the Commonwealth of Australia had visited another country at the invitation of its counterpart. I believe this is a step forward in our inter-parliamentary relationships. The benefits derived from members of one parliament sitting down and talking to members of another in a fraternal way should be encouraged for it is only through such direct contact with other parliamentarians that we can become aware of the attitudes which influence the formulation of policies in other countries.

SPEECH.PARA: As representatives of the people, we largely have left the responsibility in the field of international diplomacy to executive government. With the advent of these groups we now have an excellent opportunity to make a positive contribution in this important area. Should any honourable senators have the opportunity, I would commend a visit to the Republic of Korea. The achievements of that country in the last 20 years are quite remarkable. A most notable point about the Republic of Korea is its economic growth and technological development which has been achieved in a relatively short time span. Our trade relations are quite substantial and are still expanding. As such, we should maintain a close interest in its general strategic situation because it is becoming increasingly significant as a regional power.

The delegation to the Republic of Korea was warmly received and we, as representatives of the Australian Parliament, were most impressed with the program arranged as it enabled us to learn a great deal about the development and culture of that country. The National Assembly, the Korea-Australian Parliamentarians Friendship Association and all concerned with the visit deserve the highest praise. The report contains the program of activities as well as a record of some discussions, information gathered and conclusions arrived at by the delegation. I conclude by thanking the Inter-Parliamentary Union staff, particularly Mr John Dyer for his invaluable assistance in making arrangements for the visit.

DEBATE.TITLE: EXPORT FINANCE AND INSURANCE CORPORATION AMENDMENT BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Button) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill proposes what are essentially technical amendments to the Export Finance and Insurance Corporation Act 1974. However, these amendments form an integral part of a total approach by the Government to export development. In recent years there has been an intensification of credit competition in international trade. The recession in Western countries and slow down in domestic activities has resulted in a scramble for all available export orders. In the capital goods area, interest rates and the cost of finance have become the key determinant of competitiveness. Most countries subsidise interest rates and there is an increasing use of aid funds to further soften credit terms in order to secure major contracts. Agricultural trade is also under pressure with major exporters aggressively attempting to expand overall market share. On top of these pressures, there is a lengthening list of countries with serious debt repayment problems. Requests for extended credit terms have become more frequent .

An all out credit war has been averted largely due to the limitation on subsidised credit terms which has come from international understandings, particularly the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development arrangement on export credit which sets minimum interest rates and maximum repayment terms for capital goods transactions. The arrangement, however, is under pressure as domestic interest rates in a number of countries approach or fall below the minimum rates applying to export credits. Japan in particular is now in that situation. Against this background of intense credit competition, and also in response to widespread criticism from the business community that credit facilities currently available to Australian exporters are no longer on a par with those available to our competitors, the Government has undertaken an extensive review of Australia's export credit policy. It was the Labor Government in 1974 which last took a serious look at the problems confronting exporters in the field of export credit. At that time, the existing Export Payments Insurance Corporation was reconstituted as the Export Finance and Insurance Corporation, or EFIC as it is generally referred to, with an export bank function to provide exporters with concessional finance to meet the subsidised interest rates being offered by most of our major competitors.

The Government now has decided on a range of initiatives designed to ensure that markets for Australian exports are made secure and developed to their full potential. On the export credit side, the supporting services available to exporters through EFIC are to be strengthened and the Government will pursue a more effective export credit policy generally. The Government's intention is that EFIC's facilities be expanded to enable the Corporation to provide foreign currency financing and give Australian exporters access to lower interest rate currencies for medium and long term credit with which to meet the terms being provided by competitors. The Government is also examining the various sources of funding for EFIC's finance facility, including general offshore borrowing, to ensure that the most suitable funding arrangements are utilised.

The operating policies of EFIC currently restrict the provision of export finance to Australian dollar loans and the provision of buyer credit guarantees to Australian lending institutions, that is, where EFIC provides a lender making a loan to an overseas buyer of Australian goods with a guarantee of repayment. While the interest rates of our major competitors were above the OECD minima, this did not, in general, place Australian exporters at a disadvantage. The fact that the yen and some other currencies can now be provided at below the OECD minima and that other important trading currencies may shortly follow suit, makes it desirable to extend EFIC's facilities to provide for foreign currency financing. This will be done by empowering EFIC to give a guarantee-what is known as buyer credit-to an Australian or overseas lending institution which provides a foreign currency loan to the overseas borrower or buyer, or, alternatively, EFIC itself raising foreign currency offshore in its own name and lending itself in that foreign currency to the overseas buyer.

The benefits of foreign currency financing are twofold; not only will exporters have access to low interest rate currencies to match their competitors, but also with interest rates for many currencies presently lower than Australian interest rates, there is scope for the Government to achieve savings in the present cost of providing interest rate subsidies on Australian dollar loans. In some cases where the currency is below the OECD minima, no subsidy will be necessary. In other cases it will still be necessary to subsidise the interest rate of a foreign currency loan down to the OECD levels. It is this requirement with which the Bill is primarily concerned. No legislative action is required to enable EFIC to provide foreign currency financing. It is, however, necessary to provide EFIC with authority to provide subsidies to lenders giving buyers credit loans.

As part of a more aggressive approach to export credit, the Minister for Trade (Mr Lionel Bowen) has requested EFIC to revise its operating procedures to reflect the Government's wish that the Corporation play a conspicuous and determined role in assisting Australian exporters to secure orders. Of course this will be consistent with the Corporation's obligation to operate in accordance with sound commercial principles and comply with accepted international practice. This approach will include the establishment of credit lines or other facilities with countries which offer worthwhile trade development prospects. Exporters will no longer be required to demonstrate a need to meet competition when seeking concessional export finance and EFIC, subject to OECD understandings, will take the initiative in determining appropriate credit terms. There will be a more flexible approach to the definition of capital goods and the value of transactions which qualify for export finance assistance. The Corporation has also been asked to inform the Government prior to withdrawing or limiting cover for individual countries on commercial grounds, where such action may place significant trade at risk.

The Bill proposes a revised definition of 'lending' to include the provision of finance in any form. The expanded definition will enable EFIC to keep abreast of current trade financing techniques such as the purchase and dealing in bills of exchange and promissory notes. This is particularly relevant to the financing of lower value transactions where the more complicated, lengthy and costly process of loan negotiations and formal documentation can be avoided. The Bill will also give effect to the Government's decision to remove the restrictions which generally limit EFIC's services to those not 'normally' available from the private sector. The Government is concerned to ensure that EFIC does not become open to challenge if private operators were to seek to operate selectively in the less risky areas of EFIC's traditional activities. Rather than see the viability of a soundly run government operation undermined, this avenue for challenge is to be removed. Whilst the Government is anxious to preserve EFIC's traditional role, it does not see any need to extend EFIC's facilities into other areas of insurance as long as the private sector is effectively meeting the needs of exporters.

The regulations under the EFIC Act are to be amended to enable EFIC to provide up to 100 per cent cover against the risk on non-payment arising from political causes. The basic principle of credit insurance is that of 'co-insurance' whereby the exporter, by bearing a share of the risk, will act with prudence and caution. While the Government sees merit in this practice as it can influence the firms and organisations with which an exporter chooses to deal, it does not apply with the same force with respect to 'political risk' which is beyond an exporter's influence. The increase in cover for political risks is consistent with the Government's wish to encourage exporters to pursue all reasonable commercial opportunities. Obviously, the practice of limiting Australia's exposure in countries with a poor payment record or those known to be an imminent risk of default will continue. Cover against 'commercial' causes of loss, such as buyer insolvency, will remain at 90 per cent.

Earlier, I mentioned briefly the use of aid funds in 'mixed credits' by many of our competitors. A limited scheme, the Development Import Finance Facility, has been available through the Australian Development Assistance Bureau since 1981 to provide aid grants in conjunction with EFIC loans to soften the overall financial package available to support Australian exporters faced with competition from 'mixed credits'. The DIFF scheme has only now started bearing fruit and to overcome the uncertainty for exporters involved in protracted negotiations on the future availability of funds, the Government has introduced a $60m commitment ceiling for the scheme as an interim arrangement pending the outcome of the current examination of Australia's aid program by the Jackson Committee to advise on policies for manufacturing industry. This will significantly strengthen the scheme by enabling exporters to tender for contracts in the knowledge that funds will be available if they are successful.

I also mentioned earlier the work within the OECD to avert a credit race in international trade. To date, these efforts have been directed towards limiting subsidised finance and extended repayment terms for exports of manufactured goods. More recently, there has been increasing pressure to extend more generous payment terms than the usual 180 days for a range of agricultural commodities. Much of this stems directly from the demands of countries with debt servicing problems but there is also a strong push towards the use of attractive credit by suppliers to expand market share. Australia has instigated a study of the use of credit in agricultural trade and will continue to pursue an international agreement within the ambit of the OECD to limit the provision of officially supported credit for agricultural products.

Australia's ability to win and maintain export markets depends increasingly on an effective framework of export credit arrangements. In particular, the support services available through EFIC must reflect the changing needs of Australian exporters in a rapidly changing international trading environment which is presently characterised by intense international competition involving generous credit terms for all available export business. As this situation is likely to continue through the 1980s, an essential feature of export credit policy must be an aggressive approach towards maintaining existing markets.

The proposals I have outlined do not in themselves involve additional expenditure by the Government. The consequences of a more vigorous approach to export may be an increased amount of interest rate subsidy. However, this will be dependent on the success of exporters in winning business and savings should be achieved through the use of lower interest rate foreign currency financing. The Government expects that these initiatives, when taken as a package, will meet much of the criticism from the business community that Australia's export credit facilities are not on par with those available to our competitors. They will also provide EFIC with the base from which it can play the conspicuous and determined role envisaged for it by the Government. These initiatives build further on the trade promotion measures to boost Australia's export performance which were announced in the Budget context.

There is a continuing need to maintain Australia's international competitiveness and none of the Government's measures I have outlined seek to compensate for the basic competitive elements such as price, quality and delivery. However, they are all designed to achieve greater penetration into the growth areas of world trade by adopting a more aggressive approach to exporting. Our promotional measures are heavily weighted towards manufactured goods as it is this area of world trade which has expanded and where Australia's performance has slipped back. Our manufacturing sector has contracted and employment has fallen dramatically. Manufactured exports can play a key role in reducing unemployment.

The full range of measures I have outlined and other initiatives such as the current review of the Australian Trade Commissioner Service and the examination of a possible overseas trading corporation, demonstrate clearly the planned approach that this Government is taking to revitalise the export sector of the Australian economy. Although the proposals contained in this Bill are technical and of limited impact in themselves, I am confident that the Government's total approach to export development, of which they are part, will be welcomed by exporters as a positive step towards regaining our position as a world trading nation. I commend this Bill to honourable senators.
Debate (on motion by Senator Durack) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Button) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This legislation represents a further step by this Government towards the implementation of its industrial relations platform and is in accordance with the Statement of Accord reached between the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Council of Trade Unions prior to the Government being formed. It introduces a range of measures aimed at improving the framework of industrial relations in Australia.

At the same time the Bill incorporates significant elements of the industrial relations legislation that were introduced in 1982 by the previous Government, and which we supported, but which had not been passed by the time of the dissolution of Parliament at the beginning of this year. I refer in particular to the proposals in this Bill for greater co-ordination between Commonwealth and State industrial systems. The incorporation of the jurisdiction of the Public Service Arbitrator within the jurisdiction of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and changes to certain administrative arrangements under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act.

Honourable senators will be aware that an essential principle of this Government's approach to industrial relations is to create a climate whereby any changes that are put forward by the Government affecting the industrial relations framework should first be fully examined by the parties through the National Labour Consultative Council. Accordingly the provisions of this legislation have been the subject of extensive discussion and examination by the parties through the NLCC; in some cases these discussions have been going on for several years. Apart from an aspect that I will mention later, the legislation has the full support of the NLCC.

When the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) announced the establishment of the review of Australia's industrial relations system in July, he explained that this decision would not preclude the Government from introducing changes that it considered essential in the short term to overcome aspects of the current arrangements which were seen as deficient or which impeded the day to day effectiveness of the system. By its nature this legislation is designed to do just that. I should point out to honourable senators that the NLCC considers, with one exception, that all of the matters covered in this legislation should be implemented forthwith by the Government, and should not be delayed until the report of the review is available in 1985.

The Bill consists of the following elements. First, it provides for improved co -ordination in the work of the Commonwealth and State industrial tribunals through the re-introduction, in identical terms, of the Conciliation and Arbitration (Complementary Industrial Relations System) Amendment Bill 1982. Second, it re-introduces, with certain amendments, provisions of the Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Bill 1982 relating to term of office, common rules, casual vacancies. Third, it repeals the Public Service Arbitration Act 1920 and transfers the jurisdiction under that Act to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. This is based on the provisions of the Conciliation and Arbitration (Government Service) Amendment Bill 1982. Fourth, it gives effect to proposals that have been agreed by NLCC in recent years but which had not been acted upon by the previous Government. These proposals concern:
Changes to the accounting and financial reporting provisions contained in Part VIIIAA of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act which were agreed by NLCC in 1982 ; and
Amendments to the Act to enable certain persons to become or remain members of federally registered employee organisations.
Fifth, the legislation gives effect to some proposals that have been extensively discussed by NLCC this year. These proposals concern:

Changes to the presentation and publication of accounts and related statements by organisations; amendments to the disqualification from office provisions and to the loans, grants and donations provisions of the Act;
Petitioning procedures to be followed in seeking officially conducted elections ; and
Clarification of the rule amending powers of committees of management.
Finally, there are several technical amendments which are introduced to overcome certain deficiencies and anomalies that have been identified in various administrative arrangements.
I now turn to examine the amendments in greater detail.

The amendments designed to achieve a greater co-ordination between the Commonwealth and State industrial systems are based on recommendations put forward by a Commonwealth-State working party. The previous Government introduced legislation last year to give effect to these recommendations. The changes introduced are in identical terms to those contained in the Conciliation and Arbitration (Complementary Industrial Relations System) Amendment Bill 1982. They provide for:
Joint sittings by single members of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and a State tribunal;
Expansion of the powers of local industrial boards-when constituted by a State industrial authority-to permit them to exercise federal conciliation and arbitration jurisdiction; and
The exercise, by agreement, of State jurisdiction by members of the Australian Commission.

In the past attempts to resolve some industrial disputes have been impeded because they have involved both Commonwealth and State jurisdictions. These changes are designed to remove some of the inflexibilities in the present systems so that tribunals concerned might come together to resolve them or authorise a member of one of the jurisdictions to deal with the matter. This issue was addressed at the National Summit Conference when the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations endorsed the views of other participants on the need for complementary industrial relations legislation as part of our overall prices and income strategy.

The Government considers these amendments to be a significant first step in moving towards even greater co-ordination and this issue will of course be one of the major areas to be looked at by the review of Australia's industrial relations system. In May of this year the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations advised Commonwealth and State Ministers for labour that the Government proposed to re-introduce this legislation. State Ministers also agreed at that meeting to proceed with similar legislation. Already Queensland and New South Wales have enacted, but have not yet proclaimed, legislation to give effect to the proposals. The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations is confident that each of the other States will proceed as soon as practicable to introduce similar legislation to complement and give effect to the proposals contained in this Bill.

I now turn to consider the proposals for extension of term of office. Under the Act the rules of organisations cannot permit a person to be elected to hold office for a period exceeding four years without being re-elected. This can create difficulties where an officer's term of office is to expire shortly before his proposed date of retirement. Such an officer must either stand for re -election, and serve only part of a term, or retire earlier than intended. The Government believes that organisations should be able to have rules enabling the holder of a full-time office, who is due to retire within a period of 12 months after the expiration of the period for which he is elected, to remain in office, if desired, until retirement. Clause 24 gives effect to this proposal. It is in identical terms to that contained in the Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Bill 1982.

I refer next to the provisions under the Act concerning common rules. The Act provides that the Commission may declare any award or part of an award to be a common rule within a Territory. Once such a common rule is made all the employees and employers in the industry covered by the award in that Territory are automatically bound by the award. The existing provisions for varying such common rules are cumbersome and often result in long delays in passing on to employees the benefit of the award variations involved. In 1981, following representations from the President of the Commission, NLCC agreed to amendments to simplify the existing procedures in relation to common rule variation. Provisions contained in the lapsed Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Bill 1982 were designed to reflect NLCC's recommendation. However, for reasons of a technical nature, those provisions did not exactly conform with the proposal agreed by NLCC. The relevant provisions of the 1982 Bill are re-introduced with the necessary changes to reflect NLCC's recommendations. Clause 12 thus provides that where the Commission varies a term of an award that is a common rule, the variation, once agreed to by the Commission, will operate automatically as a common rule and, after a 28 day period for objections, the variation will be enforceable except against those who successfully object.

Another amendment concerns casual vacancies. The Government also considers that the provisions of the Act concerning casual vacancies should be amended to overcome practical difficulties that have been experienced by organisations under the current arrangements. The Act requires the rules of organisations to provide for the election of office holders either by a direct voting system or a defined form of collegiate electoral system. There are no statutory provisions for the filling of casual vacancies in elected positions.

Following consideration of the question of casual vacancies by NLCC in 1981, the Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Bill 1982 contained a proposed amendment to enable the rules of an organisation to provide for the filling of a casual vacancy provided that the unexpired period of office was not more than 12 months. At meetings of NLCC this year, both the ACTU and Confederation of Australian Industry strongly urged that the 1982 legislative proposals be changed to permit the filling of casual vacancies by appointment for up to three years. The Government considered that the proposal went too far. On the other hand the provisions of the 1982 Bill were, in the Government's view, too restrictive and did not go far enough to overcome the inconvenience and cost currently incurred by organisations in having to hold special elections.

The Government believes it is necessary to achieve an acceptable balance between the need to prevent undue inconvenience and cost for organisations and the need to maintain the principle of democratic control by members and prevent the possibility of abuse and manipulationn of the electoral system. The changes introduced by clause 25 provide that the rules of organisations reflect those considerations. The rules may provide for the filling of casual vacancies in elected positions in two circumstances. Firstly, where the term of office is for up to 12 months, then until the expiration of the term. Secondly, where the term of office is longer than 12 months, then up to three-quarters of that term or until the next regular election for the filling of that office, whichever comes first. Where a vacancy is so filled in a collegiate electoral system the person shall be deemed to have been elected to the office for the purposes of participating in a further collegiate election. The effect of this amendment will be to provide the necessary degree of flexibility to organisations in filling casual vacancies whilst at the same time reducing the possibility of abuse or manipulation. Both the ACTU and CAI have indicated their support for this amendment.

I now turn to those provisions of the Bill which repeal the Public Service Arbitration Act 1920 and vest the jurisdiction under that Act in the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. Apart from certain changes which I will outline below this legislation incorporates the provisions of the Conciliation and Arbitration (Government Service) Amendment Bill 1982. The legislation gives effect to recommendations of the 1976 report of the Royal Commission on Australian Government Administration. It reflects the principles of integration that were first agreed by the NLCC in 1977.

Since the Public Service Arbitration Act was enacted in 1920 to deal with unique features of Commonwealth Public Service employment, the Arbitrator's functions have changed considerably and jurisdiction has merged to a significant degree with that of the Commission. Some of the most notable changes in that direction have been provision for appeals and reference to the Commission in 1952, transfer of hearing of some claims to the Commission in 1956, dispute notification and settling procedures in 1972 and the filling of the positions of Arbitrator and Deputy Arbitrator by members of the Commission. What is proposed is a natural progression from these developments and will mean that all major employment areas covered by Federal awards will now be regulated by the national tribunal.

There are two substantive changes to the provisions of the 1982 Bill. These changes have the full support of the ACTU, the CAI and the Public Service Staff Associations. The first change is intended to restore the full scope of the jurisdiction of the Tribunal that applied prior to the amendments by the previous Government to the Public Service Arbitration Act in 1978. As a result of this change the Commission will not be constrained from considering matters involving the selection of persons for appointment, re-appointment, employment or promotion in public service. The Government has also decided that it would not be appropriate to restrict the scope of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in relation to orders that it may make in the manner proposed in the legislation introduced by the previous Government. Consequently the Bill does not include the detailed provisions concerning the types of orders that may be made by the Commission and the provisions concerning the consequences for employees of being stood down that were contained in the 1982 Bill. The Government is advised that this change in no way restricts the ability of public employers to gain stand-down or no work as directed no pay orders. Public sector employers will still be able to apply to the Commission for such orders in the same way that private sector employers are. This is consistent with the Government's general approach, fully supported by the NLCC, that the position of the Commission in relation to public and private sector employment should as far as possible be the same.

There are four other amendments of a minor nature that are proposed to the provisions of the 1982 Government Service Bill to remedy technical deficiencies. The Government has also decided to amend the Act to clarify the position regarding membership of federally registered organisations. Once again I should stress that the two amendments relating to this area introduced by the Bill have the full support of the NLCC and were in fact recommendations by that body in 1982.

The first amendment, in clause 22, is to take account of amendments in 1979 to the provisions of the New South Wales Industrial Arbitration Act 1940 related to membership of State registered unions in New South Wales. In conformity with the intention of section 132 (4) of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act, the amendment proposed will allow persons able to join a New South Wales State registered union, which is a branch of a federal union, to become members of that federal union. The second amendment validates the membership of those who were validly enrolled as members of a federal union before amendments to the Conciliation and Arbitration Act in 1977 made them ineligible to remain members of federal organisations. The 1977 amendments aligned more closely the eligibility for membership of State and Federal organisations. The amendment proposed requires that such persons should have had continuous membership of the Federal organisation immediately before and subsequent to the coming into operation of the 1977 Act.

I now turn to the amendments proposed to Part VIIIAA of the Act. This part of the legislation which deals with accounts and audit in respect of registered organisations came into operation at the end of December 1980. The then Government, the ACTU and the employers agreed that its operation be monitored so that any problems could be rectified. The NLCC has identified a number of these problems and the Government has accepted the recommendations for change.

The first group of proposals are designed to introduce some flexibility into the requirements of Part VIIIAA concerning presentation and publication of accounts. The amendments do not affect the basic obligations of organisations and rights of members concerned in relation to the supply, presentation and filing of accounts, statements and auditors reports.

At present an organisation is required under existing arrangements to supply or publish free of charge to each of its members, copies of that organisation's accounts, auditors statements and accompanying statement in full. This has imposed considerable cost burden on organisations; at the same time there is little evidence to suggest that members have derived significant benefits from the provision of such material in this form. The requirements of presentation are not structured to inform a person without some familiarity in accountancy. The Government accepts the recommendation of NLCC that a more practical and effective arrangement for all concerned would be to give organisations an option to supply summaries of the accounts, reports and statements to their members.
Under the amendments to these requirements, in clause 33, such summaries will be regarded as fulfilling the obligations of organisations under the Act in those cases where:
The summary is accompanied by a notice indicating that members could obtain, free of charge, the full set of accounts, reports and statements of the organisation on request;
The auditor duly certifies that the summary represented a true and fair summary of the accounts, reports and statements of the organisation;
Such a summary sets out in full any qualification on the accounts made by the auditor; and
Copies are filed with the Registrar.

At present where an organisation is divided into branches, the branches are treated as separate units for the purposes of the financial reporting requirements of Part VIIIAA of the Act. Thus even in those cases where the federal body of an organisation under its rules exercises effective control over the financial management of the whole of the organisation, the branches are nevertheless required to present and file separate accounts. The Government has accepted an NLCC recommendation that these requirements are too rigid and impose unnecessary burdens on organisations. The amendments contained in clause 29 are designed to take into account the existence of a number of employer and employee organisations that operate, in financial mangement terms, at the federal level.

The Bill provides that the Registrar may upon application issue a certificate to an organisation if he is satisfied that the committee of management of the organisation has by the rules or by practice the right of custody, control or management of assets of the organisation, including assets of the branches. Where a certificate is issued the organisation will be able to comply with the provisions of Part VIIIAA of the Act by consolidating the accounts for the organisation. The amendments proposed do not affect the rights of members under Part VIIIAA. The NLCC is currently developing the details of proposals which would allow organisations with less centralised control of branch assets, to consolidate accounts for the purposes of Part VIIIAA if they so elect. Under these proposals branches would retain autonomy and members would be able to obtain details of branch accounts and reports etc on request. The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations hopes to be in the position of introducing amendments to give effect to that proposal in the 1984 autumn sittings.

The Bill also gives effect to essentially technical amendments designed to overcome practical difficulties in the operation of part VIIIAA identified by NLCC. These deal with various statutory time limits for presentation of accounts . The appointment of competent auditors and their attendance at meetings, accounting on a cash basis for membership subscriptions, investigations by the Registrar of qualified accounts and procedures relating to the publication of the federal organisation's accounts in branch journals. Both the ACTU and the CAI have strongly urged the Government to introduce all of these changes as soon as possible to overcome constraints which in their view are totally unnecessary. Another area of amendments relates to the disqualification from office provisions and the loans, grants and donations provisions passed by the Parliament last year.

The Conciliation and Arbitration (Management of Organisations) Act 1982, which introduced those measures, was designed by the previous Government to give effect to recommendations made by the Winneke Royal Commission into the activities of the Australian Building Construction Employees and Builders Labourers Federation. Those recommendations in summary suggested that the Government adopt in the Conciliation and Arbitration Act the same sorts of provisions as in the uniform companies legislation to disqualify office holders and to prevent abuse of the making of loans, grants and donations by organisations. However, the 1982 Act went much further than the Winneke recommendations. For example, it provided for disqualification from holding office in a federally registered organisation where the person concerned had been convicted of crimes relating to damage of property and violence. The range of offences included was much broader than those applying under the companies legislation and had in most cases nothing whatsoever to do with the management of a registered organisation.

The ACTU and CAI have proposed that these provisions be referred to the tripartite review of industrial relations for consideration. However, proposals have been put to the Government by the ACTU and other interested parties for amendments to the disqualification provisions that should be implemented prior to the report of the review committee as an interim measure. While the Government does consider that it is desirable that the provisions be examined by the review it does nevertheless recognise that the existing provisions might have the effect of debarring people from holding office because they have been convicted of relatively minor offences or of offences which are not directly connected with the person's fitness to hold office in an organisation; for example, a technical assault or a driving offence. Accordingly clause 23 amends section 132F of the Act by reducing the range of offences set out in paragraph 132F (1) (B) so that the offences are confined to those relating to elections or ballots under the Act and by changing the basis of paragraph 132F (1) (D) so that the paragraph will only refer to convictions imposed for crimes associated with damage or violence intentionally committed for which a person serves a sentence of imprisonment. Therefore only criminal offences which the court regards as sufficiently serious to warrant imprisonment will attract the disqualification provisions.

The Government also believes that the loans, grants and donations provisions of the Act should be examined by the review. However, one practical difficulty has been identified by the NLCC which the Government considers warrants immediate attention. The problem with existing section 133B of the Act is that no loan et cetera of more than $1,000 can be made without the prior approval of the committee of management. In circumstances where a member or his dependents suffer sudden severe financial hardship, the committee of management may not be able to approve a payment out of distress funds in time to be of assistance to such a person. To overcome this situation, clause 26 provides that a person authorised under the rules of an organisation will be able to approve payment for such purposes up to $3,000, and the committee of management will be able to endorse the payment at its next meeting. This will only apply where the rules of the organisation so provide.

Finally, clause 38 is designed to enable the making of regulations to prescribe a procedure for lodging petitions by members for officially conducted elections. This amendment is to overcome concerns that have been expressed to the Government that existing procedures are open to abuse. Many of the changes proposed in this legislation are, as I explained at the outset, identical or similar to proposals that were introduced last year by the previous Government but which lapsed. These changes represent important improvements which are designed to meet the Government's overall objective of establishing a flexible and effective framework for the resolution of industrial disputes and for the regulation of the affairs of organisations to the extent that this is necessary. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FINANCE AND GOVERNMENT OPERATIONS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following matter be referred to the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations: The establishment, operation, administration and accountability of bodies, which are neither departments nor statutory authorities of the Commonwealth, for which the Commonwealth is wholly or partly responsible.

Since 1977 the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations has been examining statutory authorities and has presented to the Senate six major reports on these bodies. The Committee in the course of its investigations into statutory authorities has become aware of the importance of another major group of bodies, bodies which are neither statutory authorities nor government departments of the Commonwealth but are nevertheless bodies for which the Commonwealth is wholly or partly responsible. These bodies are established through a variety of means-letters of exchange, agreements between States and the Commonwealth, ministerial fiat, order in council, creation of companies and by informal agreements. They cover many functions of government and are an important source of policy and administrative advice. However, there is little scrutiny of the establishment, operation and administration of these bodies. In fact there is concern in some places that they may not be effectively responsible to anyone.
The Royal Commission on Australian Government Administration initiated a study of these bodies. A paper prepared for the Commission recommended that:
. . . a committee or office (or a parliamentary committee) should be created to review the operation of such bodies.

The Commission in its report recommended that a review be undertaken by departments, in consultation with the Public Service Board. Departments have generally kept these bodies under review; however, the Committee believes that a comprehensive review is required. The Committee also asked the Public Service Board whether any reviews had been undertaken and was informed that no co- ordinated action on this matter had been taken.

The Committee in the course of its inquiry will seek to identify the number and type of bodies within this category, their cost, their present accountability to the Parliament and whether that accountability is satisfactory. The Committee will write to each Minister seeking information on all such bodies for which he or she is responsible and will hold public hearings next year.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: NATIONAL CRIME AUTHORITY BILL 1983NATIONAL CRIME AUTHORITY (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: Reference to Standing Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That the National Crime Authority Bill 1983 and the National Crime Authority (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1983 be referred to the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs for inquiry and report, on or before 30 April 1984, as to whether the Bills fulfil effectively the objective of investigating organized crime and official corruption.

(2) That the Committee confine its inquiry and report to the terms of the Bills and associated policy matters, and not receive any evidence, or conduct any investigation, relating to any individual person or body.
(3) That, for the purpose of the inquiry, the membership of the Committee be increased to 8 Senators.
(4) That one of the 2 additional members be nominated by the Leader of the Government and the other be nominated by the Leader of the Australian Democrats.

The reason why I, on behalf of the Opposition, move that these Bills be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs is really based upon the very chequered history that these Bills have had during the life of this Government. When this Government was elected to office in early March this year, the Fraser Government's National Crimes Commission Act had already been passed by the Parliament. It was passed at the end of last year. Although it had not been proclaimed it was on the verge of being so proclaimed. A chairman-designate, Sir Edward Williams, a justice of the Supreme Court of Queensland, had been appointed and had already commenced a good deal of work in preparation for the proclamation of that Act. The policy of the present Government, as stated during the election campaign, was to review the structure, functions and powers of the National Crimes Commission. It stated that it supported the concept of a crimes commission with sufficient powers to continue and widen the vital investigative work commenced by the Costigan Royal Commission into the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. So the present Government gave a very firm commitment in its election policy that it would proceed with the establishment of a crimes commission. In fact, it said that the Crimes Commission should have sufficient powers to widen the vital investigative work commenced by the Costigan Royal Commission.

Early in April, about a month after the Government was elected to office, the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) and the former Special Minister of State indicated the program of review that was foreshadowed in the Labor Party's policy speech. That involved the preparation of a Green Paper and a seminar of interested groups and experts in the field, followed of course by a review and decision by the Government and a presentation of legislation to this Parliament. However, the history of the matter since then has been one of constant retreat by the Government from the principles and approach of the previous Government and of the National Crimes Commission.

The Government has been subjected to considerable pressures, particularly by those who were critical of the National Crimes Commission on civil libertarian grounds. I have never understood why that should be the case because some of the basic civil liberties principles, such as the privilege against self- incrimination, were laid down and preserved in the National Crimes Commission Act. Certainly, other provisions of that Act, such as the non-identification in reports of the Crimes Commission of persons suspected of committing a crime were also preserved. Many of the objections which I heard at the seminar in this chamber at the end of July which discussed the Green Paper seemed to be based upon a complete misunderstanding of or a lack of attention to, I would have thought, the actual provisions of the National Crimes Commission Act. The Government, of course, has also been subjected to a good deal of influence by some of the States in regard to the review of the National Crimes Commission Act .

Finally, it is notorious that the Government has been subjected to considerable problems-naturally, I do not know the exact nature of them or the reason for them-in getting Caucus to approve the legislation that is now before us. So, as I said, we now have before us a product of a retreat by the Government over a period of six or seven months, and a considerable watering down of the National Crimes Commission Act. I think the Attorney-General was quite prophetic in an interview he gave on the Sunday program on 16 October this year, when he was asked this question by Richard Farmer about the proposal for a crimes authority: 'Do you expect that you will end up with an authority?' Senator Evans said: 'I think we will end up with something'. That about sums up what we have before us. We have something which resembles a national crime authority or a national crimes commission. I readily concede that it has a lot of very sound provisions. A lot of the powers in it are very adequate, and the protections of civil liberties are very adequate. Nevertheless, we do not have before us a proposal for an effective type of authority which the National Crimes Commission Act of the previous Government provided. We debated this subject at some length in the Senate a few weeks ago and I said then that we definitely needed an authority or a commission-it does not matter what we call it-which could act firmly, effectively and fearlessly. I was referring particularly to the views that Mr Redlich, the Special Prosecutor, expressed in his report to this Parliament. He said:

Now is the time to implement a scheme which will result in effective national law enforcement through co-operation and co-ordination. What is required is a national response to a national issue. A robust, independent national Authority, unfettered by jurisdictional or bureaucratic constraints must be created.

I commend the efforts that have been made by the Attorney-General in this area, but I believe that one of the problems that has occurred is that in an effort to obtain participation by the States, which I concede is a most desirable objective, a tremendously high price has been paid. In the first place we have to decide whether that price is such that the Authority will be hamstrung and not able to operate in an effective manner. Of course, the other matter about which we do not have any guarantee is whether the States are going to participate in this scheme. I asked the Attorney-General a question a week or two ago and he was unable to say whether the States will participate, and if so, which States.

Before the Senate passes this legislation we need to know two things: Firstly, whether the Authority can operate in view of the way in which it has been hobbled and hog-tied in this legislation; and secondly, whether there will be virtually full participation and co-operation by the States in the whole scheme. We could end up with the worst of all worlds, without proper participation of the States and with the creation of an ineffective authority. Although I think it is important that a crimes commission should be on foot, and as soon as possible, it is no good setting up a body which is not going to be effective. That may well prove to be quite counter-productive.

As I have said, some aspects of this legislation I think have very serious deficiencies and compare very unfavourably indeed with the proposals for the National Crimes Commission. I believe that the most serious limitation on the effectiveness of this body is that it cannot investigate matters of organised crime, or-what is called in the Bill relevant criminal activity. It cannot investigate those matters or exercise its compulsive powers except in relation to a reference given to it by a new body that is created which did not feature in the National Crimes Commission Act, known as the intergovernmental committee. An intergovernmental committee will be established comprising Ministers from the Federal Government, State governments and also the Northern Territory. This body , by a majority vote, will be able to determine whether the National Crime Authority can conduct an investigation. It is all very well to say-I know what we will hear from the Attorney-General-that the Authority can do other things. It can collect intelligence and co-ordinate police task forces, whatever that really means. It can co-operate with the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence. There is a very great question mark in relation to the effectiveness of that Bureau. The general feeling seems to be that it has not been effective at all. It can make recommendations about law reform and so on. That body can do a number of things. It can only carry out its most important function-namely, the investigative powers it has in the exercise of its major function-in relation to a reference which is approved by the majority of the members of the intergovernmental committee. It is called an intergovernmental committee in the legislation but these days such bodies are commonly called ministerial councils.

I believe the most serious limitation on the role of the Authority is the ambit and extent of investigation of crime at the federal level. Clearly royal commissions have established that. There is no argument about that. We are as one on the need for this Authority. We are as one on the magnitude of the problem. The Authority must be able to act independently, firmly and fearlessly. It will be unable to act in relation to this most important aspect of its functions without the political approval-that is what it boils down to-of Federal and State Ministers. They will make decisions at a political level as to whether the Authority can investigate a matter.

Even though this Authority is to be set up by the Federal Government-it will be a creature of this Parliament-the Government will not be able to put powers into the hands of the Authority without the approval of the intergovernmental committee. Of course, a State Minister also may want the Authority to act in relation to organised crime at a State level. That Minister also will be unable to give a reference to the Authority without the approval of the intergovernmental committee. I think we all know perfectly well what occurs when we have intergovernmental committees, ministerial councils or whatever they are called, particularly when they have got executive functions. If they meet to try to co-ordinate activities and so on there is usually a great delay in getting any decisions. If that Committee is to perform the executive functions then opportunities will be provided for political bargaining, vetoing and general horse trading which may well occur. The Authority, as I said, is hobbled by that situation.

Another matter of concern is the composition of the Authority. It is to be comprised of a chairman, who is to be appointed by the Governor-General, and two other members. That is all. The two other members are to be nominated, one by the unanimous decision of the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General, and other by the unanimous decision of the Police Ministers Council. One wonders just who, in the end, will be the product of these unanimous decisions in this area. Choosing the right person may be very difficult to achieve. I do not know; it may work out all right, but I think that it will be a great difficulty. I readily agree that if the Authority is to be a body in which the States participate, the States ought to have significant representation on it. But I do not think that they should end up with two out of the three members.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy President. I raise this point seriously. How are we to distinguish in the debate on this motion between second reading debate speeches, which would be appropriate to putting the case for or against the fundamental clauses of the Bill, and those matters which are relevant to the motion? Is it not sufficient to say that the members of the Liberal Party and the National Party are opposed to the Government's Bill in this regard and want to send it to a committee, and that we should get on with the actual debate as to the urgency or otherwise of getting the Bill passed by the Parliament? That is really the choice facing the chamber. A long catalogue of matters which are really relevant to a second reading debate on the Bill seems to me to be irrelevant.
—Senator Durack is advancing arguments as to why this matter should be referred to a Senate standing committee rather than being dealt with by the chamber, and he is in order in what he is saying.

—Mr Deputy President, I am not engaged in a long catalogue. I have spent most of my time on general questions relating to the motion. I am just giving some examples of problems that I see in the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Another major problem that I see in this legislation-in order not to disturb Senator Tate too unduly, I shall not take long on this subject-is in the very restricted definition of what is called relevant criminal activity and various exclusions from what may be very obvious lines of inquiry in relation to organised crime and official corruption, particularly the fact that the relevant offences must carry a term of imprisonment of not less than three years. Furthermore-and this is a very surprising point-the offence must not arise out of a genuine dispute as to matters pertaining to the relations of employers and employees. When there are restrictions of that character on what a body of this kind can do in attempting to investigate areas in which there is so much wealth on the part of the suspect and so much ability to obtain expert advice and carry on all the legal manoeuvres under the sun, this is a gold-mine for the objections that people would have to the Authority investigating them or anything at all. We know what has happened. We have the experience of the various objections that have been taken where royal commissions' powers have been challenged, and so on. People may or may not be justified in the challenges that they make; I am not making any comment about that. But with provisions of this kind, we will be giving those who want to prevent the Authority from exercising its powers, those who want to stymie its activities, the most golden opportunity to do so.

Those are some of the considerations that we should have firmly in mind. Certainly they would be objections which would be raised to this legislation passing in its present form if we were engaged in the dabate of the measure itself or in its Committee stage. I simply give those as examples of matters that need very close attention. Preferably, they need the close attention of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. We need to have expert advice in relation to these matters. There are plenty of experts in this field. At the crimes seminar held in Canberra a number of royal commissioners expressed their views. Of course, very few honourable senators were at that meeting. I believe it is appropriate that a measure of this kind should be examined by a committee which would inform the Senate as a whole of whether a number of these provisions would unduly restrict the operations of a crimes authority or whether there may be some ways in which such problems could be overcome, or whether some other amendments may be indicated.

We ought to take the utmost care in our approach to this legislation. It is not simply any old legislation that we are being asked to pass. It is not a matter of what the Attorney-General said in his second most famous throw-away line: 'I think we will end up with something'. That really is not good enough. It is the duty of the Senate to look at this legislation carefully with the help of expert advice and comment. There should be a report on the matter by a Senate committee before we embark upon the second reading consideration of the measures.
