The other important thing for the Senate to ascertain is the views of the States and whether they will participate in an authority. That is very clearly a consideration. The Government may well make a number of concessions which it would prefer not to make for the sake of having State participation. I can understand that very well. But I do not think we are in a position at this stage to know whether the price that is being paid is too high, whether further negotiations may be able to get changes in that attitude, or indeed whether we will get the benefit of State participation at all.

This legislation was introduced only last Thursday. It was listed for debate yesterday, less than a week after it was introduced. It is major legislation which deserves much closer attention and much lengthier consideration than the time frame that the Government has laid down, or which it proposes to lay down, would permit. The Government wants the matter debated today, if it is not referred to a committee. I do not believe that that is adequate time for consideration of measures such as these, bearing in mind the length of time the Government has spent in coming forward with the legislation. As I said, the Government embarked upon consideration of it soon after it came into office. It has been engaged in long behind the scenes negotiations, the details of which are not known to us. I do not say that those details ought to have been revealed , but the Government has had long behind the scenes negotiations with the States and deliberations in Caucus meetings. I think it is quite churlish to suggest that the Parliament should, without proper time for consideration, rubber stamp the product of these negotiations simply because the Attorney-General has been held up for some time as a result of them.

I believe that this legislation should not be rushed. We are making now a major decision in response to a very major matter. The proper way of approaching it in the best tradition of this Senate is to refer the legislation to a committee at this stage. I instance the way in which the Freedom of Information Bill was dealt with. It was introduced and referred to a committee. Of course, that committee did a very good job. Both Senator Tate and Senator Evans were members of it. That tradition was very sound. Not only that Bill but many other Bills were referred to a Senate committee. In the era of the Whitlam Government the National Compensation Bill was also referred to a Senate committee. I do not think in this case that the Senate Committee would need a great deal of time to consider these matters.

One pity of references to Senate committees has been that they have taken too long to consider the legislation. In this case a date has been given, 30 April next year, which should be ample time for consideration. I hope that the Committee can do the job in a much shorter time. If it did so, it could report before that date. Even following that timetable, the legislation could be resolved before the end of the autumn session next year. There would be very little delay in establishing the Authority because it is not anticipated that it would be established until April of next year in any event. Despite earlier assurances that it would be up and in business by 1 January next year, that timetable has been put back, I understand, to April. Thus, consideration of the legislation by the Committee should not delay establishment of the Authority.

The terms of my motion ask that the Committee confine itself to the actual terms of the Bill and the policy related to it. It is not to embark upon any sort of witch hunt or McCarthyism or to give any opportunities to people to misuse the Committee. That is very firmly provided for in clause 2 of the terms of reference.

TALK.START.PARA: —It wasn't in your first draft.

—I readily agree that the suggestion was made to me, but to have asked the Committee simply to look at the effectiveness of the Bill would have confined it in that way. But to make doubly sure, clause 2 has been included. For all these reasons, I hope that the Senate will give support to the motion that the legislation be referred to the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will come as no surprise that the Government rejects this motion of Senator Durack, because we want to proceed without delay to the establishment of a National Crime Authority . What does come as a surprise, and should come as a surprise to all honourable senators, is that this motion should come forward from Senator Durack. Only a month ago, on 18 October, Senator Durack rose in this place to lead debate on a matter of urgency. He moved:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The need for the Hawke Government to establish a National Crimes Authority without delay.

He did not ask that legislation be introduced without delay but that a National Crime Authority be established without delay. He reviewed the length of time it had taken and the degree of debate that had already been had on this issue and said that the time had come for action. He said that there may be legitimate grounds for disagreement about the precise form in which the authority might be created, but that was no excuse to prolong the debate, to prolong that disagreement, that what was needed was Government action. On page 1646 of the Senate Hansard, he is recorded as having said:

Whether it is in the form of the National Crimes Commission that we sought to establish by legislation that we introduced and passed through this Parliament, or whether it should be a somewhat different model is, I believe, a subject for very reasonable debate. In fact, reasonable debate has occurred amongst experts on that problem. There are differing views amongst experts on that problem. But what there is no difference about, what there is no doubt about, is that there has to be a response by the national government. There has to be an authority created-
I interpolate that he did not say merely that legislation should be introduced-
which can take this problem by the throat and deal with it firmly, effectively and fearlessly.

What was just a month ago unconscionable delay is now legitimate further time for discussion, debate, argument, reconsideration and listening to the further views of experts on this. What would have been in the previous incarnation of Senator Durack as a Minister in this place a sensitive accommodation to the constitutional principles of federalism, now becomes a matter of capitulating to the States; bending over backwards to accommodate the obstreperous views of the States who do want to have a share in the administration of this national Authority-and properly so because, as we all know, organised crime in this country cannot be tackled without the effective co-operation of every unit in the Federation. Some people might describe this adjustment of perspective as a matter of situation ethics, I think that is the appropriate theological term for it. I would describe it as deserving no higher appellation than humbug and hypocrisy. There is no excuse whatsoever for the change of attitude that has been demonstrated here other than a willingness at all costs, irresponsibly, to score political points and to obstruct for its own sake.

Senator Durack himself acknowledged in his speech on 18 October that there had been extensive, prolonged debate on this issue. In fact he could hardly do otherwise; there was extensive debate in this place on all the basic principles that we are now talking about in the context of his own Government's National Crimes Commission Bill. That debate carried over immediately the new Labor Government was formed when I set about trying, very actively and I think fairly visibly, to overcome the deficiencies that were perceived in the Fraser-Durack model-comparatively minor deficiencies but deficiencies nonetheless-and to get a workable system into operation. When it became apparent that that could not be done without taking the debate back into the public domain, a Green Paper was produced in June this year. That Green Paper was then made the subject of a two- day conference in this chamber at the end of July, attended by every major interest group and every major person who has had a role in this area, on a professional or other basis, over the last decade or more. It was a good debate, a constructive debate, and it produced some constructive suggestions for solutions.

Those suggestions were followed up in the weeks and months that followed and very extensive rounds of negotiations, discussions and consultations with the States were held and an agreed position was reached. Certainly it was an agreement subject to the terms of the final legislation passed by this Parliament but we cannot ask any of the States to commit themselves overtly and publicly to something which has not yet achieved its final statutory form. But I assure Senator Durack and the Senate that there is no doubt whatsoever in my mind, as a result of the continuing discussions I have had with all the States, that there will be participation, that there will be co-operation, in one way or another, and that for the most part there will be full and total formal co- operation from the States in this particular model.

It is humbug, as I say, to suggest that anything more is to be gained by prolonging this debate. Certainly there may be something to be gained by prolonging the Committee stage debate. Certainly the view may be taken by some honourable senators that there ought to be formalised mechanisms, for example, for parliamentary consideration of the role and activities of the Authority and we would certainly be prepared to look sympathetically at that. But to suggest that there is a case for sending the whole thing back to the drawing board, to suggest, as Senator Chipp did yesterday, that there are fatal flaws in this legislation as it presently stands, I think is to misunderstand-whether deliberately or inadvertently I do not know-the nature of the exercise until now and the nature of the particular proposal before us.

What we do have before us is a Bill which strikes that very balance, but a balance nonetheless, between the very obvious and visible competing demands in this area. Essentially, there are three of them. The first is the demand for effective law enforcement, effective investigation, to back up the police forces , to fill in the deficiencies that have become so evident in the last decade or more in the way in which traditional policing has been able to respond to organised crime. The second objective that had to be met was the building in of appropriate safeguards for individual liberty in a way that would satisfy the legitimate concerns of all those people in the community who are concerned about the potential for organisations of this kind to acquire a life of their own, and a dangerous life of their own, in terms of the fundamental principles which we all espouse. There had to be, as a third objective, a properly derived, properly worked out, role for the States. I believe that in all those respects we have a model that is workable, that is effective and that is thoroughly defensible in principle.

There does not seem to be much dispute now so far as the adequacy of the safeguards of personnel liberty is concerned. There does not seem to be much dispute now from the States' point of view about the way in which their interests are accommodated. I am not suggesting there is universality or unanimity in this respect-that is difficult to achieve-but by and large the aspirations of the States themselves for a formal effective participatory role have been satisfied. The catch-cry now is really reduced to just one area of those targets that I talked about. It is reduced essentially to the effectiveness of this particular body, its capacity to fight organised crime effectively and its capacity to perform the functions that are so obviously lying behind the thoughts of those of us who have been trying over the months to develop an effective body.

In that respect I do think it is appropriate for me to try to answer some of the criticisms that have been made. The first point I make is that when one looks at the sharp-end powers, if I can use that expression, vested in the Authority they are in fact almost identical to the sharp-end powers in the Fraser-Durack National Crimes Commission Bill of the end of last year. The power to subponea witnesses to attend in person or to produce documents is there in almost identical terms; to the Durack-Fraser legislation the power to seek a judicial warrant for search and seizure of documents is there in almost identical terms; the power to get access to taxation records in appropriately defined and limited circumstances is there in almost identical terms; and the power to seek a judicial warrant to deny someone a passport to keep them in the country in the course of an investigation is there in almost identical terms. The powers are there.

True it is that these powers are accompanied by a different array of safeguards -a much more extensive array of safeguards-as to the way in which the Authority operates in the exercise of those powers. True it is for a start that there are very significant constraints on the kind of publicity which can be associated with an investigation during its course. There are very significant and much more extensive constraints than were evident in the previous Bill on the capacity of the Authority itself to release material or for other people to report it. They are appropriate constraints, given the nature of this body not as a court or tribunal determining guilt or innocence but rather as one which is engaged in preliminary exploratory investigations. True it is there are much more precisely defined limits as to the jurisdiction which can be exercised by the Authority. There is a much more precise definition of relevant criminal activity-a definition, in effect, of organised crime-but not such a precise or narrow definition that it will make in any way impossible or even difficult the effective performance of the Authority's functions in this area. True it is there are additional oversight constraints in terms of the role for the Ombudsman and the concept of judicial audit.

All of these things are very significant and substantial changes to the additional Fraser-Durack model but none in any way inhibits or limits the effectiveness of the Authority in going about its investigative business. I think there has been a total failure to appreciate that in most of the public debate and most of the public comment on this. The language that the Press Gallery has adopted, as usual, with its herd mentality, of the Bill being watered down from its original concept utterly fails to appreciate the fact that the Bill in the terms in which it finally appeared represents no watering down in any significant respect of the basic model that was presented originally to the Party not in a Bill but just general principle form. The Bill is effective so far as this particular balance of powers and safeguards is concerned.

So then the argument turns from the effectiveness of the Authority to perform its functions to the role that is proposed for the States, and the attack tends to centre on the so-called veto role that it is said will be played by the States in making impossible the effective embarking by the Authority on investigative activity that is likely to be at all meaningful when it comes to dealing with the Mr Bigs and the various other nasties around the country who are engaged unquestionably in very serious sophisticated criminal activity. What has to be appreciated about this-and I do not think it has been appreciated so far; certainly that is true in regard to the public appreciation, and I am not sure whether it has been fully appreciated by honourable senators-is that what is proposed here is no more than a formal recognition of what the case is already.

It is already the situation that whatever will the Commonwealth might have to establish in its own right an authority or agency or royal commission, with powers to move in and tear apart official corruption within a State involving breaches of State law only, whatever inclination the Commonwealth might have to move in on areas of illegal gambling, prostitution and things like that, which are again essentially matters wholly of State law, there is no capacity on the Commonwealth, as the Constitution now stands, to embark upon such activitity. There is no capacity in the Commonwealth to vest coercive investigative powers in this respect into a statutory authority of its own creation. There is no power in the Commonwealth to vest powers in a royal commissioner by way of letters patent to investigate breaches of State law unless the State in question also vests powers of that kind in the royal commissioner in question.

There is no power in a parliamentary committee established by this Parliament, by either House or jointly, to embark upon investigations, should it be so minded, of possible breaches of State law. It is beyond the constitutional competence of the Commonwealth, however much we might be minded to so embark upon these areas, to do that unless there is a reference of power from the State in question to the Commonwealth authority or body or individual in question. Unless the States co-operate, as the law now stands it is absolutely impossible for coercive investigative powers to be exercised in any respect so far as breaches of State law are concerned. So however much people huff and puff about the limitations imposed on the necessary co-operation of the States so far as any reference to the authority in a matter involving a potential or actual breach of a State law, it has to be appreciated that that is the situation now. Unless the States vest that authority in the authority or commission in question , it is impossible for those sorts of inquiries to be embarked upon.

The way the Authority will work is this: It is the case that the Authority, without limitation, without constraints of the kind I have just mentioned, can gather information and intelligence about anything it likes provided it does not seek to use coercive powers in the process. It is using the normal processes of co-operation, information exchange with the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence or State police forces, or in other ways acquiring information on the ground but not by way of search warrants and subpoenas, it can go for its life. It can cover the whole field. Equally, the Authority can embark upon its function of co-ordinating police investigations, including joint State- Commonwealth or multiple-State investigations, with each of the participating police forces exercising the powers available to them, without the necessity for any reference of a formal kind from the States concerned. That is, again, very much part of its functions.

It is only if the Authority wants to go beyond that stage of intelligence or information gathering, it is only if it takes the view that police powers are likely to be ineffective for the matter in question and that it wants to investigate the matter itself, using the inquisitorial and investigative processes available to it, it is only under those circumstances that a reference will be required. That reference has to be initiated, or at least acceded to, by the jurisdiction concerned. If the matter the subject of the investigation involves breach of the laws of a particular State, it has to be the case, true, that that reference is initiated or acceded to by the State or by the jurisdiction in question. I repeat that that is the situation under the law as it now stands. No amount of huffing or puffing will gainsay that short, simple and obvious fact.

If the Authority wants a reference in an area and if it is initiated or acceded to by the particular jurisdiction in question, then the only other hurdle that has to be surmounted is agreement by a majority of members of the Inter- Governmental Committee that that reference should proceed. There has been some confusion about that. Some people seem to think that any State has a veto over any reference that it does not like so far as its operation in its own State is concerned. That is not the case. The only situation is that if the reference extends to the investigation of breaches of a particular State's law or, in the case of the Commonwealth, the Commonwealth's law, that jurisdiction has to accede to the exercise of the reference in that way. But a reference of general application involving breaches, say of Commonwealth law, can apply nationwide and there is no question of a veto from any individual State. It is possible for the Inter-Governmental Committee as a whole to band together and deny the Authority some reference it is seeking, even though the jurisdiction or jurisdictions in question are keen for that reference to proceed. But as a practical political matter we all know that any such attempt at denial of the exercise of such powers in that way would be destined to absolute disaster. It simply could not be justified politically if the proposed reference had any semblance of credibility about it, as I assume it would.

The other point I make in this respect is that when one talks about organised crime, the overwhelming majority of the criminal offences that are involved really do, so far as the really key operator, the Mr Bigs, are concerned, involve Commonwealth offences. They involve the importation of drugs, which is a Commonwealth offence. They involve tax fraud and tax evasion in a number of different ways, which are Commonwealth offences. They involve corporate frauds of various kinds, very often but not always involving Commonwealth offences. They involve, usually, off-shore monetary transactions which involve breaches of Commonwealth offences. All the major sorts of things that have been the subject of revelation by the Stewart, Woodward and Costigan commissions have been essentially focused around Commonwealth offences. It is perfectly clear that the Commonwealth itself can initiate references accordingly on all the key areas of organised crime based solely on its own capacity to initiate references for possible breaches of Commonwealth law. So even in the event that a particular State, or one or more States, does not want to co-operate in an investigation so far as that part of it is concerned which may involve breaches of the State law, those references and investigations can still proceed. So far as this Government is concerned, I assure the Senate that the investigations will proceed because we are totally and unequivocally committed to rooting out organised crime in this country to the extent that we possibly can.

There are problems with further delay in this respect. There are two parts to the argument. The first part is that we are unlikely to do much better than the model we have presently reached. The second part of the argument is that there are difficulties with further delay in this matter. Let it be appreciated that it is not a matter of delay in this respect merely for one or two months. There is and will be a very substantial transition period involved, once the legislation is in place, before the new Authority can be effectively on foot, and before the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union can be asked properly to terminate its formal existence. At the moment we have assessed that transition period as taking necessarily something like four to five months from the enactment of this legislation, which we hope will occur sometime later this month or early December. Accordingly, we have indicated to Mr Costigan the current timetable we would be working on; that is, the enactment of this legislation either late this month or early December, the formal creation of the new Authority on 1 March next year, and a transition period extending both before and after that formal creation for a couple of months either side, running to a proposed termination date of around 30 April. It may well be that that has to be further extended because of the enormous logistic difficulties associated with gearing up the new organisation and putting existing inquiries on the new footing that they have to be put on in order to satisfy the terms of this new legislation.

To delay any possible passage of legislation, as is proposed, until the end of May or early June-that is, the end of the autumn session next year-will result in a slippage in this timetable where the new Authority will not be able to put on foot. We cannot ask people to gear up for something which has no legislative existence or authority behind it. The new Authority will not be able to be put on foot until well into the latter part of next year, and probably not until the end of next year, applying the sorts of rules of thumb I have just indicated. We are buying, by this particular exercise, not just a month or two's delay but a very substantial delay in the effective establishment of the proposed new authority. I do not believe that delay can be justified given the enormous processes of consultation that have produced the particular model that is now before us and given also the difficulties and, let us acknowledge it, the dangers associated with continuing on a de facto crime commission basis through the Costigan Commission.

I made clear my complete confidence and the complete confidence of the Government in the way that Mr Costigan is handling that Commission. However, I have also made clear on dozens of occasions publicly over the last year that I do not believe, the Government does not believe, I know the Australian Democrats do not believe, and I know that many people in the Liberal and National parties do not believe, that a full scale royal commission-type body is the appropriate way to deal with organised crime.

The second reading speech spells out the arguments. Royal commissions are devoted traditionally to identifying the truth of particular matters, throwing the spotlight of publicity on them and bringing them into the public domain. Royal commissions are not traditionally geared up for on-going investigations on a broad front designed essentially to generate the kind of admissible avidence which will result in prosecutions which will get people who deserve to be behind bars behind bars. There is a basic difference in function; there is a basic difference in approach. Royal commissions are geared by their very existence to the concept of publicity. There are very few constraints on commissioners and the way in which they conduct their proceedings. There are very few constraints on the way in which those proceedings may in fact be reported and the way they traditionally have been reported. In the process, an awful lot of people have had their reputations sullied and destroyed through no fault of the commissioners conducting the investigations but through the inherent defects built into the royal commission procedure. In addition, there are all the points that can be made about the removal of the traditional privilege against self- incrimination as part and parcel of royal commission procedures and so on.

There is the further point to be made-the obvious point-that the powers and terms of reference in relation to the royal commission presently in existence under Mr Costigan are enormously wide and enormously vague and are not such as to necessarily be appropriate for the kind of crime authority exercise that we have all been talking about for so many months now. So without implying any criticism at all-I would not want it to be seen that way-of what has been happening with the Costigan Commission, I make the point that it is simply inappropriate and potentially dangerous from the point of view of traditional civil liberty concerns shared by most people in this place for the Royal Commission to continue on the more or less open ended basis that we would be confronted with were this motion to succeed, were the National Crime Authority not to have a chance of establishment until around the middle of next year and were it not to be in a position of really taking over the field until towards the end of next year.

Finally, it may be that it is appropriate that there should be, in the view of honourable senators in this place, a more leisurely examination by honourable senators and by members in the other place of this whole concept as it has evolved-its strengths, its weaknesses and possible areas for improvement. I do not resist that. The Government does not resist that. We would be perfectly willing for a reference to be made now to either an existing Senate committee or perhaps a specially created committee for the purpose of reviewing in as much detail or with as much vigour as the committee wanted to, the developments so far, what we have got and what might be done by way of improvement. I express my personal view that I do not think it is possible to accommodate all the competing interests in any other way than the present legislation does. Maybe that is because I have been so close to it for so long. Maybe I have been too close to it. Maybe there are other perspectives that can be put upon it.

Do not let anyone take the view that this is in any way the product of hasty, overzealous or over-enthusiastic rushing in to legislate. The very points to the contrary were made strongly and effectively with a great deal of enthusiasm from the Opposition back benches in the debate in this place on 18 October. What we want is a body in existence which will get on with the job that we all know has to be done, a job that we all know must be done. What we want is a body that can secure the co-operation of the States and not be at war with the States which was the situation with the Fraser-Durack model that was created last year. What we want is a body that retains its effectiveness to subpoena witnessess, to issue search warrants, to have all those sharp-end powers that were there, and properly so, in the Fraser-Durack model last year, but which is at the same time sensitive to competing civil liberty interests and, in particular, sensitive to the requirement that those investigations not be conducted in the blaze of publicity unless and until such time as the hard admissable evidence is there to justify a charge to be heard and determined in the courts of this land.

We want something that will achieve those objectives. I believe that we have been through an enormous process of public consultation and discussion which has identified the issues and produced solutions which are workable. If it is thought that those solutions can be improved upon in the light of experience and in the light of further discussion over the next few months, by all means get on with that process. But I implore honourable senators not to use that as an excuse to stop further the development of an authority which is so long overdue and which is so desperately needed in this country if we are to tackle the cancer of organised crime.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are compelling and overwhelming reasons why the National Crime Authority Bill 1983 should be referred to a Senate committee. I intend in the course of my contribution to raise a series of questions which demand investigation. Let me say at the outset that there is an urgency for the establishment of a National Crime Authority. There is an urgency for one that works properly, not for one that can demonstrably do the reverse. Fundamentally, a number of questions have to be answered in any kind of inquiry. How is it that the goals as espoused in the second reading speech of the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) are diametrically opposed to the mechanism of this Bill? The second reading speech envisages a probing investigating body. The mechanism, as specified in the legislation is one that emasculates, obstructs and even puts investigation into retreat.

SPEECH.PARA: The test of this whole situation is a very simple one: Under this mechanism it would not have been possible for the Commonwealth to set up an inquiry similar to the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. The fact is that under this mechanism the Commonwealth would have needed the approval of the Victorian Government if it had wanted to inquire into the activities of the ship painters and dockers. This is a fundamental situation. We should bear this point in mind because virtually the great upsurge of demand for a national crimes commission comes heavily from the Costigan exposure of 35 bloody murders in regard to the ship painters and dockers, bottom of the harbour schemes and organised crime. I remind the Senate that the Victorian Police Force said that there was no need for such an inquiry into the ship painters and dockers even though only three of the offenders involved in some of the 35 murders have been brought to book. The Victorian Government said that it had been advised in this way. Therefore, under this mechanism there would have been a denial of such an inquiry. I remind honourable senators that only weeks ago the New South Wales Police Commissioner advised the New South Wales Government that there was no need for an inquiry in regard to the tapes concerning the former Minister Mr Jackson. Therefore, the mechanism by its very design will stop inquiry and will, in fact, encourage, because of an inability to inquire, the very things we are trying to probe.

Let me test the situation. Are we happy to have a mechanism in respect of which we could not establish inquiries such as the Costigan Royal Commission? The answer to that quite clearly must be no. Let me take these matters one by one. The Bill defines relevant offences. Are we happy to have a situation under this heading in which three things occur? First of all, a series of offences is specified and delimited so that there will be eternal court and legal arguments as to whether a particular offence can be included because it is not so specified. For example, I looked to see whether arson was so specified. Arson constitutes part of organised crime. I did not see it mentioned at all. Why do we do this? Are we happy, for example, to have a Bill which states that one cannot have an investigation at all unless the offence 'involves more than one offender and substantial planning and organization'? Are we saying that we have to prove a network exists in the first place and to prove that more than one offender exists even though we strongly suspect that there is a network and that there is substantial planning? But clause 4 (b) states that 'relevant offence' means an offence:
that involves more than one offender and substantial planning and organization;

What kind of a situation of hog tying is this? Those who know how the Federal Bureau of Investigation in America ultimately tracks down the big offenders of organised crime know that it starts through using patient investigation of petty crime in a whole pattern-prostitution, tax offences, pornography and a whole range of other things. Ultimately it establishes the pattern. But are we happy with this situation? I ask whether this Senate would be willing to pass a Bill which states:
''relevant offence'' means an offence-
the maximum punishment for which is imprisonment for a period of not less than 3 years;

In other words, are we willing to say that the Authority will not pursue in the course of its investigation such offences as prostitution, gambling, currency violations, and tax offences-mostly cases which do not attract the maximum penalty of not less than three years. If one wanted to design a Bill that put the final obstruction in the way of a search, one would put that clause in. After all, the most infamous of organised criminals, Al Capone, was caught when pursued for tax offences as such. The FBI was not looking for something which would be classed as a maximum offence which would involve imprisonment for three years. It looked at his tax affairs to get a lead-in. Yet here we are facing up to this Bill which has more defects than Senator Ryan's Sex Discrimination Bill which virtually has had to be completely rewritten.

So I pose this question: Are we happy about those three situations? Are we happy to say that under the constitution of this Authority the Commonwealth Government passes to the States its right of separate investigation of an offence which is wholly under Commonwealth law? I have never heard of such willing abdication in my life. In fact, what the Bill is saying is this: If the Commonwealth under clause 11 (1) wants to get a reference to this National Crime Authority in regard to a matter which is wholly under Commonwealth law, the only way it can do it is to get the permission of a majority of the Inter- Governmental Committee. In other words, if a majority of the States say no, the Commonwealth has hog-tied itself in that it will not be able to investigate a matter which is within its total sovereignty. The Commonwealth does not have just some minor obligations; it has absolute responsibility under Commonwealth law to discharge its rights and its responsibilities. I ask whether we are happy to pass a clause which states:

The Minister may, with the approval of the Inter-Governmental Committee, by notice in writing to the Authority, refer a matter relating to a relevant criminal activity to the Authority for investigation insofar as the relevant offence is, or the relevant offences are or include, an offence or offences against a law of the Commonwealth or of a Territory.

In other words, the Minister may do so. But he can get that reference only if the States say: 'Yes, we are willing for you to set up an investigation into a matter which is wholly your responsibility and in which you have passed the responsibility of the Commonwealth to the States'.

Incidentally, I notice that in proposing the setting up of the Inter- Governmental Committee no one has thought of the Australian Capital Territory. It has been ignored in the consultation in regard to setting up the Inter- Governmental Committee. Is it really intended that we should agree that we have a National Crime Authority which has a veto power like that of the Security Council in the United Nations? This veto power states that the only way in which issues can be brought up in the first place is: If it is a Commonwealth matter, it has to be raised by the Commonwealth; if it is a State matter, it has to be raised by the State concerned. If the State concerned says 'No, we do not want an investigation', it cannot happen. If a majority of States veto an investigation it cannot happen. If one wanted to stop or emasculate an instrument of investigation one would do that. I wonder how those who have been talking about the Costigan Royal Commission and extolling Mr Costigan's pursuit of crime would face up to this statement he made the other day:

Organised crime thrives on corruption: Any proper investigation of its activities will inevitably find evidence of corruption. If a State Government or the Federal Government has the right to forbid a particular line of investigation then the independence and integrity of the commission is destroyed .

What Mr Costigan said is that if there is a veto power the independence and integrity of the commission is destroyed. That could not have been more carefully done in this legislation. So I pose these questions in regard to the Inter-Governmental Committee: Is it good that there is no consultation with the Australian Capital Territory? Is it good that the Commonwealth should abdicate its own responsibility and powers? Is it good that there should be a veto? All of this is justified by the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) on the basis that this is the price that we have to pay for co-operation from the States. Honourable senators should not forget this: The price for co-operation with the States is that we pass our own power of investigation over to their hands. Can there be any national government on earth which is willing to say 'In regard to my national responsibilities in the case of drugs, currency, trade and passports and such major matters I will not act unilaterally in these investigations; I will ask the States: ''Please, may I set up an inquiry on these things?'' '? If a government were to do so it would be sending a clear warning-whatever the integrity of those concerned, everybody knows that leaks occur-to the offenders of what it intended to do. It will have disclosed its hand. This must happen in that situation. Is that what we want?

I was very puzzled indeed by the proposed constitution of this Authority. I was puzzled as to why one of its members should be appointed by a unanimous vote of the Ministers of the States who are responsible for police matters. In other words, what is the vested interest of the police forces of the States and the Commonwealth that they have to have a ministerial representative as such on this body, because that would be the de facto situation? This is a nonsense situation altogether. Why would one entrench vested interests in a body that, in fact, needs to be absolutely objective, needs to be free of any suggestion that there is any entrenched interest in it?

I cast no reflection on the average, decent policeman, but surely the main reason for the establishment of such an authority is that the ordinary law enforcement bodies-that is, the police forces of Australia-have been proven incapable, for whatever reasons, of pursuing organised criminals. Surely one would not want to suggest to the public that one is putting on this body what might well come to be a representative appointed by the police Ministers who would, of course, be consulting the Federal and State police forces in coming to those kinds of decisions. I cannot conceive anything that is more subjective or more Narcissus-like in its viewpoint than that situation. Is that what we will do in setting up such an authority?

I believe that the Minister accepts the principles that he expounds in his second reading speech, as I do; that is, the pursuit of organised crime and, indeed, the need to watch civil liberties. However, I believe his unhappy situation is that he cannot act on what he knows to be right because he is enslaved by Caucus on this issue, as he is on so many issues. He can shake his head, but the facts are there. He has been compromised out of principles.

Let me examine the situation. The second reading speech states that Australians are aware of the threat that organised crime represents to the economy. Perhaps that should refer to the threat organised crime represents to the community. Every one of us agrees with that. He then puts the balancing point-I do not disagree with it-that we must not endanger the rights and the liberties of individuals. That has never been thoroughly explored by the Australian Labor Party or by the Attorney-General. The endangering of the rights and liberties of individuals comes from organised crime. In fact, the great danger is that one will so protect the defendants and the suspects that the real liberties and freedoms of the citizens are destroyed. Those who know the great principles of liberty that have been expounded over the nineteenth century and beyond know that some restriction has to be placed on the rights of minorities to ensure the full freedom of the majority. Those who know that understand that this is a two- way principle.

I plead with the Government to recognise that not only do we have to protect individuals; we have to protect both sides. If, in the end, what we do is protect the criminal and therefore allow the freedoms and liberties of the ordinary community to be restricted and prejudiced, we have done a fundamentally wrong thing. Quite often we pursue a restriction on the freedoms of a minority in order to widen or guarantee the freedoms of the majority. Right through this there is a clear conflict of understanding of the real principles that have gone down in the last century or two-that is, the principles of liberty and freedom of the individual. I, for one, believe that if what all the royal commissions have said on organised crime is true-I accept that it is-such damnable restrictions and damage have been done to the freedoms and liberties of the ordinary citizens of Australia today that I would not shed a tear if some restrictions were imposed on those who cause or who are suspected to have caused such restrictions and damage, even though I believe to my back teeth in the principles of British justice. But one has to be careful of the fact that the organised criminal, who is of course amoral and knows that we as a community must obey the orthodoxy of democracy and the rule of law, says: 'I know the vulnerability, I know the soft underbelly of democracy. I don't have to conform, they do and they will bend over backwards to preserve liberty'. So the organised criminal exploits it.

The second reading speech states that we need to avoid the fragmentation of effort and ensure co-ordination and continuity in the fight. That is very good stuff indeed. Let me give an example. The National Crime Authority, in the words of the Minister, is designed to effectively co-ordinate and lead, on a national basis, the attack against organised crime. My goodness, how can we lead if, first of all, we have abdicated our basic national powers and responsibilities? We cannot and will not act unilaterally on things that are our responsibility to act on. We will ask the States: 'Please, may we do so'. The nonsense of the difference between the wording, the motherhood phrases, of the second reading speech and the emasculation and obstruction of the Bill make it clear that there should be a great deal of investigation on this matter. We have the fine phrases : 'checks, balances and limitations on the powers that prejudice the rights and liberties of individuals will be avoided'. Will they? Will this Bill put checks and balances on the rights and liberties of the ordinary citizen?

If this Bill, however inadvertently, restricts our ability to get to the soft underbelly of the criminal it damages the freedoms and liberties of the ordinary individual. This is the dilemma which America is faced with in the fifth amendment and the right to carry arms. But in Australia in royal commissions we have accepted the principle that a person can be compelled to give evidence against himself. Self-incrimination is accepted in royal commissions, but of course, it is not allowed to be used in any action that follows. This Bill removes that right in the investigation. It removes the basis of hearsay. If that is the case, it gives the Authority fewer powers than we have ever had before, certainly fewer powers than a royal commission has had and fewer powers than police forces have had in the past. Costigan said: 'By following a series of financial leads in a determined exploratory fashion, widespread and serious conspiracies can be uncovered'. Yet, as I have shown, this Bill, step by step, does not allow those small trails that lead to prostitution, gambling and crimes relating to currency and taxes to be followed because they do not attract a penalty of a maximum of three years gaol. In other words, it limits and restricts throughout.

Let me pull these questions together. The first question I posed was: Do we want a national crime authority that would not have allowed a Costigan-type inquiry into the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union to be set up? That must get the answer no. Yet, on this test, because the Government of Victoria, four years ago, received from the Victorian police the answer that there was no need for an inquiry, obviously such an inquiry would not have happened. Do we want the relevant offences restricted, as I said? Why would we want to restrict the offences to more than one offender, to demonstrate that crime must be organised? Why should we limit the investigation? Why in the name of heaven do we ask police Ministers to decide who shall be members of the Authority? Surely, members of the Authority should not represent police Ministers; they should not represent Attorneys-General. Members of the Authority should represent the ordinary people of Australia. They should have no responsibility to go back to their subjective interests and to justify what is happening to them. I cannot believe that one would want this situation. But the whole of this Bill ignores the recommendations of the Woodward, Moffitt and Williams royal commissions. It will make the work of the Special Prosecutor a great deal harder.

Equally, there is the question of the nature of the evidence and how it is heard. Much of the Bill gives the Authority the privilege of hearing evidence in private. Indeed, the discussion of a person's private life can be heard in private. However much one wants to protect the ordinary individual, the fact of the matter is that the media plays a vital role in any democracy in the exposure of corruption and in the beckoning of people to come forward to give more and more evidence. Would the investigations in New South Wales in the past have gone on without the probing of the media, without exposure of the allegations to the public and the responses of people so that the available evidence was locked into place?

I conclude by saying that I throw aside the Attorney's one attempt to say that two or three weeks ago the Opposition introduced a motion urging as a matter of urgency that a national crimes commission be established. He now says that we are urging a delay. We urged the establishment of a national crime authority that would work; that would carry out the responsibilities of the Commonwealth; that would be an effective institution. We asked him to create and bring forward urgently an effective mechanism.

He brought forward, as he does so often, a Heath Robinson contraption. We asked him to bring forward an authority that would probe. He has brought forward something that will obstruct and emasculate and that will, however inadvertently , protect the miscreants in our society. So let him not talk in that way. He has taken eight months to introduce his Bill in this House. A delay of a few more months in order to get an authority with a decent mechanism would be fully justified.

I believe that organised crime in this country has reached unbelievable proportions. Every day, it seems, in New South Wales more and more horrendous evidence comes forth that suggests that deep in our society there is a minority- not a majority, but an organised minority-that holds the rule of law in contempt , that is cocking its snoot at police forces, because the police forces are ill equipped to handle them. We need, above all, an authority that will not find itself caught in the web of competition and petty jealousies of the States, or particularly of the State police forces; not one that can veto cases because of some jealousy or competition but one that will get on with its job. Quite clearly and demonstrably-and many more questions could be posed-this Bill does not fulfil those requirements. Therefore, I commend strongly to the Senate that the Bill be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs under the terms of reference that have been laid out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I say immediately that Senator Durack let the cat out of the bag in the concluding stage of his speech when he referred by way of analogy to the Senate's treatment of the freedom of information legislation. What we have here, really, is sweet revenge. There is an air of retributive vengeance on the other side of this chamber. Having experienced when in government a hindrance or a delay to the passage of legislation which was thought to be important to the Government's political credibility-that is, fulfilling the promise on freedom of information-the former Attorney-General and his colleagues on the other side of the chamber are now only too pleased to frustrate and impede the passage of legislation by the device of sending it to a Senate committee. It is a device, as I will explain later on.

SPEECH.PARA: But there is really no analogy, because freedom of information dealt with the relationship of citizens to the bureaucracy, which is important. In this instance, we are delaying this legislation, despite the urgency and the demonstrated and acknowledged necessity on both sides of the chamber of the need to create an organisation which can effectively investigate the commission in a sophisticated way of certain relevant criminal offences in this country. Even though it is acknowledged on both sides of the chamber that something needs to be done urgently, an impediment to and a frustration of that project has been put forward. Really, it boils down to an embarrassment of the Attorney-General ( Senator Gareth Evans). That is what the bulk of honourable senators opposite are trying to do by moving the motion which is before the chamber today.

To speak of the Attorney's continuous retreats in the contemptuous way which has flowed from honourable senators opposite is to completely and wrongly characterise what has been a process of consultation with the general community and with the States. After all, this is a federation, as we are constantly reminded from the other side of the chamber, with jurisdictional boundaries and areas which can be overcome not by a stroke of a legislative pen, but only by constitutional means which are in no way in question. The fact is that we do live within a federation which has required certain consultations which have been arduous, but which have been undertaken by the Attorney and which have resulted in a certain structure of the Bill which does not apparently appeal to the Opposition.

The consultation of the Attorney went further and within the party forums was quite extensive and prolonged, as I, as Chairman of the Caucus Legal and Administrative Committee, can attest. But once again, that was to the betterment and refinement of the Bill. There is nothing to say that that betterment, refinement and modification of the Bill could not take place during the Committee stage of the debate in this place. If the Opposition has the numbers to have this motion carried, it will certainly have the numbers to bring any fair-minded proposals to the chamber to modify some clause of the Bill, get the support of enough members of the Senate and have that modification carried. The fact is that this is a delaying tactic to further embarrass the Government in the fulfilment of what was a very clear undertaking of the Government from its very earliest days in office. There is no other way to put it.

As I say, there is no way that State jurisdictional boundaries can be overcome. Senator Sir John Carrick, in his description of the type of intergovernmental committee and authority which is to be established and composed in the way it will be, or is proposed to be, did not give due justice to that need to find a national mechanism which will have the support of the investigating, enforcement and prosecuting agencies in the States. He referred to the painters and dockers. But I remind Senator Sir John Carrick that that is a prime example of the formal mechanisms that have been incorporated. The Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union is, of course, a joint royal commission. In order to make it effective and to embrace all the jurisdictional questions involved, a commission had to be given by the Governor-General of Australia, representing the national interests, and by the Governor of the State , representing the State interests. I think that is a sufficient and very relevant answer to the sort of charge that has been laid against the Attorney's and the Government's preferred structure for the necessary mechanism for this Bill. Senator Sir John Carrick I thought got a little carried away. It is a fact that one is concerned with the rights of citizens to live in an environment free of fear, free of corruption, free of distortion of their social life, and indeed free of the threat to actual life and limb which unfortunately is associated with organised crime in Australia. In trying to deal with that phenomenon, I remind Senator Sir John Carrick of the words of Mr Justice Kirby at the National Crimes Commission conference held here in Parliament House, in this very chamber , in late July of this year, when he said:

Many people in Australia-perhaps even the majority of the population-are not fully aware of or, when aware, are not really sympathetic to these limitations on the powers of officials. Because they do not themselves contemplate crime they are quite prepared readily to abandon or modify basic principles which govern the relationship between authority and the individual.

I think that statement by Mr Justice Kirby is very true, and one of the few in that learned gentleman's address with which I would whole-heartedly agree. I think that explains much of the process of consultation and, indeed, the modification of the Bill which has taken place within the forums of the Australian Labor Party in latter months. The Government has produced its Bill. My plea to the Senate is that this Government is entitled to have its Bill passed into law to enable it to say to the Australian people: 'After going through the processes of consultation with the public, with the relevant State and Federal authorities'-I have explained how that process took place and has effect within the Bill and within the Party-'this is the Labor Government's attempt to deal with the problem of organised crime in Australia by means of a national crimes authority'. We are entitled to our Bill, just as the then Government was entitled to its Bill last year, despite serious misgivings on this side of the chamber. It was given its Bill despite the expression of those misgivings. However, because of the lack of consultation by the then Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, and the then Attorney-General, Senator Durack, with the States, the previous Bill was introduced into this Parliament in the very week that a sham consultation was going on with State authorities in relation to the necessary underpinning of the Bill. The States withdrew their support and the former Government was never able to proclaim its Bill because it was never able to regenerate that support. Nevertheless, the Parliament gave that Government its legislative framework, its legislative mechanism, to establish a national crimes commission, as it was then called, in order to deal with what we all acknowledge is a very real problem.

I say to the chamber that this Government, in fulfilment of its mandate, is entitled to its legislative attempt to grapple with this problem and set up a national mechanism to investigate organised crime. I thereby, though, do not want to put to one side the entire intent of the motion before the chamber. Rather than indulge in endless second reading speeches such as those from the other side of the chamber, I will now confine myself to the terms of the notice of motion. As Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, naturally it is a matter of concern to me. My preferred solution to this impasse we seem to have reached would be to plead with the Senate to give the Government the legislation for which it will have to take responsibility in the electorate, but give to the Committee a reference which would embrace the reports of Special Prosecutor Redlich, the interim reports of Commissioner Costigan, perhaps of the Act, the legislative product concerning the National Crimes Authority, give us those references and reports which would provide a much more comprehensive basis for the sort of investigation which this chamber's committees are able traditionally to undertake. In other words, it would take us further than merely a narrow consideration of the clauses of this Bill.

Such a reference would enable us to look at all those matters which, to take one instance, Special Prosecutor Redlich says need to be looked at, for example, law reform in relation to the Commonwealth Crimes Act, and the need to create and review the range of offences there provided in relation to supra-State criminal activity. We could also have a look at the question of administration within government departments which, as all commissioners have reported and as the Special Prosecutor has reported, is a cause for concern. There is such jealousy in relation to the turf of one department that it does not make the proper authorities aware of suspected criminal activity which comes within its scrutiny or knowledge. We could have a look at a whole range of matters in relation to statutory authorities such as Telecom Australia. We could call before us private institutions such as the banks and other financial institutions which, as the reports of Costigan and Redlich and so on have demonstrated, have a role to play in the pursuit of organised criminal activity within Australia. We could have a much more comprehensive examination of these problems. I ask those few honourable senators on whom this decision might depend to consider that as an alternative means of approaching the matter. I confine myself now to the actual terms of the motion, which state:

That the National Crime Authority Bill 1983 and the National Crime Authority ( Consequential Amendments) Bill 1983 be referred to the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs for inquiry and report, on or before 30 April 1984, as to whether the Bills fulfil effectively the objective of investigating organized crime and official corruption.
Then follows a paragraph which I acknowledge is largely inserted because of fears and misgivings which I made known in the corridors of this place over the last 24 hours or so, namely:

That the Committee confine its inquiry and report to the terms of the Bills and associated policy matters, and not receive any evidence, or conduct any investigation, relating to any individual person or body.

Acknowledging, perhaps, the good will of those who have juxtaposed paragraphs (1 ) and (2) of the motion, I would say that really there is an intolerable tension between the two. I have maintained in the discussions that have taken place in the last day or so that the reference of the Bill to a Senate standing committee should not be a front or a subterfuge for a Senate select committee on organised crime, with a role assigned to it of investigating and adjudicating upon claims in relation to individual participation in alleged organised crime. I do not think we have the resources or the ability to undertake what would on some accounts become a sort of parliamentary royal commission, with all the dangers that that holds of becoming a McCarthyist parliamentary royal commission, with parliamentarians using the opportunity to grandstand in a way which would attract the sub-editors and the good headlines in the media but would not necessarily allow us to come to a conclusion which would lead to a sensible resolution of the problem of organised crime in Australia. Certainly we would be inundated with evidence which would not be of an admissible character such as would sustain any prosecution.

In order to protect against that real misgiving of mine, paragraph (2) of the notice of motion does say that the Committee should not receive any evidence or conduct any investigation relating to any individual person or body. I say two things to that. Firstly, of course, we cannot stop the reception of evidence, in the sense that the sending of evidence to a Senate standing committee is itself a privileged act. There can be no law or hindrance put in the way of the sending of evidence to a Senate committee. Once it is within the Senate committee's possession, then it becomes a question of what the Senate committee does with that evidence. If the Senate committee publishes the evidence, of course qualified privilege will attach to so much of that evidence as is published. Therefore we will have a situation where I can see this Committee receiving a tremendous volume of evidence which, in order to avoid a situation where qualified privilege by way of media report attaches to the publication of that evidence by the Senate Committee, we will have to go into camera time and time again. The Committee will have to try to deal with these matters in a way which is so secret and which will lead to a whole range of questions about the protection of witnesses. I believe that we will get into a situation where it will be questionable whether the public will have confidence in the operations of the Committee which will have to operate in a secret way to ascertain the value of evidence which it will receive. Of course, nothing can be put in the way of the reception of evidence which, as I say, is privileged when sent to the Committee.

Quite apart from that, as I said, there is an irreconcilable tension between paragraphs (1) and (2). If the Committee is to deal effectively with the reference which requires it to ascertain the effectiveness of the Bill as a means of investigating organised crime and official corruption then surely the Committee will have to take evidence which will involve certain people. For example, one would want to probably call Mr Peter Bennett of the Customs Officers Association who, in what I think was a very good contribution to the National Crimes Commission Conference, amongst other things, said:

. . . silence and lack of action is often forced on concerned public servants including police officers. Often the bureaucracy fails to develop and maintain proper checks and control measures in their systems. When officers identify those shortcomings they are often faced with two options. Either they put a muzzle on it and keep their mouths closed and keep their jobs or they put their public concern above their personal costs and they buck the system.

So it goes on. If we go beyond that abstract and general description of a situation which we might all suspect-it gains some credence because it comes from an officer of a union which is involved in the customs area-and test the real credibility of that sort of assertion surely we will have to ask for examples. Surely we will have to ask for a description of persons or situations where this is alleged to have been the case. We will have to investigate and receive evidence concerning individuals or particular sections within a department in order to fulfil our function, our primary responsibility, placed on us by paragraph (1) of the terms of reference contained in the motion. As I say, despite the fact that paragraph (2) tries to allay my worst misgivings I think that the Committee will be faced, in order to fulfil the primary objective outlined in paragraph (1), with the necessity to examine the truth of allegations concerning certain persons, organisations, departments or statutory authorities in order to come to a conclusion as to whether the Bill and the National Crimes Authority to be instituted and set up under it can effectively counter the sorts of practices which are revealed by an examination of the truth , the validity, and the veracity of allegations made concerning certain persons, organisations, departments, statutory authorities or whatever it may be.

TALK.START.PARA: —But that matter would be in your hands as Chairman. I would have total confidence in your ability to do that. I mean that.

—I appreciate that and I thank Senator Chipp for it. Nevertheless, a tension exists which I believe ought to be recognised by this chamber before it votes on the matter and which it should not be thought is solved simply by the insertion of paragraph (2) in the terms of reference. In case this matter is passed by the Senate-of course, the Senate Committee will accept the reference and discharge it in absolute good faith and as efficiently and expeditiously as possible-for the information of honourable senators, I point out that the Committee has before it at the moment two references and another which is lurking in the background. The Committee is presently undertaking public hearings in relation to the National Service Amendment Bill 1983. It is a private member's Bill which deals with the question of conscientious objection to service in the armed forces.
—Whose Bill is that?

—That is a private member's Bill introduced by a senator from this side of the chamber. That series of public hearings is drawing to a conclusion. I believe it will occupy the time of the Committee until Christmas. The Committee also has before it for examination the Joint Opinion dated 23 August 1983 of the Attorney-General and Solicitor-General given to the Royal Commission on Australia's Security and Intelligence Agencies concerning a statement made in the South Australian Parliament by the Honourable Peter Duncan MLA. That reference has been given to us. Advertisements were lodged with various national newspapers earlier this week. It is quite clear that that particular reference will have to be put to one side. That other reference is an expectation, after arrangements with the Law Reform Commission, that the Law Reform Commission report on privacy which I believe--
—It will be tabled quite soon.

—That report is to be tabled quite soon. It will form a short reference to the Committee, perhaps occupying the Committee for only a short time. Nevertheless, that is also on the Committee's plate. On the practical side of things, the fact is that Australia goes into a prolonged bout of festivities during the summer between Christmas Eve and Australia Day. We will then be in the middle of a referendum campaign which will commence, I believe, immediately after Australia Day through until 25 February. By the very nature of the composition of the Committee, many of its members will be engaged in the referendum campaign. The Senate will then resume on 28 February.

SPEECH.PARA: I am saying that it will not be an easy task to discharge our obligation to the Senate and the Parliament in the time set down in the motion. I acknowledge that the date is now 30 April rather than the end of March which was indicated in the draft copy circulated yesterday. I appreciate that extension. I want to put on the record the work load of the Committee. I want to give fair warning that the Committee will require expert assistance in order to discharge, to the satisfaction of the Senate, the reference which it appears may well be given to it. I oppose the reference of this Bill to the Committee. I, of course, say to the Senate that should that reference be given my Committee will do its best to discharge the obligation thereby placed on it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have strong reservations about the effectiveness of this proposed reference to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs and whether it will achieve anything significant in the way of improving the National Crime Authority Bill 1983. That is in no way a reflection on the Committee, its abilities or membership. That fact is that the legislation has already been widely debated in all levels of the community. Negotiations on its final form will be dependent, amongst other things-if it is to be changed from the form in which it is now before us-by agreement with the States. That is a matter which is beyond the powers of anything a committee of this Senate can do.

SPEECH.PARA: However, after very careful consideration of certain issues which lie behind this matter and which it would not be fair of me to discuss publicly, I will support the reference to the Committee on certain conditions. First, I have had an assurance from the Liberal Party-I take it that the assurance was made on behalf of the Liberal Party-I take it that the assurance was made on behalf of the Liberal members of this Committee-that the motion is designed so that the Committee can genuinely examine the Bill and try to improve it by exposing it to public discussion. I believe that is the proper, it is certainly the declared, intention of the motion as Senator Tate has said. Paragraph (2) of the motion states:

(2) That the Committee confine its inquiry and report to the terms of the Bills and associated policy matters, and not receive any evidence, or conduct any investigation, relating to any individual person or body.

If this reference succeeds the Committee should not be a muck-raking Star Chamber operating under parliamentary privilege-I use those strong words advisedly-as that would allow all and sundry to smear individuals with impunity, with no reason. I am afraid-Senator Tate's words have not reassured me-that it may well turn out to be that. I am not in the least reassured by Senator Durack' s words on, I think, AM this morning when he said that the inquiry would provide a vehicle for all those in Australia who want to speak out against crime. When Senator Durack speaks at the end of this debate I would like him to explain just what he meant by that. As far as I am concerned I support this motion on the basis of the Liberal Party carrying out the undertakings it has given to me. If it does not do that in future my support for the matters raised by the Liberal Party will be questioned seriously, especially if a similar situation arises again.

It is a fact that just a few words uttered before the Chairman can intervene can damage an individual at the hearing. One mischievous question and one brief reply could do the damage. Accordingly, I also give notice that I will not support in any circumstances any extension of the hearings of this Committee after the agreed last date of 30 April. So far as I am concerned, it ought to be able to report by that date if it confines itself to its proper functions. Certainly I will not support a muck-raking expedition which drags on through next year. I want to make that perfectly plain.

I shall also watch with care what happens at this inquiry, because I think that we have had enough unfair accusation of people by innuendo already, and to provide further opportunities under privilege is of no value. I hope that Senator Tate, as Chairman of this Committee, if it takes on this reference, will use its powers fully to operate in camera at the least suspicion that such an unfair episode is likely to occur. Senator Tate has made the point that it is almost inevitable that it will occur. The Committee's recourse is to operate in camera. If the Press criticises that because it cannot get out the muck-raking bits that it wants, so be it. It is the responsibility and duty of the Senate to see that individuals are not harmed unfairly. It is a fact that individuals have been harmed unfairly in parliaments time and again. That is one of the reasons, I believe, for the disrepute in which the chambers of the Parliament are being held by many Australians. It is a situation which the community properly should not tolerate.

Let us be reasonable and frank about this. There is a political motivation that is likely to be tempting. An election in New South Wales must be held before November of next year. I believe that I would support any justifiable and provable charge against people at all levels, including members of parliament and including members of the New South Wales Parliament, but I do not believe that a Committee of this Parliament ought to be allowed to become the unwitting vehicle of an election campaign of the muck-raking type for any political party. That point must be made abundantly clear.

I make one final point. I take issue with the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) for his mean, peevish and childish utterances appearing in this morning's Press about the Australian Democrats. I quote statements which are attributed to him. The Democrats are 'rather weak minded'; and 'The Democrats who have been wobbling about all day will see a little more reason in this respect'. I am astounded that a man of the intellectual capacity of the Attorney-General should allow himself to make that kind of statement. I for one did my level best yesterday to listen to and understand both sides of this matter. I put in most of my day listening to the Attorney-General and to the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney) in the belief that if one is to try to come to a rational decision, one needs to know the facts. That is not a matter of vacillation or of weakness. I should have thought that that is what we are here for.

It will be a grave disappointment to the Australian community to find that the Attorney-General shuns that, that he does not believe in that, and that he believes apparently that what he says is right and that anyone who disagrees with him is automatically wrong and must be attacked, under privilege, in the Press as being weak and wobbly. That may be his own morality. He is welcome to it. But I inform him that the Australian Democrats are here precisely to investigate issues carefully for as long as is necessary before a vote is taken, and then to cast our vote in the best interests of the community, not in the best interests of any other person or organisation who may be behind this blessed thing, which I believe is a very sorry situation on the whole. We have always done that and we always will. It is a pity that the Attorney-General, who is an intelligent and able man in many ways, demeans himself by his cantankerous habits.

Taking an optimistic view, which I hope is justified, I hope that this legislation will not be harmed other than by a short delay. With the whole concept of a National Crime Authority I suppose that it is right and proper that the community at large should have the chance of input to it. Then the Senate hopefully can look at the Committee's report, support amendments along lines that the Committee might propose-I stress 'might' because I would expect that there would be a minority report on this matter-and we could have a Crime Authority in place, one with teeth preferably, by June of next year. It is far better that we do that rather than create a paper tiger type of organisation at this stage and then pretend to ourselves that the paper tiger has teeth. That would be very much like the well-known story of the emperor's clothes. I urge the Senate, on the whole, to support this reference for that reason alone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support Senator Durack's motion that the National Crime Authority Bill be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs for inquiry and report. Before I commence the substance of my contribution, I assure Senator Mason that that Committee, of which I am pleased now to be Deputy Chairman, is not in the business of muck- raking. I also assure him that, from my personal point of view, my desire that this Bill be so referred to the Committee does not have a political motivation; rather, it is a motivation that is widely shared in this Senate-unanimously shared, I hope-that the National Crime Authority, or whatever it is to be called , will be effective. That is my motivation, and I am sure that it is the motivation of all on the Opposition side of the chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: I hope also that we do not reach the stage of minority reports.
