Certainly in the time that I have been serving on the Committee, I am pleased to say that minority reports have not been necessary. I am sure that the Committee will not be approaching its task with that in mind. I am pleased to see my Chairman, Senator Tate, nodding agreement to that. I know that Senator Tate does not want to hear history in this matter. He is concerned that this debate does not become a second reading debate. But in some ways, I think that that is necessary, because as I see the matter, what we have had is a long road, and we are now well down that road. However, there is considerable doubt remaining-it has been expressed in the Press and on this side of the chamber today-as to whether we have reached a stage at which the agreed objective will be achieved. As I have indicated, the agreed objective is an effective National Crime Authority.

The Senate will remember that I took an interest in the previous Government's Bill, which I supported in the end, but with considerable reservations. Those reservations were the obvious ones-that it was to be limited to breaches of Commonwealth law and corruption by Commonwealth officials. I must confess that I was surprised to hear the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) indicate-I thought that he was indicating it this morning-that perhaps that will be sufficient in itself to achieve the objectives that we all hold. I do not believe that that was his view in the past, and certainly it does not appear to be consistent with the view that has been expressed by such as Commissioner Costigan and the view as has been detailed this morning by my colleague Senator Sir John Carrick. I had that reservation. I thought that the body would be limited to breaches of Commonwealth law and corruption by Commonwealth officials , and I had reservations as to whether it would achieve the purpose for which I believed it was being set up.

I had the benefit of attending the National Crimes Commission Conference set up by the Attorney-General earlier this year as the Deputy Chairman of the Committee to which I hope this Bill will be sent, and I think it is fair to say that the Conference was a most worthwhile exercise. Certainly it showed the considerable disparity of views on the subject, which I suppose should have been obvious when one looked at the breadth of the organisations involved. Considering that on the one hand we had delegates from civil liberties organisations, the Law Council of Australia, special prosecutors and royal commissioners, and on the other hand, the Chairman of the Human Rights Commission and police commissioners, it is not surprising that there was a great disparity of view. Certainly there was no consensus.

The Attorney-General, in summing up, felt that he could define a majority view. I think it is fair to say that at that stage and over this considerable period during which we have been looking at this subject, majority views have been evolving. Since that Conference more disturbing reports have come before the Senate, further reports from Commissioner Costigan and reports of the Special Prosecutors Redlich and Gyles, which show, in the historical perspective, that the problem is continuing and in some ways is even worse than some of us may have previously appreciated.

That brings me to consideration of the present Government's Bill, which I have read carefully and which, as with that of the previous Government, I would not oppose. But I retain considerable reservations as to whether it will be effective. I have no doubt that those reservations have largely arisen from the compromises which, unfortunately, appear to be necessary in Bills that are produced through the Caucus system of this Government. All of us who support the concept of a crimes commission or a crimes authority want it to be effective. If we do not think that it will be effective we have to look to ways by which we can make it so. I submit to the Senate today that the best way we can achieve that objective, bearing a number of factors in mind, is to send it to a Senate standing committee.

There are two evils, two forms of crime that we are seeking to combat: Firstly, organised crime; secondly, corruption of officials and official bodies. I am pleased to see that both are specifically stated as such in this Bill. One reflects that the initial impetus for the commission early last year appeared to come out of apparent official corruption, the corruption of officials in New South Wales. As the year continued, we received the McCabe-Lafranchi report and the Costigan report, and the emphasis switched to organised crime. More recent events, unfortunately, have led us again to look in both directions, towards organised crime and corruption of officials. It is not unreasonable to say that the concerns that are apparent at the moment are quite distressing in that regard.

The corruption of officials obviously does not need further definition. The reasons for the failure of law enforcement agencies to deal with the corruption of officials is obvious. What is more complex is organised crime. It is not capable of precise definition, which I think comes through in this Bill, even though the Attorney appears in some way to have attempted to define it. It is usually better described by a description of the activities within its structure , the type of criminal involved, and the organisation it takes. As we know, that has been the way that Commissioner Costigan has approached the matter.

Costigan looks, for example, at the method of organised crime. He finds a basis of it in such things as prostitution, narcotics, pornography, loan sharking, gambling, starting price betting, casinos, organised labour, extortion and fraud . I invite the Attorney to reflect on those areas which Costigan sees as the basis for organised crime. If he does so I think he will find that all are subject to State law, yet the Attorney comes to the Senate today and suggests that organised crime may be able to be eradicated purely through a concentration on Commonwealth law. I am most surprised to have heard that from him today.

Organised crime obviously has an immensely broad basis. Costigan looks at the type of criminal involved: Those who supply the capital necessary for a criminal enterprise-the financiers; those who provide the sophisticated services- regrettably, members of the professions who are prepared to deviate from professional codes of ethics; the criminal entrepreneurs who put the schemes together; and, finally, what we refer to as, I suppose, the operatives, the criminals who execute the schemes. He looks at the organisation and points out that often it is of an interstate nature. He points to the modern methods of communications and other sophisticated techniques utilised.

I think it is now beyond dispute that organised crime exists and is flourishing in Australia. Unfortunately, it is some time since we have heard anybody in the Senate argue to the contrary. It is so flourishing despite orthodox methods of law enforcement. I do not intend to go through all the numerous commissions we have had but, to name a few, there have been the Moffitt, Woodward, Williams, Costigan and Stewart commissions. They have enforced in our minds the degree and depth of organised crime in this country. What is also not in dispute is the enormous cost to the community of organised crime, not only the financial cost but also the social cost, which is really immeasurable. It is clear that we have therefore a responsibility to take all reasonable steps to combat organised crime.

As I indicated at the commencement of my remarks, I believe that finally debate on the subject is becoming narrowed. I am pleased to see that is occurring. To date one major aspect has been whether simply an updating of the current enforcement agencies would be sufficient. It has been argued that an updating of equipment and perhaps personnel might combat organised crime. Fortunately, that argument now appears to be something of the past. We must now feel that it is insufficient and that it is insufficient for two reasons. The first is the diffuse nature of law enforcement in Australia. It is divided into six States and a Territory and we have the Australian Federal Police Force. It is not only divided geographically but divided by separate legal codes. It is divided in the form of numerous other law enforcement bodies, such as the Australian Customs Service, the Australian Taxation Office and the Corporate Affairs Division, to mention a few. The diffuse nature of law enforcement clearly facilitates the criminal in avoiding apprehension. That has come through in the numerous reports we have had before the Senate.

The second reason why orthodox law enforcement methods have proven unsuccessful is that those methods, the traditional methods, are basically complaint, investigation, arrest, trial and conviction. They may well work for the operatives who are involved, identified and convicted, but as has been clearly shown they do not represent a methodology by which the leaders, the entrepreneurs, the professionals, the bankers, the computer experts-those who are using the sophisticated techniques that Costigan and I have mentioned-can be apprehended and convicted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why weren't there more prosecutions as a result of the Costigan inquiry?

—I will mention that. That is an area of concern. I accept that. We must now accept that apprehension and conviction of the Mr Bigs of organised crime, which is our real aim, requires a new form of investigation. I believe it requires the use of an inquisitorial system and powers to compel answering of questions. In many ways I regret having to say that, but I think we have now got to the stage where we accept the necessity. It needs an interdisciplinary team of experts to analyse the information. It is a lesson that we have learnt from Costigan. It may need the eventual involvement of prosecuting counsel in the development of a case. I still think there are good arguments for that, although I note that it is not the direction being taken by this Government, as it was not the direction taken by the previous Government. The lessons learnt, the benefits, have become apparent from our experiences with royal commissions although, as Senator Crichton-Browne interjected, it is disquieting that special prosecutors are finding the evidence of the Costigan Commission so often inadequate for prosecution. I believe that is a serious matter that requires further analysis.

SPEECH.PARA: Accepting the need for this new method, the next series of questions relates to implementation-whether the implementation should be by investigations by ad hoc royal commissions or whether a new standing crimes commission with similar powers is the most desirable course. Again, there appears to have been a further narrowing of the debate. Most now reject the concept of royal commissions, because they tend to be ad hoc. What is needed is the ability to build up a continuing expertise. I also acknowledge concerns about the powers of royal commissions in relation to civil liberties. Royal commissions have traditionally been investigations of a different nature and perhaps it is more legitimate that their powers in relation to the compulsory answering of questions be a little wider.

Therefore, Mr President, it is generally accepted now that there should be a crimes commission or crimes authority. The debate now is largely on its jurisdiction, powers, authority and questions relating to its answerability and matters of that nature. I think even in that regard certain things can now be agreed to. Firstly, we must be able to look at organised crime from a national viewpoint. We must be able to overcome the geographical difficulties that I mentioned earlier. Secondly, we must have or have access to a computer-based data management system to analyse effectively the mountain of information that is necessary. Thirdly, we must have the full co-operation-I repeat, the full co- operation-of the States because so much criminal law in this country remains under State jurisdiction. Fourthly, we need a form of inquisitional power but we must always be wary of the reasonable protection of basic civil liberties. Somehow or other we must overcome the wall of silence which I think any who have studied our failure really to combat organised crime will appreciate is the most basic factor of that failure.

For a while last year I thought we would have a joint standing Commonwealth- States crimes commission which would meet those objections. The idea collapsed, and some would say that that was inevitable. Some argued that it would not work. I remember last year in debate on the previous Government's Bill accepting that the States do not have a good record of co-operation and co-ordination in the areas of organised crime. However there have been, and I accepted them, arguments to the contrary. Those who supported such a commission have been able to point in the last couple of years to considerable improvements. The Australian Police Ministers Council achieved the development of a number of national co-operative initiatives. In the criminal intelligence area it set up the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence to facilitate the collection, collation, analysis and dissemination of criminal intelligence. That body has been going for only a short time.

TALK.START.PARA: —That has not been robustly successful, has it?

—Well, I do not know whether it has really had a fair opportuninity to be put to the test. I think there are arguments that it could be much better utilised than it has been in the past and also, bearing in mind that combating organised crime requires the building collating and sifting of a mass of information, that is something that simply cannot be achieved overnight. I do wonder whether the condemnation-I regret we heard this morning-of that body at the moment is quite fair. The Police Ministers Council has also been able to point to other joint initiatives such as the National Police Research Unit, the National Institute of Forensic Science and the upgrading and relocation of the Australian Police College. Therefore I think there was some merit in the proposition to institute a joint Commonwealth-State body. But again there were reservations. Those reservations were really as to whether it would work in practice. However, the previous Government went in a different direction and supported a national crimes commission. We passed that legislation but it did not come into being. I have already the reservations I had concerning that body. Certainly it could have achieved some objectives but I had major reservations about it. That leads us to the third alternative which has come before the Senate in such a short period of time; that is, this Government's Bill to set up a National Crime Authority. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.
