SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the first readings of the Radiocommunications (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill and allied Bills I wish to raise an issue which is prominent in the news today, and has been for the past week. It involves United States installations in Australia. The Australian public has never been given a full list of all the defence, scientific and intelligence installations in Australia. They are described variously, in various documents, as being installations for space research, upper atmospheric studies units and geological and geophysical research centres. The most recent list of United States installations was made available by the then Minister for Defence in answer to a Question on Notice in the House of Representatives Hansard of 10 October 1978. Amongst those facilities listed by Mr Killen were the naval communications station, the Harold E. Holt, at North West Cape; the Joint Defence Space Research Facility at Alice Springs, commonly known as Pine Gap; the Joint Defence Space Communications Station at Woomera, commonly known as Nurrungar; the Joint Geological and Geophysical Research Station at Alice Springs, commonly known as United States Air Force Detachment 421; Tranet Station 112 at Smithfield in South Australia; and the portable geodetic satellite observation posts, then operating at Perth and Townsville.

SPEECH.PARA: The debate in relation to US installations has been going for quite some time, and I think basically it boils down to four main propositions. First of all, we have the implications for global strategic balance. The issue here is between those who argue that the facilities reduce the possibility of nuclear war by monitoring the enemy and those who argue that the possibility of nuclear war is increased by allowing the United States to plan a strategic posture so that it may engage the Soviet Union in a nuclear war rather than simply deter the Soviet Union from starting such a war. The second main area, and it is one which has had some prominence in the media, is that which involves Australia as a nuclear target. There is widespread acceptance, I think-we have had some evidence of it recently-that the United States facilities in Australia are likely to include this country in a nuclear war. Others argue, of course, that the effects of nuclear war would be limited because of the isolation of most of the installations and, to use the phrase of the current Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden), Australia accepts the risks involved in supporting United States installations in Australia. The third area of debate involves the implications of a more independent defence and foreign policy. These facilities were installed in the 1950s and 1960s and ever since that time many people have argued that they have had a counter-effect on Australia's ability to defend herself and to take an independent defence posture in the world.

The last element within the debate revolved around the notion of sovereignty, that sovereignty is an important issue to any nation, and that the United States installations in Australia have most certainly infringed Australia's sovereignty . For example, the high frequency transmitters at North West Cape were used to service the American mining of Haiphong Harbour during the Vietnam War and other North Vietnamese harbours in 1972. In material which became available at the Australian Labor Party Federal Conference in July 1973, there were assertions that satellites controlled through Australian ground stations had been used to pinpoint targets for American bombing in Cambodia. The present Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Bill Hayden, said in April 1981 that the Labor Party would seek to negotiate the North West Cape agreement to provide, first, that Australia's consent was mandatory for all orders to initiate military action which flowed from the stations and, second, that the Labor Party be given firm and convincing assurances that stations would not be used to send orders for first strike nuclear attack nor to initiate a limited strike.

Such a proposition, of course, relies essentially on access. If one looks at the access that is currently available, I think we can see that that type of assurance given by the Foreign Minister has not been carried out by the current Government. Let us consider the Australian officials who are located at the United States installations. For example, at North West Cape there is a deputy commander who is an Australian naval officer, 50 other Royal Australian Navy personnel, and some 200 Australian civilians. There is a similar number at Pine Gap and Nurrungar. However, there are extremely important limitations to the access the Australians have. For example, at North West Cape, Australians are excluded from the United States national communications room, which of course constrains Australia's ability to ensure that that communications room is not used for a first strike nuclear attack. There is no way that Australia would know or could know whether such a message was being relayed through that communications room. No Australians are admitted to the national United States site and communications room at Pine Gap or Nurrungar. More importantly, they are excluded from one of the most vital sections of the control and computer building at Pine Gap. That is run by the signals analysis section of the Special Air Service and is staffed by the Central Intelligence Agency and NSA analysts. I believe it is imperative that Australian personnel be present in these sections to ensure that all material of interest to Australia is passed on. While there remains a section which is inaccessible to Australia there can be absolutely no confidence that domestic Australian transmissions are not being intercepted and routed through this section. Undoubtedly, as evidence has become available, the facilities are being used for internal communications surveillance against Australian citizens by a so-called friendly power.

We need access not only in Australia but also in Washington. No Australians in Washington are specifically monitoring United States strategic policies, budgetary proposals or decision making which may affect Australia's interest through the United States installations. In May 1978 the controversy over the installation of a new satellite ground station at North West Cape resulted from the Australian Government admitting that it knew nothing about it. In 1981 consideration was given to posting a defence officer to the Embassy in Washington to monitor decisions. Again, that came up as part of the talks between Prime Minister Hawke and President Reagan in June this year and in discussions with the Minister for Defence, Mr Gordon Scholes, and the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Both of the proposals were turned down by the United States .

The crucial point in this whole operation is that the Australian public knows far less than the American public about foreign bases on our soil. I believe that is incompatible with a democratic country and with a free nation's sovereignty. The target of any secrecy ought not to be the Australian people but our security. Yet time and again one finds, on leafing through material available to various United States congressional committees, that material is delivered to United States congressmen that we cannot get, even by way of questions, from this Government or the previous Government. I believe that is treating this nation and this Parliament in a fashion which makes us a mockery in the rest of the world. On the installation of the AN75C54 satellite ground terminal in 1976 there was no acknowledgement to Australia. There was no communication with Australia on the Pentagon's plan to replace the AWMSC61 ground terminal. There was no communication with Australia on the use of the NSA satellite tracking communications facilities for defence communication purposes.

The ALP platform declares that Labor will make known to the Australian public the general purposes of bases and any changes to them. We have heard absolutely nothing from this Government. Obviously, from the statements of the Foreign Minister, it has no intention of keeping that promise on such a sensitive issue. There have been resolutions of Federal conferences of the Labor Party. They have been treated in the same way as the uranium policy has been treated, that is, with total disregard, by this Cabinet and this Government. Essentially, the Australian public has no idea what those bases are used for. I ask a very simple question: How is the Australian public to make up its mind whether it wishes to accept the risk involved with establishment of those bases on our soil if it has no idea what they are doing here? It is an absolute mockery when the Foreign Minister makes that absurd statement, as he did, standing on a nuclear armed and nuclear powered warship in Brisbane Harbour. The Government will not admit that the ship is nuclear armed but everybody knows that it is if they know anything about the distribution of nuclear arms in terms of the American arsensl. The information is available.

One has only to go through the various conferences which have been held in America. There is various material which is unavailable in Australia even by way of questions on notice in this Parliament. I have available to me a document published by the Hoover Institute of War, Revolution and Peace in August of this year which contains volumes of material that is not available to parliamentarians in this country. I believe that at the moment we have an attempt on the part of some people in this country, who are currently at Pine Gap, to bring to the attention of the Australian public the fact that those bases on our soil undoubtedly make us a nuclear target. The Russian equivalent to the American strategic adviser to the President has already declared quite publicly that those various facilities in Australia are targeted. Undoubtedly they are. The information is available. It is not a matter of guesswork. It is a matter of military operations in an all out nuclear attack. If we have the eyes, they will necessarily be picked off. The installations are not just located in remote areas. Two other installations have important considerations apart from the one of fallout. There are immediate considerations for two population centres in Australia-Darwin and Perth. If those installations were attacked by nuclear weapons there would be an enormous loss of life to Australia.

I hope at another stage to put on the record a fair amount of material I have received from America which is not currently available in Australia. The material is available to American congressmen but will not be made available by the Australian Government to Australian parliamentarians. The central point I wish to raise today in the short time that is available to me is the fact that the Australian public and the Australian Parliament are being treated with contempt by this Government, as they were by the previous Government. We are hosting installations which make us a target. We have no effective control over whether the installations are used for offensive purposes. We have no effective control over whether they will draw us into another world war.

I speak two days after what I believe, if we have a history, could very well go down as the beginning of the third world war, and that is the deployment of the first Cruise missile in Europe. The world seems to be on an inevitable slide into mass destruction. Yet, the ability of anyone to stop it seems to be mixed up with all sorts of other discussions about whether or not there is a buck in it for them. When we are talking about the ultimate existence of the human race people want to talk about dollars. I believe we are on that track. The Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists has now moved the clock closer to midnight than at any time in history as a result of the action two days ago of placing Cruise missiles in Britain. Yet, we in this chamber continue to discuss trivial matters . It seems to me that our priorities are all wrong if we are concerned about this nation and the world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise an issue concerning the desirability of retaining the present system of boards of review to review a decision of the Commissioner of Taxation on a taxation objection. On 6 June 1983 the Chairman of the Administrative Review Council forwarded to the Attorney- General (Senator Gareth Evans) report No. 17 by the Council entitled 'Review of taxation decisions by boards of review'. The report lists six recommendations which support the thrust of the proposition that the existing jurisdiction of the boards of review decisions made under taxation legislation should be vested in the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. It is acknowledged that there was some support for such a review by the Victorian Bar Council and some accounting bodies. However, I believe such support must also be viewed against a background of barristers hoping to open up a new and lucrative field of business at a time when there are a lot of hungry barristers and solicitors around.

SPEECH.PARA: When an assessment is received and a taxpayer is dissatisfied with that assessment, that taxpayer must notify and lodge his objection within 60 days. Section 185 of the Income Tax Assessment Act provides that the taxpayer who is dissatisfied with any assessment may lodge an objection against it and set out the requirement for valid objection. Under section 186 the Commissioner must consider that objection and may disallow it or allow it either wholly or in part and shall serve the taxpayer by post or otherwise with written notice of his decision. Section 187 provides that the taxpayer who is still dissatisfied with the decision may, within 60 days of such service, in writing request the Commissioner either to refer that decision to a board of review or, alternatively, to treat the objection as an appeal and to forward it to a specified Supreme Court. Under section 188, the request must be accompanied by a fee of $2 and the Commissioner must refer the decision or forward the objection to a board or Supreme Court in accordance with that request. If either the Commissioner or the taxpayer is dissatisfied with the decision of the board of review in relation to questions of law he can appeal to a Supreme Court. Later, on further appeal by leave he can go to the Federal Court. The next step is by a special appeal by leave to the High Court. An alternative is to go directly to a Supreme Court rather than to a board of review. The taxpayer or the Commissioner can appeal further to the Federal Court and it need then appeal by special leave to the High Court.

The advantage, of course, of the board of review system is that it is essentially simple, it is understood by a broad category of taxpayers, it is cheap and generally in my State reasonably expeditious. It has the advantage that board hearings are in camera; but not if the recommendations of the Council were followed through the AAT; information relative to taxpayers' affairs could be made public. The history of boards of review is a long one. The first board was set up in Sydney in 1925. In 1947 the number was increased to two with a second board being established in Melbourne. A third board, with its headquarters in Brisbane, was set up in 1950. The boards operate through a chairman and two members who are drawn from ex-departmental officers with experience in taxation, many of the legal profession and the commercial sphere. The chairman has a deliberative but not casting vote and the quorum is two. The chairmen and members are generally appointed for seven years and they may be reappointed. Their function is to hear and determine cases referred by the Australian Taxation Office at the request of the taxpayer. Apart from the exception listed in section 226 of the Income Tax Assessment Act the boards have all the powers of the Commissioner of Taxation in making assessments, determinations and decisions under the Act. So the decisions of boards have the same force as decisions of the Commisisoner.

One of the special features of boards of review is that membership must include people with commercial training outside the official life of Commonwealth departments. Unlike an Administrative Appeals Tribunal, board hearings are not so legalistic. Therefore, boards of review tend to be very much less expensive to taxpayers. I mentioned that boards of review were first established in 1925. The Administrative Appeals Tribunal, which was established in the last seven years, has fairly limited experience. The Tribunal is legalistic and it must be headed up by a judge of the Federal Court. The arguments that are put forward in the report of the Administrative Review Council supporting change are fairly shallow. I believe one example set out in the report is quite fallacious. The Council cites a matter drawn from the editorial of the Australian Taxation Review 1980 No. 9. The editorial states:
. . . it does not appear to be going too far to say that there is an apprehension that taxpayers appear prima facie to be treated as untruthful and as persons whose evidence should not be accepted.

Why should that statement have any more relevance to a board of review than to an Administrative Appeals Tribunal? In fact, I think the statement is not only inaccurate but also absurd in the context of a criticism of current boards of review. It is not surprising that this argument was very seriously and soundly challenged by the Commissioner of Taxation.

Other matters raised in the Council's report express some concern of a need for a standardisation of approach. The council believes that the strict legalistic system could provide such a great standardisation of approach. I would like to ask the Attorney-General: How many serious inconsistencies have there been, over the years, in relation to the decisions of the boards of review? After all there are only three boards with three men on each. So there are nine people altogether who are now hopelessly overworked. The report believes there is a need for consistency. How many cases around Australia involving major matters which were decided by boards of review have shown inconsistencies? The board members are specialists in their field, unlike the legal people who serve on the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, the decisions of which have to range over a wide area of administrative issues. The members of the boards are specialists in taxation. The report believes that the composition of a tribunal has a bearing on the quality of the review that it affords. I believe that this statement is an insult to the current and past members of the boards of review. It smacks at their credibility and the professionalism of their judgments.

I have raised questions in the Senate about the backlog of delays in the number of cases which are awaiting hearing. If one looks at the figures these delays are associated principally with Board No. 1 and Board No. 2 which have headquarters in Sydney and Melbourne respectively. The answer to this problem is to provide for more boards. I mentioned earlier that the last board, Board No. 3 , was established in 1950. The number of returns and assessments has increased. The complexity of the Act has grown. So naturally, more disputes have arisen. The simple answer is to appoint a couple more boards in Melbourne and Sydney to assist the present boards. They are very economical to operate compared with replacing them with an Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

If one looks at the composition of the backlog of cases, a lot of those awaiting hearing are very technical. For example, one could have the case of a school teacher in Victoria who has a problem in claiming a deduction for home office expenses which he believes are necessary as part of his work in the pursuit of his profession as a teacher. This issue is taken up by, say, the Australian Teachers Federation. The Federation, through its journal, may advise all teachers to lodge similar claims. So when one analyses the situation, the backlog variety is not as great as it appears. There is virtually no backlog in Hobart and none in Adelaide and it is very limited in Perth. Most Perth cases are associated with bottom of the harbour schemes, the majority of which will not even be heard because they will be withdrawn before hearing.

Although the Institute of Chartered Accountants in Australia expressed views that the taxation boards of review were not working in the way in which they were originally intended, it did say that this was disappointing and there was need for reform. But I found it disappointing that both the Institute of Chartered Accountants and the Australian Society of Accountants did come out with some sort of a preference in favour of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal approach. It is acknowledged that there is a need for reform of the decisions of the boards of review. This can be easily achieved. It can be economically achieved. I appeal to the Government not to adopt the recommendations of the report of the Administrative Review Council. As I say, we need to reform the taxation boards of review and we should not scrap them.

I believe that if we accept the recommendations we will essentially take away small taxpayer's rights. The big boys may like things to be legalistic, et cetera; for them money is not always a problem. But I am speaking from the point of view of the ordinary Australian who has a minor claim, for example a small businessman. He does not want to be faced with a legalistic sort of system. I believe it is important that these hearings be held in secret. There is a need for reform of the system. As I am running short of time I appeal to honourable senators to read the 5 November edition of The Taxpayer in which the editor says :

Do not hastily dump what is basically a sound system; rather the boards of review should be retained, because no evidence has been produced to say that an administrative appeals tribunal would be any more effective.
Debate interrupted.
Sitting suspended from 1.16 to 2 p.m.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, Senator Ryan, will be absent from the chamber this afternoon. Any questions which would normally be directed to her should be directed to me.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Social Security. I refer to the question I asked the Minister yesterday regarding the timing of the introduction of the assets test legislation and his reply that it would be introduced before the end of this session. Has the Minister seen newspaper reports today that state that the assets test package will be put to Cabinet next week and to Caucus on 29 November and that legislation will be introduced in the first week of December? In the light of these numerous reports, can the Minister confirm that this timetable is correct? If so, why was he not able to inform the Senate of this yesterday? Will the Minister now make a clear statement of the Government's intentions? Finally, with regard to that part of my question yesterday relating to the possible holding over of the legislation until the autumn session next year, will the Minister clarify whether we should be listening to him or the Treasurer, who has indicated to pensioner organisations that he is not opposed to such a course of action?

—I have nothing to add to what I said yesterday. What I said quite clearly to Senator Messner yesterday and in a previous answer was that Cabinet and the processes of the Caucus had been considering the detail of the assets legislation as a result of consultations that I and others had had and that I expected the legislation to be introduced into this Parliament before the end of this session. There is no document, no plan or anything as far as I know which states that that legislation will be introduced on a specific date or in a specific week as Senator Messner suggests, although I certainly hope it comes in as soon as possible. In relation to Senator Messner's remarks about Mr Keating, on my return from Adelaide this afternoon Mr Keating spoke to me and assured me that he did not say to pensioner organisations that he expected the legislation to be held over until next year. He said that that was a newspaper report which was not true. I accept Mr Keating's word for that.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President, in light of the fact that no Government senator has risen to ask a question. I ask the Minister: By the use of the word 'introduced' in answer to my question, did he mean that the matter would not be debated before the end of the session?
—I am sorry; if Senator Messner wishes to be pedantic, let me say that it is my intention and the Government's intention at the moment that that measure be introduced and debated.
—And passed?
—And passed, I hope. Whether it is passed depends on a vote in this place.
—It is not entirely within your control?
—No, as Senator Walsh said, it is not entirely within my control.

—Can the Minister representing the Minister for Territories and Local Government report on what action the Government is taking to promote constitutional recognition of local government in line with the Australian Labor Party platform and its electoral commitment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Labor Government is committed, not only in spirit but also in its policy, to improving the status and the recognition of local government as one of the arms of government in Australia. We are committed to the development of local government as a genuine partner in the overall system of government in Australia. To that extent we are seeking to gain constitutional recognition, at both the Federal and State levels, for the role of local government in a more precise form than currently exists. This undertaking by the Government is based on a recognition that if the upgrading of local government is to take place it should be built into the Australian government system so that it will survive changes at both the Commonwealth and State government levels. One of the difficulties that we face is the large number of local government bodies operating in Australia. There is a reluctance on the part of local governments to be amalgamated into more effective and larger instrumentalities so that they can play a more meaningful role in the overall system of government. Of course, local governments are currently an adjunct and a subsidiary of State governments.

ANSWER.PARA: If there is to be an upgrading of local government, as the Labor Government believes there should be, there have to be some changes in the present structure . The first step in this process of constitutional recognition, from the Government point of view, was the formation of a sub-committee of the Australian Constitutional Convention held in Adelaide in April this year, which was to examine the whole issue of local government. I understand that the sub-committee has recommended that this purpose would be best served by appending a charter to the Constitution rather than by amending the Constitution to provide for a more substantive role for local government. It is felt that this charter would more fully and accurately reflect the historical evolution of local government in Australia and would more readily gain the support of State governments than would an amendment to the Constitution. I understand that this approach has the support of the Australian Council of Local Government Associations. We hope that in the course of the next two or three years substantial progress will be made in this direction.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. It follows one asked by Senator Hamer on Tuesday, part of which was ignored by Senator Button in his response. I refer to the special State conference of the Victorian Labor Party to be held on the 27th of this month to discuss the Caucus decision on uranium policy. If, as generally expected, that conference censures the Government and declares that the Caucus decision is not binding on the Party, can the Leader of the Government tell the Senate what effect such a resolution would have on the Government's 10-day-old uranium policy?

—I certainly did not willingly ignore any part of Senator Hamer's question. If the special State conference in Victoria censured members of this Parliament, that would be uncomfortable for members of this Parliament. It would have no effect whatsoever on the Government's uranium policy.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. There were two parts to that question. If, in fact, there is a declaration of policy on the part of the Victorian Branch of the Australian Labor Party which is inconsistent with the policy which was adopted by the Caucus on behalf of the Government 10 days ago, will that have any effect on the decision taken by the Government in the Caucus 10 days ago?
—No.

—I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate a question about the provision of additional National Parks and Wildlife Service rangers for South West Tasmania. Has the Minister seen the report in yesterday's Mercury in which the State Minister for National Parks and Recreational Lands, Mr Pearsall, is quoted as saying in the State Parliament the previous night that the State would not accept the suggestion that Mr Hawke had written to the State suggesting that the cost of the protection of South West Tasmania should be shared by both governments? Has the Tasmanian Government officially rejected the suggestion contained in that letter from the Prime Minister that it should contribute to the cost of protection of the South West Tasmanian World Heritage area during the coming summer?
—You have taken it over. Why should we pay for it?

—Was the original proposal that 12 rangers be employed? Does the State, however, now intend to employ fewer rangers than that and for only four months, using the $500,000 given to the State by this Federal Government? Is the State Government siphoning off some of that $500,000 to the Hydro-Electric Commission, the police, forestry and the fire service? Would it really take $1m or $1.5m, as variously claimed by Mr Pearsall, to put 12 rangers in the field, or does the State's costing include all sorts of capital works which should not be decided upon before full consultation about the management of the South West? Finally, if the State is going to take this attitude, should not the Commonwealth consider taking full responsibility--
—It is not our attitude; it is yours.

—Should not the Commonwealth consider taking full responsibility for managing the South West, that is decisions as well as funding, and put an end once and for all to the State Government's continual disputation with the Commonwealth about this area?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am indebted to Senator Coates for his question. I was not able to hear it all because the answers were already being supplied from the other side as he read his question sentence by sentence and paragraph by paragraph.
—You really did not understand the question.

—I am told by Senator Walters that I would not understand the question anyway. Senator Walters, I might add, comes from Tasmania. If she would do me the favour of listening to what I have to say she might understand the answer even if she disagrees with it. I am not able to answer that part of Senator Coates's question which deals with the precise number of rangers who might be employed, which suggests that the Tasmanian Government is siphoning off money for purposes other than those originally intended, and so on. In respect of that part of the question I will obtain an answer for Senator Coates as soon as possible, and no doubt Senator Walters will supply him with a different one as well.

ANSWER.PARA: Insofar as the question relates to the amount of money to be paid by the Commonwealth to Tasmania in respect of the protection of the South West National Park, there has been an exchange of correspondence between the Prime Minister and the Premier. On 3 November the Prime Minister wrote offering immediate assistance of $500,000 as a contribution to the costs of the summer program, including the cost of employing additional rangers and appropriate support staff . On 16 November, I point out to Senator Coates and Senator Walters, the Premier wrote to the Prime Minister acknowledging receipt of the $500,000 and outlining proposals for its expenditure on rangers, support service, the purchase of equipment and fire surveillance. These proposals by the Premier of Tasmania are now being assessed by the two governments in consultation. In the official correspondence which has taken place there has been no suggestion from the Premier of Tasmania of the kind which emanated from Mr Pearsall yesterday. The only suggestion of that kind has come from a Press report and, of course, the ubiquitous Senator Walters. As to whether the Commonwealth Government should take full responsibility for the management of the South West National Park, I am sure that this Government and the Tasmanian Government will be able to reach a satisfactory accommodation on the matters addressed in Senator Coates's question. I believe that that accommodation will take place. If it does not and the more stroppy element in Tasmania prevails, the suggestion, which again has emanated from Senator Walters, even by interjection today, that the Commonwealth take it all over, would have much greater appeal to us.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SALE OF AUSTRALIAN URANIUM TO FRANCE

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Trade to a French Press report quoting the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, as saying that he has not suggested the abrogation of signed contracts for the sale of Australian uranium to France. He is quoted as saying: 'We shall deliver 250 tonnes of uranium to France late in 1984'. I refer also to Australian Press reports that the French Government will continue its despicable nuclear testing program in the Pacific. I ask: Is the report of the Prime Minister's statement correct? Was this known by the French Foreign Minister yesterday when he told the National Press Club that France expects to continue to receive Australian uranium shipments? Is such a statement contrary to Australian Labor Party policy that there will be no further uranium exports to France while French nuclear testing continues in the Pacific?

—The last sentence that Senator Chipp put to me referred to Labor Party policy. The Labor Party policy, already announced, is that there will be no shipments of uranium to France, at least before October 1984, and that no new mines other than Roxby Downs, subject to its commercial viability, will be permitted to proceed.
—Not Ben Lomond?

—No, no new mines other than Roxby Downs, subject to its commercial viability. If one wants to be highly technical about it, the only way the Commonwealth could stop a mine opening would be to invoke the draconian provisions of the Atomic Energy Act, but I expect that Commonwealth policy would be enforced through export licences rather than the Atomic Energy Act. However, I am not certain of what the Prime Minister is reported to have said, or the accuracy with which he was reported, and I can only refer that part of the question to the Prime Minister for his confirmation or otherwise. As Senator Chipp said, the original report seems to have come from a French magazine. I do not know the date of the interview. Equally, I am not able to say whether the French Foreign Minister was aware of that alleged statement having been reported in the French Press. I will just have to refer the substance of Senator Chipp's question to the Prime Minister.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation aware of the deep concern that is growing at the Government's proposal to withdraw rescue and fire fighting crews from Archerfield and Bundaberg airports in Queensland, transferring the responsibility to civil fire brigades which are not specifically designed to cope with aviation emergencies and which are often located too far from airports to be effective? I also ask the Minister whether he will undertake to review this decision which appears to threaten fundamental civil aviation safety procedures at two of Queensland's busiest secondary airports?

—Proposals were put to the Government by the General Aviation Association which claimed to act on behalf of the aviation industry. It suggested that there should be some downgrading of rescue and fire services at a number of secondary airports, including Archerfield and Bundaberg. The Government is currently examining this issue without in any way giving a commitment to what has been suggested. Those proposals include the proposition that the local fire services should take over responsibility in the event of any emergency. But, as the questioner has suggested, and certainly the evidence is there, it is not always possible for local emergency services to replace the current services. However, the Government has undertaken to have discussions with the staff at the affected airfields and with the unions which cover them, as well as with the local communities. No decision will be made until such time as those discussions have been held. I think I can give an assurance that the Government recognises that Australia has a very high safety record, and it would not want to jeopardise that record in any changes that might be contemplated. I undertake to pass on to the Minister for Aviation, whom I represent in this place, the honourable senator's concern that, before any review is completed, the safety aspects be seriously considered.

—I address my question to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Is the Minister aware of the concern of relatives of patients in the Bundoora Repatriation Hospital in Bundoora, Victoria, that a number of wards will be closed for varying periods? I ask: Why are the wards to be closed? Further, can the Minister give an assurance of continuing care for patients at this hospital?

—There have been some difficulties in that hospital. The Government is undertaking a review with the purpose of ensuring that those difficulties will be overcome. I can give the Senate an assurance that patients will in no way be affected by the difficulties that we have been facing.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. Has the Minister seen the report in today's Australian Financial Review headlined ' ''Get ready now'' warning on next round of oil shortages'? If he has , did he note that it reported Mr Ian D. Whiteley, the President of the Petroleum Exploration Society of Australia, as predicting that oil 'shortages could occur as early as 1985-86, prompting a sharp increase in what had been stable oil prices'? He was further quoted as referring to 'a sharp shock of price increases by the middle of 1986, coupled with a renewed international recession'. Does the Government agree with Mr Whiteley's forecast? What does the Government see as the future scenario for the supply and pricing of oil and the impact any changes will have on economic recovery and growth?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the Press reports to which Senator Crowley refers. Again, there is the doubt that one cannot be certain of the accuracy with which Mr Whiteley was reported. Assuming that he was reported accurately, there are a number of unlikely scenarios in his statement. Before moving on to that, however , let me say that the Government has already made a decision, based on the present surplus capacity of Australia's oil-producing potential and the Government's belief that that surplus capacity will continue for some years into the future, to allow the small amount of oil which is currently available, because it is surplus to the domestic demand, to be exported. Nothing could be more devastating to oil exploration and activity than the lack of a market. The Government has taken a very important move in that direction.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Whiteley is reported to have said that prices could take off in 1985-86. That is not compatible with the information which has been supplied to the Government, although I suppose, since it is two years hence, it could be possible. Indeed, the possibility of severe disruption to supplies in a major producing country, caused ultimately by political instability, could at any time conceivably substantially increase world prices. That, in itself, should it happen and should those higher prices be maintained in combination with the Government's import parity-related price, would be an incentive for oil exploration. In short, it is not the Government's expectation that there would be a major increase in prices at that stage although, in the long term, I think anybody who has seriously addressed this question expects that the real price of oil will go up.

Even more puzzling-I add again the qualification that one cannot be certain whether Mr Whiteley was reported accurately-is that Mr Whiteley was reported as predicting that there would be an association between an economic recession and rising oil prices. Other things being equal, that is so unlikely as to be almost impossible. If there is a recession and, therefore, a decline in demand for oil, prices could be expected to go down and not up. Finally, it is likely-I stress the word 'likely' because it is too early at this stage to make definitive forecasts-that the recent Jabiru discovery off the north-west Kimberley coast even at this stage has clearly added significantly to Australia's known reserves . That area has the potential to add a good deal more to Australia's known oil reserves and has substantially changed the likely availability of oil into the later part of this decade.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. Has the Minister noted newspaper reports that there was a sharp decline in the number of arrivals in Australia during the June quarter, namely by 40,000, and that the number of permanent settlers also fell sharply? Can the Minister provide the Senate with exact figures on, firstly, how many permanent settlers arrived in Australia; secondly, which countries they came from; thirdly, how many belong to the family reunion category; and, fourthly, how many came as refugees?
—Senator Lajovic has asked me a question of great detail the answer to which I do not have. I will refer that to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and get an answer as soon as possible.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. I ask the Minister whether he has seen the article in today's Australian Financial Review headlined 'Strikes at 12-year low', which reports the latest August figures on working days lost through industrial disputes as the 'lowest August result since monthly surveys began in 1970'. Has the Minister also seen the paid advertisement in the same newspaper setting out Sir Ian McLennan's Chairman's address to the Elders IXL Ltd annual general meeting in which he called for the dismantling of the centralised wage fixing system? If the Minister has seen these items, can he say how Sir Ian's theories square with the reality of our industrial relations performance? Do Sir Ian's remarks represent a militant attack upon the consensus of the National Economic Summit Conference communique?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —'Militant' is the last word I would apply to Sir Ian McLennan in respect of anything he does. Of course, there are differences of view about the Government's wage fixation policy which are demonstrated in the Senate and by other spokesmen outside. Both business and other organisations have made conflicting comments about the approach adopted by the Government in pursuit of a centralised wage fixation system. I turn to the first part of Senator Cook's question. I have not seen the Australian Financial Review article this morning, pointing to strikes being at a 12-year low, but I am familiar with the figures upon which that article is based. That is true. As I have said in the Senate before, one of the encouraging things about it is that those figures cover a period in which employment has been rising. It has always been an eminently respectable view that increasing unemployment militates against industrial disputation, just as a whole range of industrial relations policies affect the level of industrial disputation. I think the figures in the Australian Financial Review are important because they provide a tangible recognition of this Government's approach to industrial relations as distinct from the confrontationist approach of the previous Government.
—But the strikes went down during the Fraser Government.
—No, they did not.
—You are being dishonest.
—How many man-days were lost in 1974?
—A number of allegations are being made. I simply make the point that the Opposition cites a figure from 1974 as proof of the eternal--
—Eternal truth.

—Yes, as an eternal truth about Labor governments. Of course, in 1974 there was a high level of industrial disputation. Looking at the Liberal Party's record in government, one finds a very high level of industrial disputation, influenced by one factor alone-the breaking of its election promises in relation to Medibank.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no doubt about that. It broke that promise. That year reflected a high figure in respect of industrial disputation.
—Are you talking about broken promises?

—No, I am not talking about broken promises. All I am doing is pointing out that certain facts affect industrial relations performance-certain quite extraneous facts, in some ways. So the figures which have been shown in the Australian Financial Review today are encouraging in the current economic circumstances. I agree with the implications of Senator Cook's question about that. Insofar as Sir Ian McLennan's comment about a centralised wage fixation system is concerned, he is perfectly entitled to that view. As I indicated yesterday at Question Time, the Government's view is that that is the best system for this country in present circumstances, for a variety of reasons. Although it is sometimes said that at a time of very desperate need for a continuing improvement in the level of economic activity a centralised wage system is inconsistent, I just make the point, from history, that in the period ended December 1977, when there was a period of full wage indexation, between 1974 and 1977 average weekly earnings contracted by 20 per cent, and in the same period--
—What?

—The rise in average weekly earnings contracted from 20 per cent to 9.7 per cent in that period, and at the same time, in that period from 1974 to 1977, the rate of increase in the consumer price index fell from 16.3 per cent to 9.3 per cent, at a time when there was a deliberate policy of wage indexation as a centralised wage fixing system.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I direct my question to the Minister for Social Security. I was interested in the information that the Minister gave yesterday in response to a question regarding disabled persons programs. Is the Minister now able to give an assurance to organisations that receive funding under the handicapped persons assistance program that the great diversity and range of programs under the Act will be continued in future funding? On what basis will the funding be provided?

—Yes, I can assure Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle that any future programs for handicapped persons assistance in this country while we are in government will involve funding a diversity of organisations and a diversity of programs. Although I believe, as I said yesterday-I believe most people take this view-that there needs to be a greater concentration on programs which provide assistance to those in the community, rather than those in institutions, that provide assistance to those programs which are aiming to facilitate and train disabled people to take part in as normal a lifestyle as possible and to make decisions about their own lifestyle as much as possible, there clearly will always be need in some cases for some forms of institution. What I am hoping is that as a result of the present handicapped persons programs review we shall get the views of the disabled themselves and of the organisations that care for the disabled, so that we can get a better idea of what they think, because I believe that in the past they have not been asked about that sufficiently, and get the views of the carer organisations so that we can come up in the end with a better balanced program than we have had in the past. Therefore, at this point I cannot give details to Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle about what proportion of funds may go to one area or what proportion may go to another. I can just guarantee that there will be a diversification in the program. The percentage of future funding provided by government depends on, first, the result of that review; secondly, the deliberations by the Government and the Department; and, thirdly and ultimately, decisions of the Government in Cabinet.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. In view of the important role of Commonwealth bond sales in controlling growth in the money supply, is there any information available on the value of government bond sales overseas this year and, in particular, on long term bond sales overseas?

—I remember Senator Maguire raising the same question at an Estimates committee hearing earlier this year. As he indicated, it is a very important question. I was surprised to hear from the Treasury representative who was present that the Government did not have the information on the proportion of bonds which had been purchased overseas. I have since discussed this question with people in the money market, who have pointed out to me some of the difficulties of obtaining that information. But it is very important that that information be made available, because in the extreme case, if all bond sales had been taken up by overseas buyers, the effect on the money supply of any sale of bonds would be neutral, thereby completely negating the ostensible reason for making the bond sales, which is to reduce the money supply, as Senator Maguire has indicated. But I do not know whether the Government has been able to obtain any information other than that which the Treasury had available at the time of the Estimates committee hearing, which was none. I will refer the question to the Treasurer and see what information he can provide.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. I refer to the review of the Repatriation Act which is under way. What is the current state of that review? Has the Government received from the committee conducting the review a full draft of its recommendations? Will the Government give an unequivocal guarantee that current benefits available to veterans will be maintained in any legislation which may result from the review?

—For most of 1983 a legislation review committee and an administrative review council have been looking at the Repatriation Act and the current procedures involved in the Repatriation Commission and the Department of Veterans' Affairs. I have recently received information and draft reports on both of those inquiries undertaken this year. We are preparing for detailed discussions with the ex-service organisations on Monday and Tuesday of next week . I cannot give any guarantee in respect of what will arise out of those discussions or on the Government's intentions. As to the bodies concerned, the Legislative Review Committee in particular has had representatives of the major ex-service organisations working on the legislation, which, as the honourable senator will be aware, began in 1920. So we have had 63 years of experience with that. It has not been substantially improved; it has only been added to and amended in a rather ad hoc way in the subsequent years. However, I assure the honourable senator and the Senate that it is not the Government's intention to take advantage of this review in any way to reduce the range of benefits unless there were compensatory benefits as a result of changes in the way in which the Act operates. Certainly the consultations with the ex-service organisations have been very fruitful. Very shortly the results of the review process will be made available to the organisations for them to examine them over the December- January period so that the Government can then look at the matter when Parliament resumes in February 1984.

—Is the Minister for Social Security aware that a number of organisations and associations providing care for disabled children, especially intellectually disabled children, require parents to give an undertaking to contribute regular working hours and financial assistance to those institutions in order to secure or retain placements for their disabled children? Can the Minister advise what is the Government's attitude towards this manipulation and exploitation of particularly vulnerable people?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I am aware that, as Senator Giles said, some organisations caring for disabled children require such commitments, sometimes by contract, that the parents will in fact put in so many working hours or so much money before their child will be accepted. I think it is worth while to look at the fact that intellectually and sometimes physically handicapped children in this country have been cared for in the past by institutions which have developed in the absence of public funding and alternative public institutions for such training. In the past, when we were in a different time and had different attitudes, the institutions had difficulty maintaining their building programs, et cetera. As a result, the policy that Senator Giles talked about developed-a policy whereby people were asked to sign a contract committing themselves to so many hours work, to so much fund-raising or to the payment of so much money if their children were to be accepted.

ANSWER.PARA: Probably what is even more distressing is the situation whereby, if parents did not or do not fulfil such a contract, their child would be removed from the institution. I believe that that latter situation is, in fact, even more distressing than the first. We have to realise that times have changed. Firstly, all such institutions invariably receive considerable amounts of public moneys, either from government and/or from public subscriptions through the various fund raising efforts of those organisations. Secondly, in some cases, the organisations, because of the way they have developed, have more or less a monopoly on the treatment of certain disabilities-sometimes intellectual, sometimes physical, sometimes both. Thirdly, times have changed to the extent that in this day and age most people in this country believe that the most important thing is the intellectually or physically handicapped child and the fact that that child needs treatment and the sort of program to assist the child to develop regardless of the attitude of his or her parents or the capacity of the parents to contribute in the way Senator Giles has described.

The Government and I are opposed to organisations which coerce parents into working hour commitments, financial commitments or any other commitments, regardless of their financial capacity, their physical capacity or their emotional capacity to contribute in that way. In fact, most parents of children in this situation will willingly, to the fullest of their capacity, contribute as much as possible to the institutions. Therefore, I request any organisation which has such a rigid structure and approach to the care of such children to reconsider its situation, to consider these facts: It receives considerable amounts of public funds; community attitudes have changed; and it is unfair to refuse a child treatment or admission to a program or to remove a child from a program under which it is already receiving treatment or instruction because of some difficulty that the parents have. I believe that if that situation continues in existing organisations, or if new organisations are developed which set up programs in that way, it is the duty of the Government to consider how much it should fund those organisations in the future and whether it should not fund alternative organisations.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Has the Minister seen the advertisement calling for public submissions to an inquiry into the Alice Springs-Darwin railway and the upgrading of the Stuart Highway? I draw the attention of the Minister to this statement in the advertisement:

QUESTION.PARA: The Inquiry will not seek to evaluate the defence implications of proposals.

Could the Minister explain why the public is denied the opportunity to make submissions on an important aspect of the railway, namely its potential for moving defence forces and supplies rapidly and in considerable volume to our largely undefended north? Does the implicit reservation of this matter to the Department of Defence indicate that a belief is held by the Government that the sole font of wisdom on defence matters lies with the Department of Defence, or does it suggest that the deterrent value of such a railway is unimportant because it cannot be quantified in economic terms? Alternatively, does it indicate that the inherent defence value of such a railway ought to be kept secret when it would be plainly obvious to the intelligence services of any potential enemy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not seen the advertisement in question, but I do not have to as Senator Harradine has drawn out of it the point he wants to make in his question. I will certainly inquire as to why the defence aspects of the proposal were not included in the terms of reference of the inquiry. I do not in 1983 share the sorts of assumptions which are implicit in Senator Harradine's question about the need for a large transit system such as a railway to move defence equipment and personnel. I doubt very much that that is relevant in contemporary defence terms and in the circumstances of a potential war with some other country. I express my own opinion only when I say that I would attach doubtful weight to the importance of a railway of that kind for defence purposes in the current defence environment.

ANSWER.PARA: I am asked whether the Government regards the Defence Department as the sole font of wisdom on defence matters. I have not had a discussion with any of my colleagues about that. All I can say is that I hope not. The one or two other aspects with defence implications in the honourable senator's question I will address to the appropriate Minister and obtain a more detailed reply if I can.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate whether he has seen the report of the statement of the Chairman of Qantas Airways Ltd, Mr Leslie, concerning the numbers of public servants and people from this Parliament using Qantas for their travel? Is the low proportion of use that has been quoted correct? If so, what does the Government intend to do about it?

—I have not seen the statement by Mr Leslie. Once again, it is quite clear from the question what the statement is about; I do not need to have seen it. I appreciate that I am getting rapidly into the Senator Withers category, but by some magic sleight of hand, although I have not seen the advertisement in question, I am able to assist Senator Coates with an answer. The comments made by Mr Leslie which were reported in the Press this morning are subject to the following comment: Australians do rely almost totally on air travel in order to visit other countries and obviously there will be circumstances when services provided by--
—Do imports come from overseas?

—With the greatest respect, Mr President, I ought to deal with this interjection because my answer has been put in the Enderby class of 1975. I belong to a much later vintage than that. I just reiterate what I said--
—Order! Having picked up that interjection, I ask the Minister to ignore all others.

—Yes, Mr President, I will come back to the question. Australians must rely almost totally, but not exclusively, on air travel in order to visit other countries. That is all the answer means. I have travelled by ship to a number of countries. Obviously there will be occasions when services provided by one airline, such as Qantas, will not enable the traveller to meet adequately his or her commitments within the time available. The policy of successive governments of all political persuasions has been to encourage Federal politicians and public servants to use Qantas wherever possible, but it is ultimately the Australian and overseas commitments of each person involved which determine the extent to which Qantas may be used. Having said that, I will take the opportunity of getting a comment from the relevant Minister on the details of the figures quoted by Mr Leslie in his statement.

—Is the Leader of the Government in the Senate yet able to confirm that the Government has decided to declare Stage II of the Kakadu National Park in the Northern Territory and that this will be announced tomorrow , as is widely reported in the media? What is to be done about the Jabiluka uranium deposit? Is it true that the Commonwealth is trying to negotiate compensation for the Aboriginal landholders there and at Koongarra in an attempt to persuade them to withdraw from agreements to allow mining?

—I was asked a question about this earlier this week and I said that the Government would make an announcement at the appropriate time in respect of the declaration of Stage II of the Kakadu National Park. If Senator Kilgariff has some intuition that the appropriate time to which I referred is tomorrow, I am very glad to hear it.
—He just heard it on AM from Barry Cohen.

—AM is a great stimulus to Senator Kilgariff's intuition, if I might say so. If Senator Kilgariff is good enough to wait till tomorrow we will all be able to tell whether his intuition is correct. I assume that the same situation applies to the Jabiluka deposit in terms of when an announcement will be made. I think it is sufficient to say for Senator Kilgariff's purposes that in a general statement on uranium policy the Government has made it clear that it will not be opening new mines. I would have thought that even the honourable senator's intuition would have enabled him to work out what that means in relation to Jabiluka. If compensation for Aboriginal traditional landholders is a matter which the Government has to address I am sure it will do so, but it is not the sort of thing which can be done overnight.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations aware that the United States Department of Labor issued an emergency standard earlier this month to cut by 75 per cent the permissible exposure to asbestos fibres by the 375,000 workers in the manufacturing, construction and maritime industries? Will the Minister outline the measures taken by the Australian Government to regulate the use of asbestos in this country and the standards of safety that apply to exposure in the work place?

—I cannot answer that question. I know that the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, in conjunction with one or two other Ministers, has had a series of consultations about this matter and that actions have been taken in relation to specific industries involving high asbestos use. I think the question requires some detailed information indicating the extent of that activity in response to the use of asbestos in particular areas and I am not in a position to supply that. I am also aware of the United States Government's action in relation to the matter. But insofar as the question requires a detailed answer I will address it to the Minister and obtain a response as early as possible.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Since the last increase in the number of taxation boards of review was in 1950 and there has been a significant increase in the number of assessments the complexity of taxation law and the number of objections since then, will the Government give consideration to appointing additional boards of review to handle the backlog of references awaiting decision by the three three- member taxation boards of review?

—The question was: Will the Government consider increasing the number of boards of review? I expect the answer to that question would be yes, the Government will consider almost anything. But as to whether any increases are planned, that is a matter which I would have to refer to the Treasurer. No increases are planned as far as I know, but I will refer the matter to the Treasurer for his comments.

—Has the Attorney-General seen reports in the Press that certain elements of the anti-uranium movement intend to advocate a write-in in the forthcoming referendums, the write-in being 'no uranium'? Will this action, because it involves the word 'no', confuse the voters as they have to write yes or no in a particular square, and will the Minister consider some action to outlaw the inciting of electors to write over their ballot papers?
—I have seen reports that some such course of action is contemplated. It would have a grave risk of invalidating ballot papers, to the extent that there could be some confusion.
—Come on! 'No Dams' didn't.

—In an ordinary election situation, even Senator Walters will recall, ballot papers are marked with ones, twos and threes or crosses-or perhaps in her case thumb prints-but electors certainly do not write yes or no. In the context of a write-in vote of 'no uranium', there may well be confusion of the kind that Senator Ray refers to and the Government will have to give serious consideration to what measures might be taken to discourage voters from adopting that course of action. I do not think there can be any question, in the interests of free speech and all those other things we hold dear, of any more robust action than that, but it will be a matter to which the Government will pay close regard, given the possibility of confusion in what manifestly will be a very important referendum.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. It follows the answer given by Senator Button which related to the Northern Territory uranium province. Will the Minister explain to the New York Mining Club next week, when he addresses it, the way in which the Getty Oil Development Co. Ltd should treat its $50m investment, lawfully undertaken, with respect to Jabiluka? Will he recommend that it should write it off as a case of foreign expropriation?

—As Senator Chaney obviously knows, I will be speaking to the New York Mining Club next week and, yes, I will detail the reasons for the Government's uranium policy decision. As I understand the situation, with the possible and rather complicated and partial exception of the Ranger mine-that is related to the sale of the Commonwealth's one-time equity in that project-there is no legal basis for a claim for compensation from anybody.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN BROADCASTING CORPORATION: HISTORIC NEWS FILM

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. I refer to the recent disclosure that millions of feet of historic news film stored in the Australian Broadcasting's Corporation's Ripponlea studios are already rotting away due to the total inadequacy of its storage and preservation facilities. I ask the Minister: Firstly, does he agree with the description of the condition of these records and the total inadequacy of storage and preservation as described in the Age article of 2 November 1983? Secondly, does the Government agree that the matter is urgent and that failure to take immediate action would be a deplorable act of irresponsibility in relation to irreplaceable archives? Thirdly, what action is the Government now taking to save the remaining film archives and to provide suitable storage at controlled temperatures?

—On the basis of my own knowledge I certainly agree with the description given in the Age newspaper in relation to the condition of the film archives. I agree that it is a very important matter. The archives are irreplaceable and they ought to be stored in much more satisfactory and modern premises. I know that this matter has been the subject of discussion and negotiation at quite considerable length by the Minister and, I think, the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. As well, I think there has been some involvement by the Prime Minister. I believe that a response is contemplated at an early date. At present, I am not able to advise the Senate of the precise details of that, but I will endeavour to obtain a more complete answer and make it available to Senator Missen as soon as possible.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SALE OF AUSTRALIAN URANIUM TO FRANCE

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to add to an answer which I gave to Senator Chipp earlier today regarding a reported statement attributed to the Prime Minister. I have been given a transcript of the Prime Minister's Press conference, which I think was held this morning, at which this question was raised. The transcript states:

QUESTION.PARA: JOURNALIST: Prime Minister, could I ask you on a different subject-a French business daily has reported that-quoting you as saying that Australia is prepared to review uranium exports on certain conditions and you are quoted as saying-
This is purported to be a direct quote-
'we shall deliver 250 tonnes of uranium late in 1984'.
The Prime Minister replied:

Yes, it has been brought to my attention. Let me say unequivocally that that report is wrong. There is no foundation for it and to save your time I merely indicate that there is a transcript-a full transcript of that conversation that I had with the French journalist on 8th of this month and that is available in my office.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not quite sure how to handle this matter. Earlier in Question Time today Senator Walters made an excursion in my direction across the chamber.

At that time, Senator Walters asked me to obtain a clarification of an answer which had been given in relation to correspondence between the Tasmanian Premier and the Prime Minister relating to the Bass Strait ferry service. The Prime Minister indicated in his response that he had replied to a letter from the Tasmanian Premier, including his letter dated 5 August. Senator Walters was concerned to know when.
