DEBATE.TITLE: REVIEW OF CRISIS AND YOUTH ACCOMMODATION

PROCTEXT.PARA: Joint Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr Hurford), the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) and myself, I seek leave to make a statement on the matter of crisis and youth accommodation.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of honourable senators, I wish to inform them of the outcome of the review of programs in this area. In doing so, we would stress that firm Government policies in the area of crisis and youth accommodation will not be finalised until the review's recommendations have been discussed further with the States and non-government organisations. When this Government came to office in March this year homelessness was seen as a major priority for urgent attention. There were no clear cut policies or directions to remedy youth or older age homelessness, and there was no co-ordination of emergency accommodation services for women and children.

SPEECH.PARA: The major objective of the Commonwealth's involvement in crisis accommodation programs is to provide a range of services to meet the needs of the homeless, and those facing other crisis accommodation situations such as eviction or domestic violence. Arrangements need to be logical and practical to assist non- government sector involvement, to ensure needs are met in a cost effective way, and to help the co-ordination of Commonwealth and State action. We had already seen the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare report on homeless youth and there had also been an evaluation of the youth services scheme. Both these reports highlighted problems in this area and the need for action. As interim measures the Government provided a further $1.9m for a 12-month extension of the youth services scheme and in the recent Budget increased funding for the homeless persons assistance program and improved the subsidy arrangements under the program.

In addition Senator Ryan and I announced funding of $4m for this financial year to set up the women's emergency services program. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has already written to the States to initiate action for the allocation and expenditure of these funds. The first step will be to see that the money allocated is spent in accordance with our priorities and this will be done in consultation with the States, women's refuge groups and other relevant non- government organisations. It has been recognised that the difficulty with access to permanent housing is a major cause of demand for crisis accommodation, and we have increased our funding for public housing under the Commonwealth-State housing agreement by 50 per cent, to $500m in 1983-84.

Following the change of government, the Minister for Housing and Construction and I agreed to continue a review into programs in the crisis accommodation area . Because the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs has responsibility for co -ordinating all Government policies relating to youth, her Department joined the review. There had already been consultations with the States and all parties accepted the need for the review.

The review is now completed and, in summary, found that there is no logical basis for current arrangements, where some programs are administered and funded by the Commonwealth and others administered and cost shared by States. There is also no overall planning and programs are unco-ordinated and unnecessarily complex. Youth refuges, for example, are funded under two different programs. Needs are not being met due to this lack of planning, and due to restrictions on assistance able to be provided. Funding of approved projects under existing program guidelines is often inadequate; for example, wage levels in refuges are generally below award levels. Given these problems, the review recomended that, following negotiations with States and consultations with womens and youth groups, Aboriginal organisations and other non-government bodies, all Commonwealth crisis accommodation programs should be brought together under a crisis accommodation asistance Act.

The review recommended that this Act provide funding to the States and Territories, and embody a five-year Commonwealth-State agreement covering such matters as guidelines for the operation of programs including protection for youth and women's refuges, funding arrangements, including matching and a guaranteed base level of funs, and the establishment of Commonwealth-State co- ordinting committees which would also include representatives of the relevant non-government organisations. The Act as proposed by the review would incorporate three proposed programs, to be administered and cost shared by States. These programs comprise a youth supported accommodation scheme, the women's emergency services program and a general crisis accommodation program, and would cover the full range of crisis accommodation provision.

Guidelines for these programs would provide States with considerably more flexibility than currently operates. The review saw this as avoiding the present situation where individuals are in refuges because other assistance, such as medium term supported accommodation, is unable to be provided under existing program guidelines. This flexibility will enable provision to be more closely aligned to needs. The review's recommendations involve a shift in administration from the Commonwealth to the States. To enable the better identification of needs and the better co-ordination of programs, the review recommended that it would be administratively more sensible to operate from one level of government; States already operate a range of programs in this area. This could place additional pressure on the States, and accordingly such aspects as the anticipated administrative costs would be taken into account in discussing overall finding arrangements. The review recommends that any new arrangemens be in place by 1 July 1984, and negotiations commence as quickly as possible. Negotiations on these crisis accommodation arrangements will be the responsibility of my Department.

The Government is conscious of the important role of non-government organisations. Non-government organisations provide most services in this area, and we do not propose to change this. We will be seeking to consult with them at the same time as we commence negotiations with the States on ways of making sure that the most appropriate forms of services are provided. The review recommendations involve changes to existing programs. Accordingly, the review recommended that any new arrangements ensure that the position of existing projects be protected, and consultations with service providers will cover this aspect.

The Government is committed to developing, in consultation with the States, a national program for women's emergency services. Our prime concerns are to allocate moneys efficiently to areas in need of such services and to assist existing refuges with adequate funding and staffing. The review recommended that adequate and guaranteed funding for women's emergency services can best be ensured if this program constitutes a separately identifiable component of an overall crisis accommodation program. The review suggested that a five-year Commonwealth-State agreement, including guidelines for the operation of all components of the crisis accommodation program, would both eliminate funding uncertainties and guarantee adequate levels of funding for women's refuges. Accordingly, negotiations with the States will be undertaken to assess whether the review's recommendations provide an appropriate basis for developing a national program in this area. At the same time, consultations with women's refuges, which at present would prefer to be part of a purely Commonwealth program, will be undertaken to see whether they would find such new arrangements satisfactory.

As indicated, we have provided $4m for the women's emergency services program in 1983-84. We are conscious of the need to ensure that funds are allocated as soon as possible and are taking steps to ensure that the funds can begin to flow quickly. It is envisaged that, prior to further consideration of the long-term structure of this program, arrangements for the allocation of this $4m will be consistent with the overall arrangements proposed for the crisis accommodation program.

The review also considered a number of housing programs and proposed, as a basis for negotiations, that the crisis acommodation for families in distress program should be incorporated into an expanded mortgage and rent relief scheme. This would provide States with greater flexibility in the area, in response to their wishes. Negotiations on the housing programs will be carried out under the direction of the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr Hurford). The review recommended that, as part of the renegotiation of the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement, an agreed proportion of public rental stock be made available for crisis accommodation purposes, and that youth and other users of crisis accommodation such as women's refuges have improved access to public rental housing. I seek leave to table a more detailed outline of the discussion proposals, including a draft outline of program guidelines. These will be forwarded to the States prior to commencing negotiations.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Commonwealth Government recognises the crucial importance of effective crisis accommodation arrangements, including assistance for homeless youth and for women in crisis. Certainly there are issues to be resolved, but I am confident that in our negotiations with the States and non-government organisations we will be able to resolve these. The recommendations of the review provide a useful basis for Commonwealth and State governments to work together to develop coherent and effective arrangements in this area. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to welcome this statement from the Government on the problems of crisis and youth accommodation. I think the statement is particularly timely in view of the fact that for some months the Government has been undertaking a review of this matter, which flowed on from review procedures established by the previous Government. We noted the concern generally in the community earlier this year about programs for crisis accommodation and support services for youth under the youth services scheme. In July the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) announced that there was to be some temporary funding of, I believe, some $2m. Since that time we have been waiting for the Government to make some further announcement on this type of service.

SPEECH.PARA: This statement is based upon the Government's review of all programs. The review found that existing Commonwealth and State programs were generally unco- ordinated and in fact overlapped. I think that has been one of the great concerns of people interested in this area, and it was particularly drawn to the attention of the Senate and the Government by Senator Chaney when he was Minister. These problems are relatively recent. As they have grown and the Government has attempted to come to grips with them, I think there has been an evolutionary phase in the development of policies. The move to establish a crisis accommodation assistance Act and subsequent machinery is welcome, with perhaps one or two reservations. Certainly a number of good features are outlined in the explanation of the three programs to be administered under the Act. The innovation of the five-year funding basis will be welcomed by all involved in providing services. This will overcome problems raised earlier this year when funding for the youth support services scheme was coming to an end. Considerable concern and uncertainty was expressed about the future of youth centres which had been created as a result of that funding.

The Government's emphasis on flexibility is a very admirable feature. I think it is very significant that this is going to be one of the keys to the success not only of the negotiation procedures into which the Government is now entering but also the subsequent operation of the schemes under which a more satisfactory type of accommodation will be provided for people who are in this sort of need.

The Government's commitment to the continued use of State and non-government bodies in the administration and implementation of the programs is particularly welcome. It is true that State governments and those agencies have the expertise and are closer to the consumers and therefore are able to react more quickly than is possible under a centralised program administered solely by the Commonwealth. The establishment of bodies to enhance consultation between the Commonwealth, the States and non-government bodies is also to be widely welcomed . There are, however, one or two reservations in that regard. I believe that we must avoid at all costs the possible over-bureaucratisation of the program by the central control that may be exercised from Canberra. That would affect the flexibility which the Minister stated in the paper as being one of the keynotes of success in delivering the appropriate service.

Assistance in this area must go to those in need. We have to recognise that different groups have different needs. Although there may be some overlapping of problems, groups such as the youth group have distinct and separate problems. Obviously the biggest problems faced by the youth group are unemployment, lack of vocational training, as well as homelessness. Those things need to be addressed very clearly as part of the overall program with regard to homelessness. The problems of that group are quite distinct from the problems of the more traditional homeless people-those in their middle age who are in need of rehabilitation because of alcoholism, financial failure, family breakup and matters of that kind. Those people are clearly in need of a distinct and separate kind of assistance from that required by people in the youth group. The third group, of course, is women who are homeless because of temporary or permanent family breakdown or disharmony. Of course, the special needs of the children of women in that unfortunate situation also need to be taken specially into account. I think that the point about the need for flexibility is very important, and the Government is commended for endeavouring to meet that difficulty.

As we go through the negotiating phase there will be some need to clarify the eventual and final form of the committees which will be established with voluntary agencies, State governments and the Commonwealth government to administer these programs so that we will have a clear understanding of the way in which the programs can be properly administered.

It is obvious that the problems, which have arisen in some areas such as in nursing home administration where similar committees have been established between those organisations and governments, are a signpost to the kinds of considerations which the Government must think about very deeply before implementing administrative programs at the Federal level in order to ensure that they reach their final conclusion. I believe there are some lessons to be learned. For instance, the question of staffing ratios which are applied by the Federal Government in regard to the operation of nursing homes, hostels and organisations of that kind are a guide to the difficulties which may be faced. These problems in regard to homelessness occur as a result of an inadequate appreciation of the quickly changing scene-the result of multitudinous factors in our society-in a community.

We hope that restraints are not to be applied in these programs and that the Government will give very deep consideration to the implementation of its administrative and bureaucratic machinery. Obviously there is a need not to create centres where few people are in need. Clearly funds should not be squandered but should be directed to those who are experiencing the most real crises. I think that some queries arise when we consider that aspect. There is also the question of the women's emergency services program which stands out in this area. The guidelines which are attached to the Minister's statement state that Government sponsorship of projects is permissible where no suitable non- government agency is available. I think that first of all we need to establish what level of government we are talking about. Does it mean State government, the Federal Government or local government? Does the statement mean, if we are talking about the Federal Government, that intervention by the Federal Government is likely in the area where no non-government agency is available? I would like to hear the Minister's views about that matter in the course of the debate on this subject.

Other matters are of concern and I hope there would be some scope for a far greater involvement of the third level of government-that is local government-in the implementation of the programs. I hope that the Federal Government in dealing with the States would be proposing that local government would be able to take a far greater role in this area. It is a truism to observe that local government is an enormous untapped source of expertise and can give a quick and very useful assessment of the local needs in regard to this matter. I believe that on the whole local government would be most willing to involve itself and to assist in the provision of services for the homeless, being as close as it is to the community. In fact we could clearly see co-operation occurring at all three levels being very effective in delivering appropriate services. Again, the Opposition welcomes the statement and looks forward to seeing the Government's firmer policies being developed in this area and we wish the Government well in the course of its deliberations and discussions with the State governments. I hope the Government notes the points that we have made in regard to establishing close liaison with local government and non-government agencies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support the Government on the proposals contained in the statement on the review of crisis and youth accommodation. Unfortunately, I have not had time to review the statement completely, but on initial reading it appears as though the Commonwealth Government is at last seriously addressing itself to the crisis situation which exists in relation to youth accommodation. Having said this, I would like to express a few reservations in regard to major points. Firstly, I am concerned about the shift in administration from the Commonwealth to the States, in spite of the Government's undertaking to relieve some of the additional pressure which will be put on the States by providing for the additional administrative costs within the funding arrangement. My concern is that in passing administrative control to the States, we may allow the scheme to wind down eventually and to be lost completely, as happened with the Australian assistance plan. I believe it would be better to maintain a close supervision at the Federal level until the new programs have been firmly established.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, my concern relates to the new youth support scheme in that although it is a vastly improved scheme, it still does not allow for capital expenditure for the purpose of purchase and maintenance of accommodation. I believe that there is very good evidence to suggest that in many places the outright purchase of accommodation would be cheaper in the long run than rental. I would have thought that this flexibility ought to have been provided within the scheme. Thirdly, my concern relates to the fact that it appears as though the Government has not thought of tying housing grants specifically to youth housing. The National Youth Coalition for Housing put forward such a proposal. It seemed to me that this proposal would indeed be able to be accommodated well within the range of programs which the Government is here proposing.

I think that in many States single young people in particular are last on the list for priority for public housing and I would have thought that the Government might have been able to tie those things together in order to assist in that regard. But having stated those reservations, I would certainly like to reiterate the Democrats' support for the new initiatives. If the legislation may be needed to spell out any of the programs mentioned in the statement and if the legislation closely reflects the concerns in the statement, the Government will have our total support.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS AND DEFENCE

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 16 November 1983, on motion by Senator Chaney:
That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Primmer Sen C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, in my opinion, the Government response to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence has been rather strangely formulated. In my view it may well have fallen off the back of a truck between Darwin and Timbuktu. The editor could have been any one of a number of persons because it is written in both the first and second persons. I find that rather strange. In the second paragraph on page 4 of the report, this terminology is used:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . I do not think it warrants detailed comment now.
Further down the page the response states:
I now come to the last and most important part of the Senate report . . .
Later it states:
I shall take these together:
Yet on page 5 it states:
In a statement issued at the conclusion of his visit, Mr Hayden reaffirmed . . .
Later, in the same paragraph, it states:
At the same time, Mr Hayden made it clear . . .

I am wondering who the author of the response is in actual fact. It came to the Senate without any signature whatever on it. As I said, it may well have fallen off the back of a truck. It could have come from the Sydney fish market or God knows where. It seems to me that the authors are obviously in the Indonesian desk at the Department of Foreign Affairs. I suggest that they go back to school and learn how to put a report together. If that is the best that they can do then God help Foreign Affairs and God help the Timorese.

In other parts of the response there is a general tendency, in my view, to write down the Senate Committee's report by stating that the Senate Committee's report was largely prepared from evidence given by refugees as though there is something wrong with a refugee. It states that much of the report relates to the immediate aftermath of the Indonesian invasion. When I spoke on the tabling of this report, I pointed out that the Committee did its utmost and succeeded in taking evidence from people from Timor who had arrived in Australia only a matter of a very few days or a very few weeks before the hearings. Later, the reponse states:
The suggestion that there was some semblance of normal political freedom in East Timor at the end of Portugese rule overlooks the extreme social and political backwardness of East Timor at that time.

So what? The facts of the matter were, in the view of the Committee after listening to evidence from all over Australia and elsewhere, that there was some semblance of normal political freedom in East Timor at the end of Portugese rule . Why do the authors have to tend to denigrate the authors of the Senate Committee report by introducing material like that? Later on the response again, in a somewhat denigrating view of the Senate Committee's report, stated:
It should be noted in this respect that food shortages have long been a feature of life in East Timor.

The facts of the matter are that that is true, but what the authors of this response do not go on to say is that those food shortages were regional and were overcome by the transfer of food and other goods by the people within East Timor . When one area was short of food, food was transported from areas where there was plenty of food. For that reason I am very distressed at the way the authors have put this response together.

In relation to the Committee's recommendations, vis-a-vis the question of some form of consensus being taken in East Timor for the people to decide whether they want to go in with Indonesia or not, the response is not in keeping with Australian Labor Party policy on this matter. The first paragraph of the ALP policy on East Timor carried at the last National Conference, states:

The ALP recognises the inalienable right of the East Timorese to self- determination and independence and condemns and rejects the Australian government's recognition of the Indonesian annexation of East Timor.

My time is running out. I just say, in the final analysis, that it is regrettable that public servants have, in my view, much more influence and input into government policy on foreign affairs than do the Australian people's elected representatives in this place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Government response to the report of the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence on East Timor. I regret I did not hear all that Senator Primmer said, but I also find this response an extremely evasive and unsatisfactory one and one which does not stand to the credit of this Government. In the very short period that we have to discuss this matter may I comment on some of the remarks contained in the response which demonstrate what I say. In the early part of the Government's response, where it talks about the situation in 1974, it states:

SPEECH.PARA: After that, the collapse of Portugese rule and the turmoil and chaos of civil war, led ultimately to Indonesian intervention.

That really telescopes a lot of facts and truths, and leaves them out, because we know that the encouragement which I am afraid the Indonesians received from some United States sources and the encouragement which they received from the Australian Government at that time-that was the Whitlam Government-was such that the Indonesians were persuaded that they could get away with such an intervention. It certainly was not just the turmoil and chaos that led to the Indonesian intervention. There is a lot more to it than that. When one goes further, in the response one finds that it mentions the two reports, including the one of the Australian Parliamentary Delegation that went recently to East Timor. It states that the report of the Delegation was compiled on the basis of first hand experience and observation. Of course, it was the result of a four- day visit and a visit during which the Delegation rapidly went from one place to another. I think it must be recognised that there was inadequate material before both bodies when they prepared their reports. The report we are discussing today had to be based partially on evidence given by people who had not been in Timor for some time. Also, I think that in one or two cases witnesses could not come here-certainly they were not supported in coming here. So there are defects.

I now turn to the various matters which this response deals with. The matter of human rights can only be said to be dealt with in a very scant and inadequate way. The response mentions the atrocities and abuses of human rights which took place on both sides. There is no doubt where the mass of atrocities took place. It was not the Timorese who were killing the 150,000 or so of their fellow persons who were there at that time. They were not dropping people from helicopters and planes. They were not doing these various things which are matters of history. Of course they are matters of the past, but we in this Parliament should still be watching for any continuation of them. We know that, despite the optimism of the Delegation that went to Indonesia, since then, a considerable campaign has been waged against an apparently almost non-existent enemy. But we were told that that was not going to happen. We were told by the members of the delegation which went there that they put all their trust in Governor Carrascalao. He seems to have lost a large part of his power since then and has been pushed into the background. I think we have to watch the area closely because we still have an interest, and a human rights interest, in Indonesia.

I believe that in considering current conditions there one must recognise that current conditions include what seems to be violence and behaviour towards the native peoples of Timor that is, not worthy of a country of the size of Indonesia. Although there have been improvements in the normal conditions of the people there and there may not be the famines and so forth that there were, nonetheless the absence of human rights and the fact that people in their thousands are still in camps, and there without trial, are matters which should be constantly part of our concern.
The recommendations are dealt with in a most cursory manner. I presume it is the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) who says in the response:
The Australian Government has never sought to evade the obvious fact that there have been differences between Australia and Indonesia over East Timor.

What a weak and pusillanimous attitude that is. Why should we be avoiding that obvious fact. We never sought to evade it? What have we done to explain it in straightforward terms to them? I think very often our Department of Foreign Affairs has tended to put the facts aside. It has not always investigated the complaints that have been made. I believe that altogether this response and its attitude towards the recommendations in the report do not make positive statements of what we will do in the future, in what way we will help the Timorese people and in what way we will ensure that the help we give to them goes into their hands and not into the hands of the officials, and Indonesian officials at that. I believe this is a totally unsatisfactory response to the report of the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Sen The Hon D.B.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: -I wish to address myself briefly to the Government's response to the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence inquiry into human rights and the conditions of the people in East Timor. I preface my remarks by saying that I am convinced now, as I was then, that it was an unfortunate area of investigation. It was an area of great emotionalism. It was an area in which we found it extremely hard to get a cross-section of views, and it was an area in which we could find no way, as a committee, of investigating the situation on the ground.

SPEECH.PARA: Having said that, it is abundantly clear to me, having read the Government's response, that the response very closely follows the conclusions of the three members of the Committee who unfortunately saw fit to issue a dissenting report. It very closely follows the views that were reached in that dissenting report. For instance, the Government's response highlights the sad history of the East Timorese under 400 years, or thereabouts, of Portugese occupation. It also indicates that prior to April 1974 there was no real emergence of an independence movement or of individual political parties. It refers of course to the collapse of Portugese rule-the collapse of colonialism-to the chaos, the turmoil and the civil war that followed that occurrence and to the intervention at that stage, at the conclusion of the civil war or indeed partly in an attempt to conclude it, of the Indonesian Government itself. The Senate Committee report was compiled largely from evidence that came from refugees, and much of it was five, six or seven years old. Of course these were matters which we, in our dissenting report, highlighted and which have clearly been observed by the Government in its response to that report.

On human rights, the Government came to the conclusion that atrocities certainly were committed on both sides, but that there is now a human rights situation which is significantly better than the rather disastrous circumstances of five to seven years ago. That was the conclusion that our dissenting report likewise came to. Similarly the Government's response suggests, basically as a result of the visit of the Australian Parliamentary Delegation to East Timor, that the current conditions are significantly better than they were some years ago. There is no specific food shortage. There is indeed a probability that within a few years East Timor may well be self-sufficient in rice and in a number of other fibres. The Parliamentary Delegation concluded that there is also to be seen a distinct improvement in communications and in the general health and welfare of the Timorese people in their present circumstance.

The United Nations resolutions and actions was a third area of inquiry and the Government's response on that was merely to remark that these are a matter of historical record, which after all is true. On the question of Australian policy towards East Timor the Government response concluded, as indeed the dissenting report concluded, that the best thing we could do for East Timor was to maintain a pressure in a circumstance of close liaison with the Indonesians directed towards the welfare and development of East Timor itself. The final matter I wish to raise relates to the appropriate action to be taken by the Australian Government. I think the concluding words of the dissenting report really sum up the view expressed in the Government's response:

As history has unfolded Australia can best serve the people of East Timor by expanding its determination to liaise with Indonesia in helping the wide spectrum development of the island as an Indonesian province instead of as a Portugese colony.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I can help Senator Primmer with regard to the ostensible author of the paper we are considering. I take it that in accordance with the current practice when the word 'I' appears in the report it refers to the Minister who represents the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden). In this case it is the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans), although I understand he had no personal part in tabling this document in the Senate. It deals with a report of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence which was tabled on 8 September. That inquiry began in November 1981. The Committee was charged with reporting not only on the human rights and conditions of people in East Timor but also on the actions taken by the United Nations and on the appropriate policies that might be adopted by an Australian government. Two days before the Senate Committee's report was tabled a report from the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence which had visited East Timor was tabled in the Parliament. It had the advantage, of course , which our Committee was denied, of visiting the province of East Timor.

SPEECH.PARA: Our Committee's report was, regrettably, divided. Three Government senators supported the report and three Opposition senators opposed it. This is very regrettable but there was no way in which we could reach agreement in relation to most areas. Our criticisms of the report were as follows: It was almost entirely based on the views of refugees; much of their information was out of date; they were dealing not with matters that were referred to the Committee but with events that occurred some years ago; and refugees, whether from the Soviet Union, East Timor or elsewhere are notoriously a very unreliable source of information about the state of the country from which they have fled. We saw no satisfied Timorese. We saw no Indonesians. The whole tone of the report, in our view, was anti-Indonesian in slant.

With regard to the recommendations-we agreed with one recommendation but disagreed with the others-the problem was that the incorporation of East Timor into Indonesia is irreversible. The recommendations, if the Government had taken any notice of them, would have antagonised the Indonesians, harmed our ability to help the East Timorese and achieved nothing. For those reasons the Opposition senators on that Committee dissented from nearly all of the recommendations.

I should make it clear that in my view-I think this is the view of my colleagues-the Indonesian invasion of East Timor was in clear breach of international law. It was accompanied by great brutality. The short term effect was to do great harm both to human rights and to the physical condition of the people of East Timor. However, our information is that the conditions of the people of East Timor are improving. That was supported by the views of the Joint Committee which visited East Timor.

I agree with the Government's rejection of virtually all the recommendations made by the Senate Committee from which we dissented because they would be mere irritants and would achieve nothing but harm in our relations with Indonesia. They would not help us at all in our ability to assist the people of East Timor. We all agreed with one recommendation, that is, that Australia should encourage Indonesia to permit the free movement of East Timorese out of Indonesia and East Timor and that Australia should continue its family reunion program for East Timorese. In the Government's response, the point is made that as a result of that policy being implemented there has been a steady improvement in family reunion. That program is now virtually complete. I congratulate the Government on the decisions it has made. I think it made the proper decisions. The decisions will not be popular with some people. I do not think the people with whom the decisions will not be popular really understand the consequences to us, the Indonesians and the East Timorese of the actions they proposed. I can well understand why the Government did not choose to have this matter debated either by the Caucus Foreign Affairs and Defence Committee or by the Caucus itself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government, by its response, has virtually rejected the majority report of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence and essentially has accepted the minority report. I speak as one who, a long while ago, had some knowledge of East Timor. The Government's response and ministerial statement has, for the first time of which I am aware, put down some of the essentials for any such debate, such as a description of the nature of the island, the meagre resources, the lack of any particular agricultural potential, the very poor quality of the colonisation of the Portuguese over the centuries, the lack of any public service infrastructure by the Portuguese, the fact that the people themselves have been subjected, as the Aborigines here have, to all the bad characteristics of the Western community, and the very low subsistence level of the people in East Timor.

SPEECH.PARA: To understand the island one must understand that it has bare subsistence, it is mountainous and it has only very small pockets of agriculture. The people themselves live in very fiercely independent tribal areas. They are very proud of their tribal leaders and kings. No public service was developed by the Portuguese. I think that at the time the Portuguese left one medical officer on the island. The point I want to stress more than anything else is that when we look towards these people, for whom I have considerable affection and sympathy, our primary aim, apart from assistance given through the Department of Foreign Affairs, should be to give as much medical help to that island as we can.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Indonesians knock it off.

—Let us press on and let us check it. If that is the case we must overcome that problem. The fact is that the Timorese, in the same way as the Aborigines, have inherited from us upper respiratory tract infections of a chronic nature, tuberculosis which is tremendously infectious, venereal diseases, various other diseases of the Western world and, of course, those diseases that flow from our habits in relation to alcohol and diet. As one who knows something about the problems of health and diet in that area I emphasise that the first problem to tackle is that of health. A person who is healthy, who is not plagued with dysentery, malaria, avitaminosis, typhus or any of those kinds of diseases can exist on six or eight ounces of uncooked rice a day. I know, because I did so for years. A person who has two pounds of uncooked rice a day and who is subjected to any one or two of those diseases is likely to die. In other words, we should be attempting to improve their health by attacking malaria and the amoebic and bacillary dysenteries. We should attack, above everything else, tuberculosis and upper respiratory tract infections. We should get them healthy. We should immunise the young as we did in Vietnam. I saw that being done to the young in Vietnam. We should de-worm them, de-louse them and de -scabies them as we had to do with the Aborigines. We will be doing more for the new generations ahead if we can give them a healthy body. They will survive on their Indian maize, corn, gula, malacca, and the sago palm sugar. They will survive on the wild goats, caribous or buffaloes in that area provided they are healthy. I make the plea that above everything else we do we should seek to help them on a health level.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that this is a time of need and understanding. It is true that we can criticise the Indonesians for their actions in 1975. We can criticise ourselves equally or even more strongly than that. The Indonesians themselves suffered enourmous problems because under the Japanese they had no public service structure or infrastructure. They had to build a public service from nothing. I say this to the Senate: Of all the nations I have seen in South East Asia and the nations in which I have lived the Indonesians have made tremendous gains. They started literally from nothing, from an army form of public service, and they now have a much more orderly show. There is a much greater distance to run. I ask the Australian people, not with any lack of criticism, to look at the Indonesians, to understand the problems that they face and to reach out to them with the hand of friendship. They are our next door neighbours. They are people who have a lot to give to this area. Of course where we have problems raised by Amnesty or anybody else, we must act. We must always be against any kind of tyranny. The message that ought to come through from this is that we should learn more about human understanding.
Debate (on motion by Senator Grimes) adjourned.

Consideration resumed from 16 November 1983, on motion by Senator Crowley:
That the Senate take note of the papers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to comment on two of the papers. I guess that other senators have different interests, but I was particularly drawn to the annual report for 1982-83 of the Human Rights Commission. I found it a most fascinating document. I cannot possibly give a report on all the points raised in it. It describes very nicely what the Commission is about and what it has done this year. In particular, the Human Rights Commission addresses itself to the Human Rights Commission Act 1981. Under that Act it can review legislation, investigate complaints, and undertake research and educational programs affecting human rights, and it is further charged with the administration of the Racial Discrimination Act 1975. Some things it can do on its own initiative; on others it takes instructions from the Attorney-General. I suppose that the most recent example of the Human Rights Commission acting under its own initiative was earlier this week when the Commission met and decided to send an observer to the Alice Springs gaol to observe the procedures following arrest of prisoners from the Pine Gap demonstrations.
—How much did that cost the taxpayer?
—Was that really necessary?

—I am very interested that Opposition senators are all suddenly so interested. Perhaps they will observe that when it is reported next year. One of the principal functions of the Human Rights Commission, apart from its responsibility in terms of reviewing legislation and taking complaints and investigating them, is to promote an understanding, an acceptance and a public discussion of matters of human rights in Australia. To answer the interjections just made, that is precisely what the Commission will be achieving with its observer in Alice Springs. Public discussion about what happens to people after they are arrested will be able to take place based on the independent observations by the Commission's observer. I should have thought that that was well worth whatever the cost is.

SPEECH.PARA: Further, the Human Rights Commission is able to undertake research and educational programs and any other programs that it might see fit to undertake. I am particularly taken in the report with the effort the Commission has made to address itself to its responsibility for disseminating information and in taking up its educational role. In particular, the Commission has devised a course entitled 'Teaching Human Rights: Activities for Schools'. This course provides activities and materials organised around set topics, including human rights and the law, freedom of conscience, opinion and expression, the right to live and the right to die, freedom of assembly, association and participation in public affairs, equal opportunity, non-discrimination, the family, and education. These are organised into a course for school children. That is one area of the Commission's responsibility that ought to be applauded. I notice further that the Commission is hoping to address itself in the near future to the development of material for adult and community educators. I am interested that it sees the provision of materials for adult education as quite separate from the provision of materials for school education.

Finally, I raise two points. The first concerns the comments made by the Commission on the Mental Health Ordinance in the Australian Capital Territory. I have had the privilege of sitting on the Mental Health Review Tribunal in South Australia for four years, so matters of rights of people under Mental Health Acts are of some interest to me. I notice that the Commission commented on these ordinances, and its report, which was tabled in Parliament on 9 December 1982, is summarised here. It stresses the right of people to suicide if they choose, and says that attempting to commit suicide is not in itself evidence of insanity or mental illness.

It is quite an interesting challenge for us to consider the Human Rights Commission suggesting-and I do not believe that this has been widely debated by the public-that the choice to commit suicide is a right of people, the right to die, and that, further, it is not evidence necessarily of mental illness. The Commission also suggests that while it is very distressing to watch people who are becoming ill, particularly for relatives and friends in the community, compulsory intervention at an early stage to relieve that distress should not be permitted. I find that very interesting and somewhat perturbing. I would offer to follow this up with the Commission, because I am not sure that we should leave people who are becoming psychiatrically ill to make decisions on their own behalf until they are very ill, at which stage their care and treatment is more difficult.

I was fascinated to discover that the Commission has taken a considerable look at the problems of corporal punishment because it had a submission from Parents and Teachers Against Violence in Education. The most striking comment in the report is that the Commission will seek the reaction of children themselves before it concludes its inquiry. I am rather fascinated by the Commission asking children how they expect to be hit.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: — When I turned to the list of papers, I noticed that in relation to the treaties the document states:

SPEECH.PARA: Text of Treaties to which Australia has become a party by signature.
Over the page we get:
Texts of Treaties which Australia has accepted or to which Australia has acceded.

That is not accurate; it is not even a summary. I certainly do not have any of the texts or even a summary of the treaties and I have no idea what the treaties are. I believe that every honourable senator should know in detail what they are . I take just one of them, and I gather that the country of Australia has already accepted this treaty and acceded to it. It states:

Amendment to Article 11, paragraph 2 (a) of the Constitution of the Asia- Pacific Telecommunity, adopted on 27 March 1976, which amendment was adopted at Bangkok on 13 November 1981. The Amendment was accepted by Australia on 16 August 1983 and has not yet entered into force.

What amendment? I have absolutely no idea what that amendment is, and I defy anyone else in the chamber to have any idea of what the amendment was or, indeed , any knowledge of any of the treaties. The treaties might be tabled, but I am sure that the Government does not expect every honourable senator to go and sit at the table and read the texts of the treaties.

TALK.START.PARA: —Most of those matters were tabled in due course.

—Yes, that is what I said. I believe that they were tabled, but I do not believe that the Government would expect us all to sit at the table and read the treaties one by one. Can the contents of the treaties--
—Ignorance has never been an excuse.

—I believe that that was wrong. I agree with Senator Gietzelt, but I believe that treaties have become far more important to the Australian community since his Party has been in government. The fact that since he has been in government the whole Constitution of Australia has changed by the present Government's use of the external affairs powers and by its challenge regarding Tasmania in the High Court of Australia--
—Upheld.

—As Senator Crowley says, it was upheld, but not upheld in a legal sense; it was in an opinion sense, and it cannot be described in any other form at all. There were seven High Court judges. The senior High Court judge said that the external affairs power of the Constitution could not be used in that way. Two other judges agreed with that view. Four judges were of the opposing view. It was on the opinion of those four judges, opinion only, and on their personal views and feelings that the Constitution of Australia was so radically and dramatically changed. It was forced to change by the centralist Government that is now in power. It is for that very reason that I ask the Government, now that the treaties and conventions have been signed and accepted, and will be carried out particularly while this Government is in power, to give each honourable senator the details of them. That was not necessary while we were in power, because only with the agreement of the States could the treaties be forced through to State governments. This Government is not of that persuasion. It is a centralist government. It demands, indeed forces on the States-whether they agree or not and even without consultation with them-any conventions or treaties that it signs.

SPEECH.PARA: It is for this reason that I believe the whole system must be altered. Every honourable senator in this chamber needs to have a complete detailed knowledge of what the Government is about and on what it is signing on behalf of all the States. While Tasmania was the first victim of this Government's powers, of the change in the Constitution, every State and every honourable senator must be interested in the protection of their States and must be given the opportunity to obtain the necessary knowledge. Because of this situation, I ask the Government not just to table the treaties, but to allow each honourable senator to have a detailed copy of them in their rooms at the time they would normally be tabled.

TALK.START.PARA: —But when the documents are tabled you can ask to speak to the tabling of the documents.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

—Can I answer the interjection, Mr Deputy President, because I do not think the Minister quite understood what I was saying. I acknowledge the honourable senator's point. Every report is also tabled, and I do not think the Minister expects us to be able to talk to them or to go to the table and peruse them. They are put in our rooms. I am asking that the treaties also be put in our rooms.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —A couple of very interesting matters have been raised by honourable senators under what is a compendious motion covering a series of papers. I think it would be in the interests of the Senate if we could separate those papers and leave them on the Notice Paper for further consideration. With that in mind, I seek leave to move a separate motion that the Senate take note of the Human Rights Commission annual report 1982-83, to have it adjourned and put on the Notice Paper, and to move a separate motion with respect to the Treaties-Australia's Involvement, papers.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I think this report is a matter to which the Senate may wish to direct its attention, particularly in light of the announced intention of the Attorney- General (Senator Gareth Evans) to introduce human rights legislation. For that reason, this report, which raises a number of interesting matters, some of which were touched on in the very brief speech that was given by Senator Crowley within the five-minute limit, needs further consideration. It seems to me that in the General Business time which remains for us in this session there may be an opportunity for us to come back to that. At this stage, I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the papers.
Since another senator wishes to speak on this matter, which has already been addressed by Senator Walters, may I not speak at this stage and reserve my right to speak at a later date?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make some comments concerning the list of treaties. I wish to draw attention to the list that was tabled yesterday . As anybody who has looked at it would find, it contains agreements covering a fairly wide variety of areas. For instance, it covers matters dealing with telecommunications, the Antarctic, air services, meat trade, fishing, wetlands, coffee, marine living resources, and others. The point to be made is that the Government's attitude is that all these matters, whether at home or abroad, can now fall within the Government's use of its foreign affairs powers and interpretation. I do not think that many people would realise that to deal with a group of treaties of that nature could throw this net over all those matters, whether they be within or outside the Commonwealth. It may well be of concern to many people to know that irrespective of the Government's involvement with these matters, it may intervene. The centralist and expansive desires of the Government may well be felt in any of these areas as they will in any other area of the approximately 1,400 treaties and agreements on various issues that we have with other countries. All I wish to do is record the fact that I totally oppose the concept of the use of these foreign affairs powers in these totally inappropriate ways.

SPEECH.PARA: Debate (on motion by Senator Chaney) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Ministerial Statement

Senator Grimes-In the spirit of conciliation, may I ask that Senator Crowley have leave to speak on a report on medical fraud. As the motion was moved en bloc, she really does not have the right to speak again.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I felt it was important to make a brief comment about this statement, because very much discussion happened in this place during the introduction of the Medicare legislation. One of the arguments brought against the introduction of Medicare legislation was the possibility of fraud. These points were also raised during the Estimates committees, particularly during Estimates Committee B hearings. There are a number of things that must be noted. One is that the Government has made it very clear that it will not tolerate the abuses of medical fraud and is very serious about its intention to reduce the magnitude of the problem. I presume that means that it does not think it will reduce it altogether. It is also important to notice that the medical fraud that is currently being pursued is happening under the existing health insurance scheme which is a combination of private health insurance funds. While it may be the case that it will continue under Medicare, I think we have first to note that medical fraud of a considerable size has been happening under the existing insurance schemes. It may well be-I would argue that it is certainly likely to be-the case that under Medicare the likelihood of fraud will be reduced because it will be easier for the Health Insurance Commission to pursue that small percentage of medical practitioners who engage in this practice.

SPEECH.PARA: The paper devotes quite some time to an estimate of how much medical fraud amounts to. I will not devote too much time to the extraordinarily complex formula arrived at, but it is certainly estimated that last year it was $100m and probably it will be nearer to $120m in the current financial year. That is a very large amount of taxpayers' money being lost to the community, and the Government says that it will address itself most seriously to preventing that continual loss. It is important to note that in the Budget $8m was allocated to pursue medical fraud practitioners. It is also important to note that only a very small percentage of medical practitioners are involved. It is estimated that about 3 per cent of doctors actually could be charged with or are involved in medical fraud. Even so, they are doing very well, thank you; they get away with about $120m a year. It is important to note, too, how much it is costing the taxpayer to pursue medical fraud moneys. It costs at least the $8m allocated in the Budget, but also a further $4m was appropriated to the Australian Federal Police. There are more appropriations in other departments, so perhaps the cost may be even higher than $12m.

This expenditure is justified in terms of the possibility of reclaiming some of that $120m; however, during Estimates committee hearings we were given evidence that although that may be the estimate of what is lost, it is certainly not the amount of money that is reclaimed even when doctors are found guilty and charged . So I think we have to notice just how expensive medical fraud is and in particular the costs this Government is bearing to ensure that that medical fraud does not continue at the current rate. Even so it is a very big expense and I think it is important that we do take it very seriously. Some people in our community take considerable punishment by way of gaol sentences or large fines if they are found guilty of crimes. Many of that small percentage of doctors, although large numbers in terms of dollars might be involved, who are actually guilty of medical fraud, which is a considerable crime in terms of the size of the exercise, are able to avoid any punishment at all because it is very dificult to collect evidence against them. The Government is saying it does not believe one set of criminals should be treated differently from another set of criminals.

Medical fraud is a crime that we do not tolerate. However, we also appreciate that chasing and catching that fraud is a very expensive business. The collection of data raises some very important difficulties in terms of the invasion of the civil rights of people whose evidence may be necessary in order to bring charges against the medical practitioners. The Government's legislation changes will address these matters but I think it is too complex a matter on which to develop an argument at this stage, so I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Crowley, you cannot seek leave because you were given leave to make a statement. You made your statement by leave; that is the end of it.

—We are all caught by the fact that a procedure has been followed which we would all agree is rather cumbersome and does not enable us to follow the normal forms. I suggest that if Senator Crowley or indeed Senator Walters wishes to keep this matter alive for further discussion now or at a later time, they might follow the procedure of seeking leave to move a separate motion to take note of the paper.
—That would be appropriate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 16 November 1983 on motion by Senator Chipp:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to detain the Senate for very long because this is a matter where, as I understand it, it is clear where the majority lies. Senator Chipp has moved a motion to establish a Select Committee on Animal Welfare, to consist of four senators. That matter has been addressed on behalf of the Opposition by Senator Scott who laid down a series of propositions about the work already being done and indicated that we would not oppose the establishment of the Committee notwithstanding the fact that a great deal is being done in this field. On behalf of the Opposition I wish to move an amendment to the terms of the motion to establish the Select Committee. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: In paragraph (1) of the motion, leave out the words 'four', 'two' and 'one' and insert 'six', 'three' and 'two'.

I shall speak quickly to that. Senator Chipp's proposal is to establish a select committee consisting of only four senators. That is not a unique proposition of course; there have been other select committees of that size although the more common size of committees of the Senate has been six. On this occasion four senators have been selected and I understand the reasoning behind that is that there is a heavy committee work load and it is not desired to add to that any more than is necessary. The feeling on the part of the Government, as I understand it, is that a couple of senators is a reasonable complement from its side to man this Committee.

The difficulty that arises from the Opposition's point of view is that with two members to be nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button), one to be nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, and one to be nominated by the Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Chipp) we will have the situation whereby the official Opposition has only one representative. The difficulty with that is two-fold: First, the Opposition is officially composed of two parties and within each of the parties, although we are in coalition and generally in close harmony, there are quite particular interests in this matter which is of great public interest around Australia. I think there is a particular interest in it in the State of Victoria but certainly there is in other States as well. There is a desire on the part of the Opposition to participate in this Committee, if it is to be established, on the basis of having two representatives rather than one. That would enable both the Opposition parties to be represented and would enable us to also have what we see as a slightly better balance between the official Opposition and the Australian Democrats. As the motion stands, five Democrats would be represented by one member and 28 Liberal and National party senators would also be represented by one member. In terms of the balance of the Committee we would prefer that change.

I put the view, and I think we would be consistent in putting this in most cases, that we would wish the Senate, in general, to aim to have committees with a maximum of six members. Having that number of members eases the administration of committees, quite apart from the considerations I have raised. It does mean that a committee can divide into sub-committees, and that it can carry out its work when some senators are unavoidably absent on other business. It would ease the position considerably. It does make for a more fair representation of the official Opposition. I move that amendment for those reasons. It has been indicated to me by the Government and by the Leader of the Australian Democrats that they do not support it, although I should not purport to speak for them in this debate. On behalf of the Opposition I commend the points which I have made for the Senate's consideration and I seek support for that change.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to confirm what the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Chaney, said; that is, that the Government is not inclined to support the amendment moved by him. I think that this is a matter of balance. We have a situation in which a very heavy work load is placed on members of the Senate in the committee area. I make no bones about it. There is always a problem on the Government side, as honourable senators opposite would know, that six people are removed from the possibility of being members of such committees because they are Ministers. We believe, on balance, that four is a satisfactory number of members on the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare. We do not believe we will gain anything other than to increase the workload unnecessarily by making the number six. It is essentially a committee which will not, we believe, divide on any party, ideological or philosophical ground. It will be, as all committees should be, I suppose, a fact finding committee. Out of those facts will come recommendations. For those reasons and after looking at the matter on balance, we will not support the amendment moved by Senator Chaney.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Regretfully we cannot support the Liberal amendment, although we have great sympathy with it . The Leader of the Opposition, Senator Chaney, put an almost unanswerable case on the grounds of equity. On the other hand, the Government, to which we are grateful for accepting my motion, has a case on grounds of practicality. Senator Chaney said it was fair for the Opposition, which has 28 senators, to have more than one member on the Committee because of the Australian Democrats has only five senators. That also is unanswerable logic, but I suspect that he was talking with his tongue in his cheek. There is no joy in serving on committees; it is just jolly hard work. Seeing that the Australian Democrats sought the indulgence of the Senate to have the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare created, we thought it would be pretty bad sportsmanship if we did not offer to do our share on the Committee. We have offered to do so. We have tried to do our share.

SPEECH.PARA: I see wisdom in the point that the Minister for Social Security, Senator Grimes , made. For example, Senator Bernard Kilgariff has written to me on a very serious matter asking for our support for a Senate select committee to inquire into the dreadful practice of glue sniffing, which is increasing at a frightening rate. We would like that matter to be investigated. I have replied to Senator Kilgariff saying that at this stage the Commonwealth-State Health Ministers conference may be the more appropriate forum in which to deal with this. If that forum is not a satisfactory one, the Democrats will be looking, hopefully, to support Senator Kilgariff in his pursuit of that investigation.

Other honourable senators have other matters which they want pursued by Senate select committees. Wisely, I think, the Senate has made the unofficial rule that at any one time only two Senate select committees should be in operation. Limiting the membership of the Committee to four would allow, in an emergency such as Senator Kilgariff suggested, the rule to be stretched for a month or two so that three Senate select committees may operate at the one time. For those reasons we reluctantly state that we cannot vote with the Opposition's amendment .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —We do not intend to divide on the matter, since the numbers are clear. It should be clear from the Hansard that we, of course, support our amendment and it is opposed by the Government and the Australian Democrats.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the negative.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: NATIONAL CRIME AUTHORITY BILL 1983NATIONAL CRIME AUTHORITY (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: Reference to Standing Committee
Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I spoke earlier today on this matter I indicated that I believed we had gone a long way down the road with this. We had recognised the extent and nature of organised crime. We had recognised that traditional law enforcement agencies and methods are insufficient to combat organised crime. We had recognised that ad hoc royal commissions are not the answer. We had recognised, in fact, the need for a crimes commission or authority. We had also gone down the track on the consideration of a State- Federal standing committee, some body of that nature, and had analysed its potential strengths and weaknesses. We had gone even further on the alternative of a Commonwealth crimes commission, to the extent of actually passing a Bill to that effect. We recognised the strengths and weaknesses of that proposal. Now, finally, we are looking at a third alternative, which is this Government's proposed National Crimes Authority. We accept that it picks up some of the strengths of the previous proposals and attempts to overcome some of the recognised weaknesses. But some of us still have considerable reservations as to whether we have yet found the most effective body to achieve the now agreed objectives.

SPEECH.PARA: I am pleased that this proposed National Crime Authority will involve the States through the Inter-Governmental Committee. The Inter-Governmental Committee must, of course, refer matters to the Authority. I think that can be argued to be a safeguard-it has certainly been argued by this Government to provide a safeguard-in that the Authority will not simply be able to go off and pursue matters on its own initiative. It may well be argued, and has been argued by others, that that very restriction is too limiting. I note the Authority is not to refer references unless it is satisfied that they cannot be combated by ordinary police methods. I understand and agree with the spirit of that provision, but when it comes to application it may well be found to be too restrictive. It is something that is very difficult to define.

We have noted specifically the veto provisions in the National Crime Authority Bill, that a State or the Commonwealth can veto an investigation into offences which relate to its specific laws. I know that the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) tried to comfort us this morning by saying that we could be assured that a State or the Commonwealth would not exercise that power. With respect, I submit that his argument was very effectively demolished by the examples that Senator Sir John Carrick gave to the Senate. We on this side are far less confident that a State, or in fact the Commonwealth, may not make a decision that is necessarily in the best interests of the nation in fighting organised crime.

Many other specific questions could be raised. A number of them were raised by Senator Sir John Carrick. I do not intend to repeat the subjects that he covered . It may be difficult to specify a particular offence in relation to a proposed investigation into organised crime. I think that matter must receive further consideration. What if it led to other offences? What mechanism would operate in that regard? Senator Durack raised whether we can be sure that we will have the advantage that appears on the face of the Bill to be so; that is, that all the States will be participating. If they are not, this proposal will have a number of the weaknesses which existed in the Bill that was before the Senate last year .

I am concerned with the definition of 'relevant offence'. In effect, the definition seems to be saying that we can only investigate a major offence. After reading the reports of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union and other reports, I think it is quite arguable that that is not the most effective way to go about investigating organised crime. In fact, this procedure is made to sound more like an orthodox police investigation and this methodology has in fact failed. It has been suggested that a more effective way may well be the investigation of the whole series of petty crimes which tend to be at the base of an organised crime empire . I am not sure that this Bill is going to allow such an investigation to take place. If it is not, one has to be particularly concerned as to whether it will be effective.

Of course, I do not want reports containing hearsay or scuttlebutt, as stated by the Minister in his speech. However, I am concerned that no protection is given in defamation law except insofar as the publisher is prepared to rely on the defence of justification. I am just concerned that perhaps we have gone a little too far. So I have considerable reservations still as to the effectiveness of the proposed crime authority that has been put before the Senate.

Although it was suggested, I think by Senator Tate and Senator Gareth Evans, that if we are concerned about particular aspects we have the opportunity at the Committee stage to amend the Bill, I am not at all sure whether that will be possible. This argument is almost the same as the one we had last night because the provision that causes most concern is the veto provision. Can we amend the veto provision without the co-operation of the States? I presume that this provision is part and parcel of the package that has been agreed between the Commonwealth and the States. If in fact we amend this part of the legislation does it mean that we will lose the co-operation of whatever States are currently of that mind and therefore enact a body that will lose a considerable amount of its potential effectiveness?

I have indicated that I do not oppose many of the incidental matters. However, I still have reservations. All of us who have contributed for so long to the debate on the principle behind this legislation would obviously like a few months to consider the detail of the Bill. It has been before the Parliament for only a few days and some new definitions and new concepts have been raised. As I said, we are concerned about whether it will work effectively. We now need the views and comments of the public who have shown interest in the subject in the past. We are not concerned about principle. I am pleased to say that the matter of principle is now settled. Rather, we need to consider details that are critical in regard to whether the Bill will be successful in operation or not.

There is no better way that I can contemplate to allow the public to so contribute than to refer the Bill to a multiparty committee of this Senate which can consider such questions and, I hope, respond positively. It appears to me that a Senate committee is the best vehicle by which to eliminate the reservations that some of us have, to satisfy the questions of the public who are interested in stamping out organised crime and to assure people that the formula which has been arrived at will give us the greatest possible opportunity to create a body capable of achieving the agreed desired objectives. I therefore urge that course of action upon the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —A month ago the whole of the Parliament- every member of Parliament-was grasped with the need for the establishment of a National Crime Authority now. Not one member of parliament would have suggested then that there was any need for delay in the establishment of such an authority . The spectre of organised crime in Australia has been raised in the minds of the public following the glare of publicity that has been associated with the inquiries of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. The public has been made conscious of sophisticated crime involving such things as drug running, tax evasion, illegal gambling, currency violations, theft, fraud, obtaining financial benefit by vice engaged in by others, extortion, violence, bribery and corruption. The people of Australia are now well aware that organised crime is a major problem.

SPEECH.PARA: The time has well passed for the need to raise public consciousness of the problem. The need now is for the establishment of an authority which will be able to generate admissible evidence to ensure that criminals are put behind bars. Despite the integrity and the energy of Mr Costigan, are the runs on the board? Are the criminals behind bars? I believe that probably more heat than light has been shed on the problem thus far. My remarks should not be considered in any way as being derogatory to the efforts made by the Royal Commissioner or by the Royal Commissioner's staff. However, I believe-I understood this was the attitude of every other member of parliament a month ago-that there is a need to establish an authority now, post haste, which will be able to generate admissible evidence.

We are now faced with the proposition that the Bill brought down by the Government for consideration by the Senate, entitled the National Crime Authority Bill 1983, should be sent off to an expanded Senate standing committee and that that committee should report back by 30 April 1984. As has been explained by the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans), to my satisfaction, this delay would be unfortunate, to say the least, and may, indeed, be damaging to the consensus that apparently has been reached with the States and to the eventual effectiveness of the Authority. In my view, no case has been made out for such a delay. A case may have been made out for certain amendments to be made to the Bill after due consideration at the Committee stage. Senator Durack advanced an argument which is possibly admissible in considering whether or not this matter should be referred to a Senate standing committee and that is that the Bill arrived in the Parliament only last week and it may well be that members of parliament have not had time to consider its implications.

As we all know, a considerable amount of discussion has taken place over how best to combat sophisticated organised crime throughout Australia and how best to establish the machinery which will give the backup required to the various police forces in Australia.
