That is an argument, but there has been considerable discussion on that matter. A Green Paper on a National Crimes Commission was published. Major discussions were held on the initiative of the Government, in Canberra in July. Only last month there were debates on this issue in this chamber and in the House of Representatives. The lines were clearly drawn. There have been discussions between the Government and each of the States. As was indicated by the Attorney-General in his second reading speech, agreement was reached at ministerial council level, we and now have the National Crime Authority Bill.

Senator Durack raised a number of points about the Bill. He queried the appropriateness of the provisions relating to appointments. I do not think he queried the appropriateness of the provision relating to the appointment of the Chairman, but he queried the appropriateness of the provisions relating to two other members of the Authority. He questioned whether or not one should be appointed on the unanimous recommendation of the Attorneys-General and the other appointed on the unanimous recommendation of the State Ministers responsible for police matters. He queried the restricted definitions of 'relevant criminal activity' and 'relevant offences'. Senator Sir John Garrick and Senator Durack queried the provisions of clause 11 relating to references by the Commonwealth. Indeed, they queried clause 12, which refers to the operation of the Inter- Governmental Committee.

All of these are really matters more properly to be considered at length and in detail in the Committee stage. I believe that neither Senator Durack nor any of the supporters of the reference to the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs have denied the fact that the Authority will have appropriate powers to subpoena documents and persons, that these powers will be effective, and that the Authority will have other powers which were contained in the National Crimes Commission Act. It was admitted by the Attorney-General that there are significant differences between the contents of these measures and the previous legislation. One of those differences related to the right of a person appearing before the Authority not to incriminate himself or herself. Quite obviously, that right is not available to persons appearing before royal commissions, but then of course, that evidence is not admissible. If there were to be admissibility of evidence that was self-incriminating, it would throw open to possible attack the whole concept of British justice, the onus of proof aspect that one is innocent until proved guilty. I believe that the Government has attempted to come to grips with that problem and has struck a balance. It has balanced that aspect against the need for an effective National Crime Authority.

I believe some features of the legislation need amending. I find it quite extraordinary that the Commonwealth Minister needs to have the approval of the Inter-Governmental Committee to refer a matter relating to a relevant criminal activity to the Authority for investigation where that matter relates to an offence against a law of the Commonwealth or a Territory. I cannot see why that should be, but we are not debating the Bill now. If this were a major matter of concern on the part of the Opposition and the Australian Democrats, surely the place to have it aired would be at the Committee stage? I put it to the Opposition and to the Democrats: Surely it is proper that we should be able to vote for the second reading of the Bill, have it considered in the Committee stage, and have it appropriately amended. Then, if the Opposition desires, it could have the matter referred to a Senate standing committee. The Opposition should at least let members of parliament have a first bite at the cherry.

We have not had the opportunity, as I understand it, of having a second reading debate on the Bill. We are faced with an unfortunate situation. I believe that the Democrats ought at least to allow this Parliament the opportunity of considering the Bills. We are not even debating the Bills; we are debating a motion to send them off to a Senate committee. What are we sending off? We are sending Bills which we have not even debated to a committee before they even get to us. That, in my view, is putting the cart before the horse. Frankly, I do not know of any other measure which has come before us for which this step has been proposed. Maybe there were a dozen measures, but they have gone over my head. I know that when the industrial relations legislation came before the Senate last year we at least had a second reading debate on the measure and it was then sent off to a Senate select committee. How can we properly send a Bill to a standing committee if members of parliament have not had the opportunity of addressing themselves to the Bill as a whole in the second reading stage?

I believe it would be appropriate that if the Opposition and the Democrats so desire-I believe the Government will agree to this-we debate the legislation, adopt the measure, amend it if honourable senators like in the Committee stage, and establish the Authority so that the Government can make the appropriate financial and administrative arrangements for the appointment of persons concerned with the Authority. We should seize the opportunity that has been given to us by the co-operation of the States which was not there with the previous Government's Crimes Commission. I am not saying whether that is good or bad. It was not there. The States did not co-operate. The States have said that they will co-operate on this occasion. Let us get this piece of legislation on the statute book and then appoint, as it were, a review committee of the Senate to consider the appropriateness or otherwise, generally, of the terms of the legislation. At least let us get the Authority established. Otherwise we may well lose the co-operation of the States which is so essential for the effectiveness of a national crimes authority. A good deal of time will be wasted .

I believe, and I speak from some experience because of consultations I have had with electors on this matter, that the electors are looking for the establishment of a crime authority to ensure that the criminals who are fleecing this country, the drug runners, the frauds and all of those people described in the definition of relevant offences are brought to justice. I repeat that the definition of 'relevant offenders' includes all persons engaged in offences such as, theft, fraud, tax evasion, currency violations, illegal drug dealings, illegal gambling, obtaining financial benefit by vice engaged in by others, extortion, violence, or bribery or corruption, et cetera. People engaged in those offences should be brought to justice. Enough is enough. We have had enough publicity. There is an expectation in the minds of the people that justice now ought to be done. For justice to be done, as every member of the Senate knows, we must be able to generate admissible evidence. Frankly, the generation of admissible evidence has been somewhat lacking in activities up to date. There has been plenty of publicity, but not too much admissible evidence.

I appeal to the Opposition and the Democrats not to put the cart before the horse. If they do not accept what I have just said, if they do not accept the need for this Bill to be enacted to enable the Government to set the wheels in motion for the establishment of an authority, at least let the Parliament debate the Bill first in the second reading stage. Preferably it would go through the Committee stage and then, if honourable senators like, can be sent off to a committee. I believe that it is a reflection on members of parliament not to allow the Bill to at least be debated at the second reading stage, to allow honourable senators to have their say and, against that framework, to then have the Bill considered by a Senate standing committee after receiving evidence from those from whom that evidence is sought.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find myself drawn into this debate against the normal custom that I have in matters such as this.
—Resist the temptation.

—I say to the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) that he is the temptation. If he is prepared to put up rubbish like this national crime authority legislation under the guise in which he has put it then he is likely to get me to come and, at least, express my displeasure. I agree with nearly all that Senator Harradine said in as much as what we are looking for is some way to effectively attack criminal elements of this country. But in spite of the fact that I have listened to an excellent lecture from the Attorney-General and from Senator Tate, neither was able to demonstrate that the Bill will succeed in even embarrassing Australia's top crooks in any way, shape or form. The Government suddenly now talks of urgency. I think most of us really understand what the urgency question is all about. I think the urgency of getting this legislation through is probably to assist a certain State government which has certain commitments next year. It does not wish this legislation to come on at a time when it is involved in the sort of investigation that real legislation might ensure.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Sir John Carrick and Senator Hill, in particular, outlined so many of the ways in which this Bill is just so absolutely useless. It is a show piece only. I think we could be perfectly safe in saying that the big crooks in Australia this afternoon will be toasting Senator Evans in French champagne if this motion is lost. I believe it is a matter of terrible importance. Normally, I would agree that governments that put up rotten legislation should have the luxury of being able to live with it for a while to see how badly it goes. But in this case it is far too serious. I believe, that the National Crime Authority Bill should be renamed. I believe it should be called the crooks protection Bill because, as such, I believe it would be successful beyond the wildest dreams of anybody who proposed it as such.

Sending this legislation off to a committee, I believe, is the best way that we can save time. The Bill provides protection to people in high places. If we pass this legislation in the pathetic form that it has been put up to us we will allow Australia's top crooks at least 18 months of total protection before we can do anything about trying to change it and before we could see the damage it would have done. I believe that by reference to proper legislation they would have been herded and prosecuted before that. I certainly support the motion for that reason.

Senator Harradine made great comment about the need for the National Crime Authority. I certainly support that. We all do. My Party supports it, I support it and I think everybody in the community supports it. But the word that he missed in all that he said was 'effective'. There is no point in saying that we have an authority. It is much the same as the Sex Discrimination Bill. Just to say that we have it does not give us anything if it is bad legislation. I think Senator Evans and Senator Ryan are having a competition and I think they are about neck and neck with these two Bills.

TALK.START.PARA: —This one wins hands down.

—Senator Missen, who is a far better judge of these things than I , wishes to nominate Senator Evans. I believe that we need legislation. I believe that it needs to be as strong as we can make it. Clearly this Bill does not provide that. I have much pleasure in not only supporting the motion put forward but also in urging everybody to support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I begin my contribution to the debate on the National Crime Authority Bill 1983 with a quotation:

SPEECH.PARA: Organised crime thrives on corruption. Any proper investigation of its activities will inevitably find evidence of corruption. If a State Government or the Federal Government has the right to forbid a particular line of investigation then the independence and integrity of the commission is destroyed .

The person who said that is Mr Frank Costigan, QC, and that excellent quotation was used by Marian Wilkinson in the National Times of 11 November in a magnificent article criticising the National Crime Authority.

I was pleased to hear the contribution of Senator Archer. He put his view in, I think the strongest possible terms, saying that the present title of the Bill we are now debating is a misnomer and it should be the 'crooks protection Bill'. That is going much further than I would go, but as I say, he did put his view in very strong terms. I am staying with the line that where a Federal government has the right to forbid a particular line of investigation, then the independence and integrity of the Commission is destroyed. This Bill gives a State Government the right to forbid a particular line of investigation. On those grounds alone I believe it is unsatisfactory in the present circumstances.

I came to the Senate in 1977 and I can remember honourable senators on both sides of the chamber, who are now very gung ho-if that is the in term-on organised crime, making fun of me, or trying to make fun of me then and in subsequent years when I got up time after time and made the point that organised crime in this country was earning profits of something like $700m or $800m a year. I am not a Johnny-come-lately to this debate. I have been associated with it since 1969 when I first discovered the extent of organised crime in Australia when I was a Liberal Minister for Customs. In fact all Australian Democrats are in favour of an effective national crimes commission and we all voted for it, for a model that maybe had some shortcomings, but a model which I thought was first class-the so called Fraser-Durack model. If we are accused of holding up legislation to fight organised crime I simply say to the Attorney-General ( Senator Gareth Evans) that he has a Bill right at this moment that has been passed by both Houses of the Parliament and all it needs to implement that particular crime authority is for him to get in a car and go out to Yarralumla. Let it not be said that those of us who favour sending this Bill to a committee to look at it are holding up the appointment of the infrastructure of some form of authority.

The Attorney-General has quite properly stated his difficulties in Caucus, and I sympathise with him. I have publicly praised him whenever I have had occasion to talk about a national crimes commission and organised crime. I have stated that the Attorney-General's wishes for a solution going far beyond what he has been able to get out of Caucus with this Bill. In return for that sort of support I get childish, churlish abuse from him in newspapers this morning, a subject to which I will return in a moment. Okay, the Attorney-General does have difficulties in Caucus, but so what? That is his problem. It is not my problem and it is not the problem of other senators here. This is a House of Parliament before which a Bill is being presented. If a majority of honourable senators believe that that Bill is unsatisfactory, their only criterion is to amend that Bill to such a stage that they believe it will be effective and will work. Our job is to tell the House of Representatives that. It is then the Attorney- General's problem to persuade Caucus that the Senate is of the view that the Bill is ineffective. That is the position I want to arrive at. All of us could make criticisms of this Bill now, but we believe the best, most constructive course of action is to send it to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs under the distinguished chairmanship of Senator Tate, who, in passing, I complement on the excellent contribution that he made to this debate earlier this afternoon.

Senator Harradine raised a valid point as to why we do not have a second reading debate here. He even suggested that we go into Committee of the Whole and tidy up the Bill and then maybe send it to a committee. I find a lot of merit in that view. In fact that was the original proposition I put to Senator Chaney and Senator Durack-let the Committee have what is at least in the Senate' s mind. They countered with the argument to me: 'Would it not be better to have the second reading debate and the Committee debate armed with the wisdom and the recommedations of the Senate Committee?'. I think on balance that has a great deal of wisdom. If we are going to ask a committee of hard-working and able honourable senators to look into this kind of legislation, why not then debate the Bill five months from now with that knowledge and with that wisdom that that Committee elucidates from the evidence that it receives?

TALK.START.PARA: —If you do it the other way round you will have everyone in fixed positions before it even goes to the Committee.

—That is a danger I acknowledge-I thank Senator Missen for his interjection-while at the same time acknowledging that there is validity in Senator Harradine's point. There is something else that Senator Harradine said that I want to challenge; something on which I disagree with him outright. He said: 'Let us get an authority started. Therefore pass the Bill today and get the structure there'. There is merit in having this done as soon as possible, but can I remind Senator Haradine that this is our last chance. Once we pass this Bill we have then to rely on the good will of the House of Representatives or the good will of the Government or the good will of the Caucus before we can get even one amendment to this Bill if we pass it today. I acknowledge the urgency of this matter but I would rather wait another five months and have an effective body to fight organised crime than come in with something-I do not want to be unkind to the Attorney-General-which one journalist has described as an authority that does not have in some instances as much power as a policeman on a beat. I say, without going to the extremes of Senator Archer, that it is a toothless tiger. I believe it would not make any significant contribution to eroding the $700m or $800m profits per year that are now going to organised crime.

SPEECH.PARA: First of all, the Authority may not initiate inquiries, but may investigate only if a matter has been referred to it by the ministerial committee. Now arguments for this can sound very plausible. The Attorney could well say: 'Yes, but it does not have to be a total decision, it can be a majority decision'. Well, it can be, but then if we go to clause 9 we find that although a majority decision of the ministerial committee can investigate something, the reference may be stopped if one State concerned says that it is an offence against the law of that State. Therefore any State has a right of veto.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nonsense-only insofar as that State is concerned. Do not misrepresent it.

—Exactly. Let me take as an example my favourite State when I talk about the subject of organised crime-New South Wales. Let us assume that a majority decision is made by the ministerial committee to investigate something occurring in New South Wales involving organised crime. A majority decision is made; it is then referred to the Authority. That investigation can be vetoed by the Government or by the relevant Minister in New South Wales. I am not at all impressed with the arguments of the Attorney that most offences of organised crime are in the Commonwealth area. As has been pointed out, organised crime is notorious in areas such as prostitution, vice, gambling, those sorts of areas where they launder money-
—But how can the Commonwealth investigate those without State support?

—I am answering the Attorney's quite clear statement that most organised crime is in the area of Commonwealth offences. That is palpably not correct because a great majority of organised crime is in fact in the area of State offences and, indeed, relates to offences carrying a penalty of less than three years' imprisonment. That is the threshold over which one has to jump before the National Crime Authority is involved. References may not be made unless the committee is satisfied that ordinary police methods of investigation are not likely to be effective. In relation to this I quote the comments of Ms Wilkinson again. She makes some telling points:

SPEECH.PARA: The shackles on the authority do not end there. Before the committee of attorneys-general can refer anything to the NCA, the committee has to show that the offences cannot be handled effectively by existing law enforcement agencies.
How can this be established in the case of complex organised crime? This has yet to be explained by the Government.
What seems likely is that the State or Federal police commissioners would advise the Government on whether the offences should be referred to the NCA.
Two examples of how this might work come to mind. Last month, NSW Police Commissioner Cec Abbott--
I have stated in this House that he is an honourable, honest police commissioner -
reported to the NSW Government that a judicial inquiry into the allegations surrounding the early release of prisoners was not necessary. This followed a police investigation of the matter.
That was a New South Wales police investigation. Ms Wilkinson continues:

One month later, with a new police inquiry under way, the NSW Government was forced to refer allegations concerning the former Corrective Services Minister, Rex Jackson, and the early release of three prisoners, to the newly established NSW Special Commission of Inquiry.

On that very case a police commissioner said that no further investigation was necessary. But because someone stirred or someone sent more information, it resulted in the resignation of a senior Minister and a judicial inquiry into his activities.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would appear it arose because someone read the transcripts.

—I acknowledge Senator Chaney's interjection if he wants to get into the debate by hook or by crook against the wishes of his friend, the shadow Attorney-General. The article written by Marian Wilkinson continues:

SPEECH.PARA: Four years ago, the Victorian Police were asked by their Government if an inquiry into the Painters and Dockers Union was necessary.

The Victoria Police replied: 'No'. I stand by the Victoria Police. I believe that by and large it comprises an outstanding group of men and women. It has a supurb police commissioner and a fine record in fighting organised crime. The Victoria Police was asked whether everything was okay with the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. The article continued:
Under the new National Crime Authority, it is unlikely that crucial aspects of the bottom of the harbour tax frauds would have ever come to light.
For the record I will read this out. It is a fascinating story which could almost come from a Hadley Chase novel. The article continues:

Frank Costigan QC was asked three years ago to investigate the Painters and Dockers. Early in his inquiry, Costigan examined a phoney ship repairing company . Until then, he had stated, he had not seen any money transactions in his investigations above $5,000.
When Costigan examined the files of that ship repair company, to his surprise he found a cheque for $1.5m and an application to the Reserve Bank to bring into Australia $4.5m from Lebanon.

That same company had a bank account in another State. An examination of these records found that in three months $250m had passed through that account and it was only one of dozens of similar accounts around Australia.
Under the Attorney's legislation, if Mr Costigan wanted to pursue his investigation he would need the approval of every State government as well as the Attorney-General.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't talk rubbish. Don't talk absolute rubbish. You can do it with the informal co-operation in the way Costigan did. He had Victorian Letters Patent and Commonwealth Letters Patent.
—I am quoting from Ms Wilkinson--
—You are quoting from Ms Wilkinson, who has written her usual heap of rubbish, and you know it.

—I acknowledge Senator Gareth Evans's interjection to get it into the Hansard. Once again I disagree with him. I regard Ms Wilkinson as one of the most distinguished and fearless journalists who write about organised crime in this country. Thank goodness we do have people of the calibre of Marian Wilkinson writing such articles.

SPEECH.PARA: I assure the Senate that, like the Opposition, we have no desire to go on a witch hunt. Yesterday, when these matters were being discussed with the Attorney -General, he passed the Australian Democrats a note. It is not marked confidential. I ask the Attorney whether I have his authority to read it into Hansard?

TALK.START.PARA: —Try and stop you.
—The Attorney can stop me. If he says no, I will not read it.
—Go for your life.

—It would be helpful to the Attorney's career if he could learn some common courtesies. Sometimes his petulance overcomes the great ability that we all know he has. It does not do his career any good. The Attorney said:

SPEECH.PARA: I take it that in the event of any kind of committee referral motion proceeding , you would accept a limitation in the following terms:

The Committee shall confine its inquiry and report to the terms of the Bill and associated policy matters, and not receive any evidence, or conduct any investigation, related to any individual person or body.
Can you confirm?

I was very pleased to confirm that. I subsequently found out that the Attorney sent an identical note to Senator Durack, who acknowledged in the same way as the Australian Democrats. Senator Durack in his motion has used the exact words for which the Attorney asked. I know that he does not want this Bill referred to a committee, but at least he cannot claim that we are on a witch hunt, which I know was one of his worries. I acknowledge that it was a real worry. Give a bunch of politicians the chance to get stuck into another bunch of politicians, with a State election coming up and, as Senator Tate said, we have possible McCarthyism. I, as one who hopes to serve on that Committee, give that categorical guarantee. I know that under the chairmanship of Senator Tate and with the Liberal members of that Committee this will not happen.

I conclude by asking: What are the objections to referring this Bill to a Senate standing committee? Is it to be understood that the opponents of this proposal believe that all of the royal commissioners have nothing to contribute? Is that the proposition? At the crime summit that the Attorney held in this chamber-I thought it was an outstanding success, if only to the extent that once again it flushed out the petty mindedness of State politicians who apparently would rather see organised crime flourish than have their precious States' rights trodden on-each of the five royal commissioners-Mr Justice Moffitt, Mr Justice Williams, Mr Justice Woodward, Mr Justice Stewart and Mr Costigan-said that we needed a national commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —An effective one.

—Yes, an effective crime authority. These people had all the facilities of royal commissions at their disposal. They were virtually saying: ' Notwithstanding the powers with which we are clothed, we cannot do the job of uncovering crime. We need a national crimes commission'. If my memory serves me correctly, they certainly were in favour of one of the two models that the Attorney-General put forward, and they would have been appalled at the present Bill before the Senate.
—Have you asked any of them subsequently?
—No.
—Why don't you do that?

—I do not believe that it is my business, nor is it proper for me, as a senator, to be asking distinguished judges: 'What do you think of Gareth Evans's Bill?' If the Attorney-General thinks that that is a proper course, let him say so. I am saying that a Senate committee surely gives a dignified and proper vehicle for those royal commissioners to say: 'This Bill is too weak. This Bill is not effective. It will not do the job'. Or it would give them the opportunity of saying: 'This Bill is okay. This is what we want'. What is the Attorney-General worried about?
—The problem of constitutional power and the inability to do anything without State co-operation. Why don't you address that one point?
—I have already addressed it, and I have sympathised with the Attorney-General for the way in which he was mauled by those petty-minded State politicians.
—But you cannot do it in any other way. Tell me how to do it in another way and we will do it.

—With great respect, and with the admiration that I have for the Attorney-General, I am not yet prepared to acknowledge that he is an oracle. I am not yet prepared to acknowledge that he knows everything. I believe that the five royal commissioners could well have a contribution to make to improve this incredibly important legislation. We have been 83 years without a National Crimes Commission, unfortunately.
—We will be without one for another 83 years at this rate, because of the fundamental problems.

—I cannot believe that a delay of another five months so that we can get the best advice in the land from former royal commissioners and from commissioners of police would be wrong. If my memory serves me correctly, at the crime summit called by the Attorney-General there were several distinguished State police commissioners who were in favour of the two models that the Attorney-General put up-a quite different proposition from their State politicians.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion, perhaps I may express, more in sorrow than in anger, my disappointment with words that the Attorney-General--

TALK.START.PARA: —Spare us the sanctimony, for God's sake.

—The Attorney-General is a great user at times. Last week I paid him the courtesy of telling him that it was the Democrats' inclination to move this Bill to a standing committee of the Senate. He said: 'Please, will you make yourself available for discussion and comment?' I said: 'We are always prepared to do that'. Last Tuesday the Attorney-General was informed that we had come to a view that we would support a Liberal Party motion to refer this legislation to a committee. He rang me and said: 'Can you come and see the Prime Minister and myself, to discuss this?' I did so. They did not persuade me. They then said: ' Will you please allow the Attorney-General to meet your fellow senators in the morning?' I could easily have said that we had made up our mind-which we had-but I agreed to the meeting the next morning and admitted the Attorney-General into our party meeting.

SPEECH.PARA: In return for that sort of courtesy, which we have extended to the Attorney- General, this is what he says about us:
With a cooling-off period overnight, some of those Democrats who have been wobbling about all day will see a little bit more reason in this respect than they have so far.

We 'wobbled about all day'-to use his expression-at his request, to accommodate his new points of view, and to try to do the right thing by him. Yet he appears on national television and radio and makes comments such as those. I simply write that into the record to tell him, as a person for whom I have a high regard, that if he wants things to pass through this Senate, if he wants the co- operation of his colleagues of parties other than his own, perhaps showing a little courtesy in future might not go astray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-This has been a very good debate. The arguments for and against the motion that I have moved have been very well expressed. I am particularly grateful to Senator Chipp for his strong support on behalf of the Australian Democrats. I am pleased about that. I do not propose to canvass again those arguments which have been very well advanced, particularly from our side in the debate, in support of referring this important Bill to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. However, one or two matters have been raised with which I should deal.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Mason asked me to give assurances as to what the Opposition's object was in moving this reference. I thought that I had already made that clear in my speech in support of the motion. It is the Opposition's intention that the Committee should confine itself to the question of the Bill, the nature of the proposed National Crimes Authority, and its policy and effectiveness; and it is certainly not intended to be conducting a witchhunt against any person or any organisation, or anything else. That is not the object. The standing of the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee and its membership would be a clear assurance that that would not happen. Senator Chipp says that he has nominated himself, so he will probably be a member of the Committee. He has assured us of that. Senator Hill, a member of that Committee who has spoken in this debate, has said the same. Senator Lewis, another member of the Committee, has asked me to say that he gives that assurance. The other member, Senator Missen, has confirmed it, and we all know anyway, from his reputation, that he would not be engaged in that sort of thing. But to make assurance doubly sure, and as Senator Chipp has indicated, on the suggestion of the Attorney-General himself, the second--

TALK.START.PARA: —You had to be backed into a corner to get you there.

—That is a most offensive and totally untrue interjection. I am surprised at the Attorney-General. Both Senator Chipp and I readily agreed to this being put into the terms of reference. Even though it was not, in my view, within the terms of reference to the Committee-the standing of the Committee, the membership of the Committee, did not require it-we readily agreed to put that clause in to make assurance doubly sure on this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: The question has been raised by Senator Harradine and, somewhat obliquely I think, by Senator Tate, as to why we would refer a Bill to the Senate Committee at this stage and not later. The reason for that has been very well explained by Senator Chipp. It is simply that the object of this reference is that the Senate should be better informed when it comes to the second reading debate. There is a long and very honourable tradition in this Senate for that course of action to be taken. I mentioned what was done with the Freedom of Information Bill. That Bill was referred to a Committee at exactly the same stage. I introduced it in June 1978. It was referred to a Committtee before any second reading debate; before any debate on it at all, I believe. I see that Senator Missen is confirming my recollection. But Senator Tate said that I was referring to that precedent because I wanted some revenge. I reject that suggestion utterly. I am pleased to see him smiling and to note that he does not really seriously believe it. I am glad about that, because that is certainly not the case. I was referring to that as being a very distinguished precedent for what I am proposing here today.

Other major Bills such as the National Compensation Bill and the Family Law Bill were sent to Senate committees before the second reading debate. That is a very proper use indeed of the Senate standing committee system. As I said, one of the dangers of that course of action is the very long delay that sometimes occurs as a result of that proceeding. That is why we have put an early date for reporting in this reference. I hope that the Committee may be able to report at an even earlier date, but in order for the Committee to do the best job possible 30 April next year seemed to be a realistic date. It still gives the fullest opportunity for the Senate to pass this legislation in the autumn sittings, if the Committee reports that it is effective or that it can be made effective with certain amendments.

As to any delay that might be occasioned, I point out, as did Senator Chipp, that when the Government took office earlier this year the National Crimes Commission Act was ripe for proclamation. The Government chose to delay for eight or nine months while it brought forward legislation of its own. It is quite clear that the Attorney-General would have preferred a model rather more like the National Crimes Commission, and such a model was put forward in the Green Paper. The legislation has been steadily watered down over this period because of the various pressures and problems the Attorney has faced. I believe that it is a very suitable exercise for a standing committee of this Senate, and I trust that the Senate will agree with my motion and allow the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs to get on with the very constructive job which we all know it will do.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Durack's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: BILLS RETURNED FROM THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following Bills were returned from the House of Representatives without amendment and having been agreed to by an absolute majority:
Constitution Alteration (Advisory Jurisdiction of High Court) Bill 1983
Constitution Alteration (Interchange of Powers) Bill 1983
Constitution Alteration (Parliamentary Terms) Bill 1983
Constitution Alteration (Simultaneous Elections) Bill 1983
Constitution Alteration (Removal of Outmoded and Expended Provisions) Bill 1983
Message received from the House of Representatives intimating that it had agreed to the amendments made by the Senate to this Bill.
Consideration resumed from 15 November 1983.
Remainder of Bill-by leave-taken together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are still in the Committee stage of Appropriation Bill (No. 1). I would like to refer back to the debate which took place at the Committee stage on 15 November. During the course of that debate, according to Hansard, at 4.49 p.m. I raised with the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Walsh, who was then in charge of the Committee, a number of questions, which had already been put. I refer to the Hansard, where I said:

SPEECH.PARA: I should like to raise a matter with the Minister for Resources and Energy which is relevant to this matter and to other matters which are still before us but also relevant to matters which we have passed.

I referred to the fact that we had had extensive discussions and questions raised, and I sought from the Minister answers to those questions before we completed our consideration of the Appropriation Bill. There had been a discussion between the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, and me which was referred to at that time. Senator Walsh replied:

Senator Button spoke to me about this matter. I am not able to give a definitive answer about the Department of Trade. As I indicated at the time, I think a number of the answers to the questions asked would be regarded as being commercial in confidence information.
That related to specific inquiries about uranium. The Minister continued:

Concerning the Department of Resources and Energy, I think the answers should be available by mid-day tomorrow, or some time tomorrow afternoon, anyway. I think that that includes-I do not want to be absolutely held to this because I had a very quick conversation about it-the question Senator Peter Rae had asked about the latest estimates of the cost of power produced from quite small reactors, down to 200 megawatts.
In response, I then said:

Can we take it from that that there is no objection to that procedure-that we adjourn them for the moment, collect up the answers and then deal with them and complete the Bills after that information is to hand?
The Minister replied:
Yes, that is agreed.
I said:
Thank you.

There has been a series of contacts between my office and Senator Walsh's office and I acknowledge and indeed thank him for the series of responses which he has provided. He has provided some responses from the Department of Resources and Energy and the Department of Trade, and he has provided other responses from the Department of Veterans' Affairs. The information, insofar as it relates to matters which I have raised, appears to meet with the inquiries I have made. However, I am told that there are still matters outstanding which have been raised during the Committee debate. For example, Senator Peter Rae tells me that he has a number of outstanding inquiries. But at this stage I particularly want to refer to a matter which was raised by Senator Sir John Carrick and on which it is apparent to me that the Government could readily provide further and better information, but the indication I have had from Senator Walsh's office is that it does not intend to provide any further answer. I refer to page 2405 of the Senate Hansard. Senator Sir John Carrick said:

Throughout the debate on uranium-it has been implicit indeed it was implicit in the decision-making of the Australian Labor Party on Monday-that the government has made a decision based on very expert evidence that the world market for uranium is rigidly limited and will remain so, and that there is an upper ceiling that can be very clearly defined for Australia and, therefore, the Government must intervene and decide which mines shall operate and which mines shall not.

If that is so, quite clearly the Government must have in its possession precise projections as to what the accepted projection of world demand is for uranium, year by year, for the next 10 or 20 years. The Government must be able to indicate precisely what the demands of individual countries will be and precisely what the supply to meet that demand from individual countries will be. Otherwise the argument falls flat. How can the Government argue that it knows that markets are limited? This afternoon the Minister indicated that the Government did have such expertise. I challenged that and said that commerce and industry has a wider expertise. If the Government has this expertise, and if it is so arguing, I ask the Minister to provide to the Committee, in the next day or two, the precise details as to the world projections of demand by individual countries over the next decade or two and the world projection of the directionalism of supply, indicating therefore how the Government reaches the decision it does, that there be nothing more than whatever is the forecast-some 3,000 tonnes extra availability for Australia. I believe this is fundamental.

If I may put a slight gloss on the matter which was raised by Senator Sir John Carrick, uranium is slightly unusual with respect to estimates of future use because obviously the quantity of use for peaceful purposes is dictated by the number of power stations which are using uranium. The number of power stations is not something which is speedily variable and indeed there are projections as to what power stations will be in train to, I think, the year 2000. The capacity of those power stations is known and the fuel usage is known so we are in a situation where, better than with respect to most commodities, it is possible to estimate what future use will be. Obviously there are variables in any projection because demand for electricity varies as indeed it has varied over recent years from the projections of only a few years ago, because of the world economic downturn. We are dealing with a rather less elastic commodity in terms of usage than many others. Senator Walsh came back to the question raised. I refer to page 2411 of the Senate Hansard of 9 November, where Senator Walsh picked up the words of Senator Sir John Carrick. I quote the Minister, beginning with those words of Senator Sir John Carrick.
'The Government has asserted that it had precise knowledge of the state of the uranium market'.
Senator Walsh went on to say:

The Government of course has asserted no such thing. The Government has made a judgment on evidence provided from a variety of sources, importantly from the interdepartmental committee report on the likely commercial global demand for yellowcake from Australian sources. The Government has taken account of an admission-if that appears to be a loaded term I shall use another one-or a statement by Mr Grey, of all people, the Chairman of Pancontinental Mining Ltd, who acknowledged only last month that for the first time in very many years we were approaching a situation in which the production of yellowcake was likely to come to balance with consumption because for very many years production has been in excess of consumption and stockpiles have continued to accumulate. Mr Grey expressed the opinion that consumption and production were about to come into balance. We have also taken account of a statement by Mr Townsend of the Central Electricity Generating Board of the United Kingdom, that not until 1995 would the product of a new mine or new mines be required on the world market. But the Government has not asserted that it has precise knowledge.

What the Opposition seeks-it is clear from the passage which I read out from Senator Sir John Carrick that it is available to the Government-is an estimate of the likely commercial global demand for yellowcake from Australian sources. No doubt that is based on an estimate of the overall demand for uranium and then a sub-estimate of the extent to which it might be expected that Australia will supply that demand.

TALK.START.PARA: —Depending on a host of factors.

—Depending, of course, on a variety of factors. I will go back to the point I made a moment ago. The figure with respect to the likely total commercial usage of uranium for electricity generation is a figure which ought to be able to be calculated with some accuracy because of the relatively determined situation with respect to nuclear power stations, many of which are in operation, many of which are about to come into operation and a relatively small number of which are yet to be commenced. We believe the Government clearly would have access to some accurate figuring, or figuring which is based on facts which ought to be able to be put on the table because they would relate to the Government's information on the number of power stations, their capacity and their extent of fuel usage and the Government's estimates of the percentage of market that can be obtained. Since there has been an interdepartmental committee report, it is very likely, as any of us who have seen the products of those reports would know, that all of this has been reduced to the sort of neat bundle of information similar to the sort of stuff that was circulated by the Government to Caucus before the Caucus debate on uranium. In this case, however, it should be less judgment laden because one is dealing with some precisely ascertainable facts.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason we seek this information is quite clear. Very important policy decisions have been made by the Government which are, in part, based-if we are to have regard to the words of Senator Walsh in this place and elsewhere-on the Government's view of the commercial realities that face Australian producers. I think it is important, for the sake of an accurate public debate, that we have access to some of the factual information which is available to government so that we can have some way of assessing the accuracy of the information on which the Government has based its decisions and some guide which will help us who we are part of the debate and who represent part of the interests of the community, to make our own assessment of what the appropriate policy response will be. I think that in all respects this is a legitimate request. Clearly, because of the existence of the IDC report, we are not asking the Government to set off on a new information hunt. This is information which has already been gathered and put together in a form for absorption by those who sit on the other side of the chamber.

It seems to me that if we are to have a proper consideration of the Appropriation Bills, and if we are to take seriously the responsibilities of the Parliament in voting many billions of dollars for the services of the Government on behalf of the people of Australia, we are entitled to ask the Government-as we do at Estimates committee hearings and during the Committee's consideration of the Bills-the basis for the decisions that it has taken and the basis on which it is seeking appropriations of money to support and implement those decisions. It becomes slightly farcical if the matters which are raised can simply be put aside and not answered and the Committee be expected to deal with the appropriations in any event. I put the proposition to Senator Walsh originally that these were matters which should be dealt with before we considered the Appropriation Bills. As I read to the Committee a little while ago, at that stage Senator Walsh agreed to that proposition. Therefore, I believe it would be appropriate at this stage to ask the Government to respond to that inquiry before we take the matter any further.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak very briefly to give an example of another group of questions that were asked and that remain unanswered. The common ground is that the National Film Archive is in a very unsatisfactory state. I asked a number of questions about the arrangements for the National Film Archive. A decision has been promised by the Government. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) made an announcement that something would be done about the Archive. In order to make sense of that decision, when it comes up, it was important in the consideration of the Estimates to establish certain facts about the National Film Archive. I made a list of quite a number of questions, about 20-odd, of which I gave notice to the Minister concerned two days before the consideration of the Estimates began. The office of the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, Senator Ryan, was given a list of the questions. When the debate came on the Minister said she knew nothing about the questions, she was unable to answer them or to get answers for me. Today I sent around to her office to ask when the answers would be provided. Senator Ryan must have quite the most muddled and disorganised office in the whole Government, I think, by a wide margin. Her office said it knew nothing about the questions. If the Appropriation Bill is held up so that answers can be provided, and under that pressure there is still no intention or ability to provide them, what chance do we have of getting the answers after the Appropriation Bill has been passed?

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is highly proper that these answers be provided. It is an important issue. It is very important to many people. I know that it is a relatively minor issue in the scale of government operations. Nevertheless, it is important to many people who are concerned about the operation of the National Film Archive. Before the Committee is expected to pass these votes it should have the answers to questions of which proper notice has been given and for which answers have not yet been provided.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the benefit of the Minister for Industry and Commerce, Senator Button, I add to what was said so well by the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Chaney. The request for information on the world situation on the supply of and demand for uranium related not only to yellowcake but also to enriched uranium. That information was specifically sought, as Hansard will show, because on the same day the Chairman of the Uranium Enrichment Group of Australia put out a statement indicating that UEGA had come to a conclusion that there would be a market for enriched uranium, as distinct from yellowcake, in the 1990s and not before 1990. In order to ascertain the Government's policies it is necessary to establish the availablility of yellowcake in the 1990s in terms both of supply and demand. As Hansard shows, that information was sought.

—I still have not received answers to two matters which I would like to pursue. One relates to the Department of Administrative Services. I raised certain questions in relation to the allocation of a security contract, of which I gave the number. I asked whether the person who holds that contract is a fit and proper person, having been adequately checked out, to hold such a security contract. The other matter merely relates to the tabling of a document which the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, Senator Ryan, has made available to Senator Teague, Senator Peter Baume and me about bias in relation to the Australian scholastic aptitude test. At the time of the discussion the Minister said the document would be tabled and incorporated. I think that for those who follow the topic and who are very interested in it, and who may look at the Hansard, the document ought to be incorporated. As I say, copies of the document have been made available to us, but I do not think the record has been properly completed.
—Why don't you incorporate it if you are so keen to help?

—I do not have the document with me at the moment. The Minister said she would incorporate it. As it is an Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority document, I think it is more appropriate that she incorporate it.

—I too have not received answers to any of the questions I raised. I do not know whether the Minister for Social Security, Senator Grimes, intends to give them to me in the near future, but to date I have not had any replies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —While we are indicating the state of play, I point out that I have received from the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Walsh, information relating to a number of questions which I asked with regard to the comparative costs of nuclear energy, coal fired thermal, oil fired thermal and hydro-electricity. I assume that these answers will be incorporated in Hansard or in some other way put in the record. If this is not the Minister's intention, I will seek leave to do so because the reply confirms and further illustrates the points I have raised. I am delighted with the very full information which has been provided. I thank Senator Walsh and his Department both for the expedition with which they obtained the information and for the fullness of the information, which puts beyond any possible doubt the fact that, with the exception of the United States of America, nuclear power in every country which one can imagine from which one can obtain figures is appreciably cheaper-the trend lines are that it is becoming increasingly cheaper-than coal fired thermal and oil fired thermal. A detailed explanation is given in the information with regard to the problems of hydro-electricity costs.

SPEECH.PARA: However, I have not received an answer to a question I asked a week a go about the National Film Archive and the Corrick collection. There is a long history of correspondence and questions on this matter and I had hoped to receive an answer . However, information has not been provided as yet. I raised another matter in regard to estimates of the Department of Primary Industry with the proviso that the question would be passed on if it were regarded as coming within the responsibility of another department. The following information is provided in respect of matters raised by Senator Rae:
1. COMPARATIVE COSTS OF NUCLEAR POWER AND ELECTRICITY GENERATED FROM OTHER SOURCES

My Department has not been able to quickly identify each of the specific studies quoted by Senator Rae. However, in recent years there have been a number of comparative economic assessments of nuclear electricity with that generated from other sources. In general these have drawn conclusions similar to those quoted by Senator Rae ie that nuclear power has a significant cost advantage over competitive forms of electricity production, notably coal and oil (although in the US studies are showing that the long term cost advantage of nuclear coal has narrowed to the point that nuclear and coal are in a 'virtual deadheat' in most regions of the country).
Recent authoritative figures were published this year by the UK Central Electricity Generating Board (CEGB) as part of its statement of case for a pressurised water reactor at Sizewell (Sizewell B).

This study adopted three broad approaches to comparing costs; snapshot 1981-82, lifetime to date, and whole of lifespan. Within each of these, variants of the basic approach led to eight different bases of cost estimation being used. For the nuclear stations the costs included interest on stocks and full allowances for reprocessing spent fuel, radioactive waste disposal and decommissioning. The CEGB's coal fired stations were estimated to have a 40 year lifespan, oil fired stations 30 years.

The results show that nuclear has not been the cheapest option historically in the UK but is likely to be so in the future. Generation costs on a lifetime to date basis show that magnox reactors commissioned in the period 1965-1977 have been more expensive than coal fired stations. All appraisals show oil to be the dearest option.
The calculations for generation costs of possible future stations over whole of life time show that nuclear, whether PWR or AGR, has a significant edge, viz:
Coal fired plants-3.88 pence per kWh
Nuclear advanced gas cooled-3.15 pence per kWh
pressurised water-2.61 pence per kWh

The new coal stations do not assume any installations of flue gas desulphurisation plant which would add appreciably to the capital charges. The difference between the two nuclear options is mainly attributable to lower capital costs of the PWR and to a small degree by lower fuel costs.
Other recent studies the results of which the Department is aware include:

Forecasts by Electricite de France for the 1990s (this may be the French Study referred to by Senator Rae) which indicate the cost of a kilowatt-hour in 1981 francs produced by an EDF nuclear power plant coming on line in 1990 will be 16. 5 centimes, while for coal it will be 34.6 centimes and for oil (theoretically, since none is being built), 58.3 centimes. This would make nuclear power in 1990 only 48% of the price of coal power, and 28% of oil fired electricity. EDF attributes nuclear's advantage to a stabilisation of construction and investment costs while fossil fuel costs are rising. The analysis accounts for all nuclear fuel cycle costs including decommissioning.

A breakdown of the 1981 kilowatt-hour figures indicates that the 16.5 centimes for nuclear is composed of 8.9 centimes for investment costs, 3.2 centimes operating costs and 4.4 centimes fuel. Coal investment costs are 6.9 centimes, operating costs 3.2 centimes, fuel 21.5 centimes and anti-sulphur pollution devices 3 centimes. Oil fired station investment costs are 6 centimes, operating costs 2.9 centimes, fuel 45.7 centimes and anti pollution devices 3.7 centimes.
Estimates by the Japanese Institute of Energy Economics in 1982 indicate that in 1980 Japan was generating nuclear electricity for about half the cost of oil.

In the US the Department of Energy's Energy Information Administration has published a study focussing on new units beginning operation in 1995 which shows nuclear losing its cost advantage in the US. This study shows for capital costs alone, a nuclear plant beginning operation in 1996 would cost about $5.3 billion while coal burning plants would cost between $3.1 and $3.2 billion depending upon the type of coal. However, the cost of delivered fuel varies from region to region making nuclear much more attractive in the long term in New England, the Southeast and the far Northwest. In New England, for example, nuclear power is projected to have at least a 5% cost advantage while the balance tips the other way in the Southwest where coal is 26% to 28% below nuclear in overall costs.

A comparative study by Atomic Energy of Canada Ltd (designed to establish the superiority of the CANDU reactor system), whilst admitting that it is difficult to make meaningful international comparisons or nuclear power costs, compares nuclear to coal fired power costs in seven countries based on various cost studies in recent years. The Department considers that these conclusions should be treated with extreme caution. Of these, only the United Kingdom Magnox, USSR and French PWRs and Indian PHWR are based on operational reactor units.

Cost Comparison With Larger Reactors

There has been little published on the economics of modern small and medium sized power reactors. Two recent papers which have come to our attention, by Reiner Schmidt of the IAEA and Tor Pedersen of Asea-Atom Sweden, have estimated that a 600 MWe nuclear plant would cost approximately 65 per cent more per kW installed capacity than an equivalent 1,200 MWe plant. In turn a 200 MWe is estimated to cost between 50 per cent and 100 per cent more per kW than a 600 MWe plant.
3. Cost of Hydro-electricity in Japan

Although the cost of hydro-electricity in 1982 was estimated by MITI at 20 yen/ kWh and is thus well in excess of nuclear electricity at 12 yen/kWh, the two types of plant are used in different modes. Nuclear plant is used to supply base -load electricity while hydro-electric plant is used mainly for peaking purposes in a similar manner in which the Snowy Scheme complements the coal-fired base- load units of New South Wales and Victoria.

The capacity or utilisation factors of the hydro-electric plant are about half those for nuclear plant so that the capital charges are spread over fewer units of output. A more meaningful comparison of generating costs would be to compare hydro-electric generation with other common alternatives utilised for peaking purposes such as oil and distillate fired gas turbines, oil-fired steam plant and older smaller coal-fired plant for which the cost of generation would be expected to be well in excess of hydro-electric generation. As an example in Australia, the cost of production of electricty from old coal-fired plant for peaking purposes in New South Wales is typically between four and ten times that for base-load electricity from large modern coal-fired power stations.
4. Electricity Pricing in Australia

In recent years, the price of electricty has risen as a result of substantial rises in each of the three major components of the cost of production, namely fuel, operating and capital servicing costs.

The experience of the Electricity Commission of New South Wales (ECNSW) is illustrative of the situation which has affected all the electricity authorities to a greater or lesser extent. The ECNSW operates by far the largest electricity generation system in Australia which is based on coal-fired power stations supplemented by hydro-electric generation mainly from the Snowy Scheme.
Coal costs rose by 80% in real terms between 1976-77 and 1981-82 partly as a result of increasing dependence on more expensive underground coal and purchases from private mines.

After coal costs and leaving aside financing charges and non-cash costs eg depreciation, personnel costs are the next largest element of the Commission's costs. Between 1976-77 and 1981-82 personnel costs rose by an average of 4.8% per annum over and above the inflation rate.

Between 1976-77 and 1981-82, financing charges per unit of electricity sold increased by 84% in real terms as a result of an increase in the Commission's outstanding loans from about $900m in 1976-77 to over $2,000m in 1981-82 and an increase in the average interest rate from less than 8% in 1976-77 to over 12% in 1981-82.

Assets Test

Senator Messner asked how it was estimated that the assets test would save $ 300m in the Department of Veterans' Affairs since the Minister had said that only 3 per cent of people would lose their pensions.
The source of the $300m is not known. It was not the Department of Veterans' Affairs.

The Department does not have enough information about the asset holdings of pensioners to be able to estimate precisely the savings to accrue. This is because the present income test does not require full disclosure of asset holdings, only income obtained from assets. Nevertheless the Department of Veterans' Affairs does have sufficient information about a number of particular pensioners to know that they may be classed as ''wealthy'' by most standards and certainly have sufficient financial resources at their disposal to provide for their retirement without the need to rely on either the service pension or fringe benefits.
