I only offered a solution which might provide even greater expedition, because the honourable senator has said that she is concerned about not wasting time and about obtaining information. It was in that spirit that I made the offer, but if the honourable senator is not as concerned about that, I will ensure that she gets the answers.

SPEECH.PARA: Motion (by Senator Chaney) agreed to:
That the Committee report progress and seek leave to sit again.
Progress reported.

DEBATE.TITLE: EXCISE TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1983CUSTOMS TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1983CUSTOMS AND EXCISE AMENDMENT BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 16 November 1983.
Bills agreed to without amendment or requests.
Bills reported without amendment or requests; report adopted.
Bills (on motion by Senator Button) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 16 November 1983, on motion by Senator Button:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The States Grants (Petroleum Products) Amendment Bill proposes to amend the petroleum freight subsidy scheme in terms which were foreshadowed by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in his Budget Speech. Specifically, the Bill provides for the removal of power kerosene from eligibility for a subsidy, which is a long-standing subsidy designed to try to provide some equality of opportunity between those in the major urban areas, those closer to the centres of distillation and distribution, and those who are further afield, venturing and adventuring in various ways. Of course, the Northern Territory is also included under the Commonwealth Act. That formerly was an exceptional situation and I do not think there is any objection to that provision. The Bill specifies that delivery be a requirement which must be met before the subsidy payments are made. That provision follows an inquiry which was established last year under the former Government in relation to the operation of the scheme and is a recommendation that was made to make it more efficient.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill also provides authority to pay subsidy on eligible products to places which are not specified in the schedule to the scheme. As I mentioned, the Bill is the product of a review of the scheme which was announced last year, and I think it is important to trace through something of the history of the reviews which have taken place. Last year the former Government announced a review of the scheme. On 23 August this year the Minister for Industry and Commerce ( Senator Button) announced in a Press release:

The former Government initiated a review of this Scheme in last year's Budget because of concerns that the Scheme was being abused and costs were escalating. The conclusions of that review have led to the decisions announced by the Treasurer in his Budget Speech.
That included the decision to remove power kerosene, allegedly, and a number of other decisions which I will come to shortly.

When some objection was raised by sections who were adversely affected, in particular by sections of the fishing industry and, in particular again, by sections of the fishing industry involved in prawn fishing in northern Australia , the matter was allegedly reviewed again. Shortly before 1 November my colleague Senator Archer, who shortly will speak in more detail in relation to this aspect, received a telex from the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Kerin, which stated in part:

Following representations from the industry about the Budget decision which among other things excluded safe anchorage locations from the freight subsidy schedule, I have taken the matter up with my colleagues in the strongest possible terms in view of the financial difficulties confronting prawn fishermen .
Following a comprehensive review and the impact of the decision on safe anchorage locations the Government has decided that it must maintain the Budget decision.

So there we have the original review and the decisions taken in the Budget as a result of the review. Following objections and requests, a further review was undertaken and a further decision was taken by the Government after what is described there as a comprehensive review. In relation to this piece of legislation, we now have a further statement dated 15 November 1984 which, I presume, is not in anticipation of next year but is a mistake for 1983, which was made for the Minister for Industry and Commerce. It states:
However, the Minister for Industry and Commerce, Senator Button, who announced the decision today, said the extension was to enable a full review of the scheme to take place.

So apparently we will have a third review within 12 months. It will apparently relate to the problems of the fishing industry, particularly the prawn fishing industry and more particularly to the safe anchorage aspect, where fishing vessels are fuelled at sea and the subsidy should apply on the cost of transporting the fuel to where the fishing vessel is refuelled and not only to the port at which it can, if it calls, obtain fuel.

So what we have is a rather unclear and vague statement by the Department referring to an announcement by the Minister that we will have a further review of this scheme. Because the statement is about the fishing industry, the review will be primarily related to that, but it does not limit the review of the scheme to that. Perhaps we will hear tonight from the Minister for Industry and Commerce before this Bill is passed that the review will also include a review of others who have been hard hit by aspects of this legislation, including some of that relatively small group within the community which still uses power kerosene for various industrial purposes. The removal of power kerosene from eligibility for subsidy is estimated to save $100,000 in 1983-84. So perhaps in the course of this third review of the scheme we will have a review in relation to those people. For the sake of saving the cost of a review that $100,000 might as well be given to them to save the expenses which have been undertaken on so many occasions.

The Bill gives the impression that it is much like the 1983 Budget in so many aspects. It is ill-conceived and ill-considered. Once again we have a situation where the Government has made the big announcement, back-tracked on the big announcement, and will now review the review of the big announcement. One wonders with what certainty anyone can approach business in Australia, even living in Australia, when one has this sort of continuous review of a review of a review situation, when objection is taken by people who are hard hit. We had the pilots and the unions complaining about the superannuation decision. What did the Government do? It went off and played palsy-walsy with its union friends and then came back with some review of its firm resolute decision to take this country forward on a clear path. This is the sort of attitude the Government had when it announced the May mini-Budget. Then what did we find? It started back- tracking from the May mini-Budget. We then found the same sort of resolute leadership of Australia in the August Budget. What did we find then? People objected to it, so again the Government changed it around and reviewed it again. Why did it review it? Coincidentally, there happened to be a lot of prawn fishermen in the Northern Territory. Coincidentally there happens to be an election coming up in the Northern Territory. Coincidentally, the Government happens to announce that it will let the prawn fishermen have the benefit of the subsidy until the end of next year, when it will have reviewed the scheme.

One would not need to be very much of a cynic to think that there was some association with the sort of decision Mr Cohen will make, if somebody tells Mr Cohen what he is allowed to say, or somebody else will make in relation to Kakadu National Park and the $36m in tourism development funds that are supposed to assuage the anger of Northern Territorians for what has been done to them by this Government in relation to uranium development, Ayers Rock and various other things. There will be a whole series of these extremely convenient announcements by this Government of convenience which have nothing to do with economic management, nothing to do with making firm, clear, considered decisions and then sticking to them. Rather it will bounce around like a ping pong ball in a rough sea. It is cynicism unsurpassed. It is typical of this Government that when it wanted to pretend it was giving firm leadership it struck at those sections of the community it thought were most remote from it. It struck at primary industry , it struck at the people who were likely to be users of diesel in off- road conditions and it struck at those people who used power kerosene. It struck at all of the sections of the community it thought did not vote for it, and then it forgot one thing-the possibility that there might be a Northern Territory election. Then it thought: 'Oh dear, we had better do something about that'. So out it comes and it starts changing it all.

TALK.START.PARA: —They all live in Cairns, not in the Northern Territory.

—Strange as it may seem, as the honourable senator might hear from Senator Kilgariff and Senator Archer, both of whom will speak with great authority on this matter, there are a significant number of people in the Territory who are most concerned with the Government's decision in relation to this. I do not want to take up an undue length of time in covering the full detail. Let me say that this is just a further example of the incapacity of this Government to do anything about the creation of employment. It is a further impost on industry and it is a further impost on those sections of industry which are furthest from the Government. It is a further impost adding to inflation and it is a further inflationary factor which, along with indexation of excises, to which we have already referred in the preceding Bills, can have an effect which will only add to the inflationary pressures of Australia. It will do nothing to create employment. In fact, like so much of the rest of the legislation that has come before this chamber since this Government has been in power it does nothing to create the employment for which it was elected on the promise that it would create it. The employment that has been created, and the Bills that we have had in relation to employment creation, have all related to the things that the former Government did, connected to the wage pause. So with those comments, Mr Acting Deputy President, I move an amendment to the motion for the second reading of the Bill:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add:
', but the Senate-

(a) condemns the Government for the discriminatory imposition of extra fuel costs on industries already heavily disadvantaged, such as remote area fishing, pastoral, mining and farming activities; and

(b) calls upon the Government to review this legislation, with a view to ensuring that industries in remote areas will not be made worse off as a result of changes to the Petroleum Freight Subsidy Scheme'.

Notwithstanding the rather vague announcement made by the Department of Industry and Commerce, which was embargoed until midnight on Tuesday 15 November and which appears to be related to the fishing industry but may extend further, we seek to have a full review to ensure that those industries to which I have referred will not be further disadvantaged, so that in the course of the review that the Government is going to undertake-the third review of this scheme-it will endeavour to achieve that purpose.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking briefly to the States Grants (Petroleum Products) Amendment Bill 1983 I stand to support Senator Peter Rae who has given quite an able description of the problems that exist in this area. As I see it the purpose of the Bill is to remove power kerosene from eligibility for subsidy. This includes the Northern Territory under the Commonwealth Act and it specifies that delivery be a requirement which must be met before subsidy payments are made. It provides authority to pay subsidy on eligible products to places which are not specified in the schedule to the scheme. I suppose the one thing that affects most people, if not all people, in the outback in the Northern Territory these days is the cost of fuel. Perhaps the city dweller is not affected so much, but no matter what an individual in the outback does day by day, his first cost usually comes from transport.

SPEECH.PARA: Over the last few years incredible costs have been placed on the people in the outback, yet we hear on the other hand that the Territory, the outback, needs to be more densely populated, industry must be encouraged, northern development must be brought about and all these things. Now there is a person who is prepared to carry out this type of work, as can be seen. When one looks at the population of the Northern Territory now one sees that it is developing quite remarkably, at some three times the rate of the average population growth in Australia. This is despite all the heavy costs. Whether one is on the land or in the sea in the north, there are tremendous costs. Let us first of all look at the fishermen. Very many fishermen who have operated out of Darwin, out of Nhulunbuy and out of Groote Eylandt have gone out of business because of the high cost of fuel. I think it is a pity that we see these individual fishermen being put out of business. On the other hand we see these fishing arrangements being made with overseas countries with the result that many overseas trawlers come in and we see them in large numbers along the northern coast. Yet the people we want to have along the northern coast are the local fishermen but because of the various costs they are pushed out of business.

I believe that this applies to the people in the outback too, the people who depend on road transport such as farmers, station managers and all those other people. As I understand it now the 10,000-odd individual locations at which the subsidy is paid are to disappear and a retail point is going to be the point where this 1.1 cents per litre subsidy is to be paid above that. What is the definition of a retail site? Surely if the people are to have some understanding of the situation-indeed if we are to have some understanding-there must be an understanding of what this particular point, the retail site, is. I understand that part of the Budget statements of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) stated that the Government is moving the subsidy payable points to retail outlets. What is to happen then to the people who live past the retail outlets, to those very many people, whether they are on cattle stations, mining camps or Aboriginal settlements? How is the subsidy to be applied to all those people in the outback who live past the retail points? What is the rate of the subsidy? As far as I can see no procedures are established as yet to determine what rate of subsidy will apply to those current locations which are downstream from retail sites. This of course includes the outback stations and elements of the fishing industry.

This seems to be a hasty piece of legislation. It seems to be incomplete. How is the message to be given to the people as to what this is all about? Surely when one looks at the Bill one sees that it is incomplete. These procedures are important, so the Bill says, for outlying non-retail locations which would appear to be disadvantaged by the legislation. But I can think of very many people such as farmers, say along the Daly River, who are really scratching for a living. Gradually they are going under because of the high fuel costs. What can be said to those people? How does this Bill apply to them?

TALK.START.PARA: —You cannot say 'Use power kerosene', can you?

—As Senator Peter Rae points out, they cannot use power kerosene. For what reason is power kerosene removed from subsidy eligibility when one examines the savings to the Federal Government? Is it for the miserable amount the Federal Government will save? I cannot see the reason behind it. Even though it is said that very little power kerosene is used these days the fact, of course, is that power kerosene is used in the outback. Why should its users be penalised? I think it is up to the Minister for Industry and Commerce ( Senator Button) to give a clear indication of what this is all about. Perhaps he can spell out very clearly what advantage this measure will be to the people of the outback. Frankly, I am very concerned about the situation. I await the Minister's explanation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to speak to the States Grants ( Petroleum Products) Amendment Bill 1983. I will restrict my remarks to one particular aspect because I believe the rest of the Bill has been adequately covered by other senators in this debate. I would like to take the somewhat unusual course, I suppose, at this stage of making a short speech of thanks and congratulations. Since the Budget I have exerted as much influence as I can in an effort to reflect the absolute horror of safe anchorage users of diesel fuel in the fishing industry. Having spoken in this chamber about this matter on three occasions and having written letters, sent telegrams and so on to various Ministers, I am pleased that the general representations I have made all round have been recognised. Not many people in Canberra have any appreciation whatsoever of the vast distances or of the costs of non-fishing and non-earning steaming time that goes with the operation of trawlers in the north. I am talking about vessels for which the extra costs of fuel will amount to about $35 ,000 a year and where the safe anchorage alone might be as much as $5,000 to $8, 000 of that. In those cases the fuel actually represents about $2 a kilogram on the entire catch of fish.

SPEECH.PARA: It may have escaped the attention of some honourable senators but I am a great supporter of the owners and operators of the nearly 300 boats that are part of the overall $360m a year export fishing industry. I believe that the people in this industry should be given a little more consideration than they are getting. The old divide and conquer theory is alive and well when these fishermen are strewn about at sea and hardly ever get together to create problems. Every country tries to support vital export industries. Why does Australia not support this industry? What do we do to match the assistance given to Australia's competitors in world markets?

There have been several statements that the Government's Budget decisions have to be maintained. Even though some unkind people are thanking Mr Paul Everingham for the decision, I am not like that. I just thank the Minister for Industry and Commerce, Senator Button. I go a little further though. I note that the reprieve is provided until the end of 1984; I seek a declaration of permanence. The statement that I have seen alludes to abuses in the system. The Government has used that as a reason to cancel this subsidy. I too have heard that there may be abuses. However, my advice to this Government is the same as it was to the last Government, that is, do not blame and penalise the vast majority of honest people for the reputed miscreants that nobody seems to be worrying about anyway. I suggest that penalties should be sufficient to deter miscreants and that the rules, when implemented, should be implemented and carried through very solidly. I do not have any brief for crooks, if there are any, and their misdemeanours. If they are detected I would be the first to say to them: 'It serves you right; I would not wish it to be any other way'.

The northern prawn fishing industry earlier this year showed signs of an improvement in profitability. The fishermen welcomed the devaluation of the dollar which it was thought would make the industry more competitive. The market looked quite good. However, regrettably, since then the situation has faded very badly. Over the last six months world prawn prices have dropped from about $14 a kilogram in April to $8 a kilogram in September; the value of the Australian dollar is now higher than it was in March; there has been an increase in fuel costs, irrespective of the safe anchorage question; there have been extra costs in wages and wage related costs which are estimated at about 6 1/2 per cent, and there have been reductions in the export incentives, besides the other matters contained in the Budget.

That is all, of course, in addition to the loss of the safe anchorage allowances that the fishermen were receiving. The safe anchorage scheme was instituted only in 1979. It was not implemented to provide any great advantage but to remove some of the disadvantages that the sea fleet suffers. In 1979 it covered costs based on Karumba. In 1980 it was extended to Darwin. In 1981, 13 other anchorage locations were used by fishermen in the north. The six big companies that make up the Northern Fisheries Companies Association themselves use about 50 million litres of fuel a year. Of this amount, 33 million litres are actually delivered at sea. Safe anchorage fuelling is, of course, an integral part of the industry. It represents much of the net profit for these sorts of fishermen.

I am not making this appeal for 1983 but for the long term future of this very valuable, potentially long-term export industry. These people are responsible, hard-working Australians. They are producing export dollars and not asking for benefits. They are simply seeking continuity and stability so that they may proceed to tidy up and rationalise the whole industry for the good of the industry itself and for the good of the resource. Again, I appeal to the Minister in relation to the safe anchorage allowance. The safe anchorage scheme is a must. It is up to the Government to ensure that it works. I never want to hear any talk of its cancellation on the basis that either the Petroleum Products Pricing Authority does not like it or because of alleged abuses. The present decision is most welcome. It is nice to be able to get some credit occasionally for actions, such as those which have been taken in this instance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank those honourable senators who have commented on the States Grants (Petroleum Products) Amendment Bill 1983. Any honourable senator who attributes any change I announced last week in the application of the Government's decision in the Budget on the petroleum freight subsidy scheme to Paul Everingham or anybody of that kind is indulging in charity and fantasy. Let me be quite frank about it: The Government has had representations made to it on this matter since the Budget was introduced. Representations have been made by Mr Gayler, the honourable member for Leichhardt; fishing organisations in Queensland, not in the Northern Territory; and Senator Boswell who is sitting opposite, together with fishermen from Queensland, not the Northern Territory. The Government took a number of factors into account which led to the announcement that I made in the Press release which has been quoted. Those considerations were very much of the kind Senator Archer mentioned in his speech-the increased costs being incurred by the industry, poor prices, the revised estimates of the costs of each boat that were being incurred, the very real need for a management scheme to be put in place in respect of the northern prawn fleets and the desire of the Government to get that in place with the greatest degree of consultation and co- operation with the fishermen concerned and so on. All these factors were taken into account.

SPEECH.PARA: Some people have taken the terminology of the Press release which was put out on 15 November as meaning that that foreshadows a review of the whole petroleum freight subsidy scheme. The expression in the Press release which has been quoted relates to a review of the mechanisms for supplying diesel fuel to the fishing vessels in the prawn fishing areas. At the time of the Budget, the Government said that it was very difficult to administer the petroleum freight subsidy scheme in relation to a number of areas. I do not know whether the farm gate issue has been mentioned in the course of the debate, but when the Government looked at this matter it found that there were some 10,000 farm gate sites in Australia to which the subsidy scheme applied. That number was growing very rapidly and creating enormous administrative difficulties. It was almost impossible to police the application of the scheme to the fishing fleet.

This Government has reponsibilities, as have all governments, in respect of the taxpayers as well as responsibilities towards particular industries and sections of the community. I say to Senator Archer that I do not know whether the difficulties of administering the scheme led to so-called rorts. I do not know of my own knowledge. I know that many fishermen have told me that it led to rorts. Senator Boswell knows that, too. A lot of fishermen have told me that they have seen diesel fuel being pumped out of a tanker vessel in Cairns Harbour into a fishing vessel alongside, and that the petroleum freight subsidy has been blamed for that. I am not able to state the precise distance from the shore that that operation was said to take place. But those sorts of administrative difficulties are there, and the interesting thing is that they are acknowledged by the fishermen.

TALK.START.PARA: —And they can be solved by the fishermen.

—And they can be solved by the fishermen in consultation with the Government. By the end of 1984, which is the extension period which has been provided, we hope to have solved those problems, because there is no point in taking this measure otherwise and a government cannot provide a system of particular assistance to a particular industry when it knows that malpractices are taking place. It is in order to correct those malpractices that the extension of time has been granted.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Kilgariff raised the question of the use of power kerosene. The Government considered this matter at some length at the time of the Budget. The use of power kerosene is minimal. The cost of administering the petroleum freight subsidy in respect of that item was becoming absurd in the light of the very minimal use of the fuel. Senator Kilgariff also asked what a retail site is . Without wishing to be kept to this as the definitive explanation of what a retail site is, perhaps I can say that it is to be regarded as a site where there is dispensing equipment approved by an appropriate State or Territory government or a statutory authority and where that equipment is installed for sale of eligible products to the public.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that the equipment approved or the site approved?
—The site is approved, as I understand it, not the equipment.
—Not necessarily an oil company retail point.

—Not necessarily, no. I think I am correct in saying that there are retail sites, for example, at Gove. I think there is a retail site under the scheme which is not an oil company site. So it means an approved site for the purposes which I mentioned.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Kilgariff was not present at one point earlier, let me say that if there was one consideration that was not taken into account in the Government's change in relation to the prawn fishing fleet, it was-believe me or not-the Northern Territory election. A whole range of other factors were taken into account. The imposition of the Budget decision suddenly and without further opportunity for consultation about means of getting rid of malpractices was the main reason for that decision.

I took Senator Peter Rae to be concerned about the question whether the review referred to in the Press statement meant a full scale review. The expression as it is contained in the Press statement relates to the review of the safe anchorages situation only.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you.

—But I do not wish to be taken, by saying that, as implying that the Government would be precluded from having a review of the whole scheme, because that is always something which a government has to keep within its contemplation about any scheme. In answering the question in that way, I am not saying that the Government will not be making any review at all of the scheme; but that is not currently in contemplation.

SPEECH.PARA: I should make the point, in answer to Senator Kilgariff, that the press statement refers to the fact that the Government will continue to review subsidy rates to remove anomalies between locations near each other and to examine rates for very remote farms or isolated communities where the rate applicable at the nearest retail site may not be appropriate. That is to say that the question of the extremely remote farms has been taken into account in an administrative way and will continue to be taken into account.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will always be difficult but it will never be impossible.
—I thank Senator Archer for those immortal words. The Government is prepared to confront the difficulties. Having said that, I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the second reading motion was carried , I had moved an amendment to it, which I now reiterate:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add:
'', but the Senate-

(a) condemns the Government for the discriminatory imposition of extra fuel costs on industries already heavily disadvantaged, such as remote area fishing, pastoral, mining and farming activities; and

(b) calls upon the Government to review this legislation, with a view to ensuring that industries in remote areas will not be made worse off as a result of changes to the Petroleum Freight Subsidy Scheme''.

The question on that amendment was put. The Opposition-that is, the National Party of Australia together with the Liberal Party of Australia-voted in favour of that. In other words, members of those parties were here to be counted, to stand up for the people of the outback of Australia, the disadvantaged people, the people in the outlying areas, the people who will be hit by this change. But there were no representatives of the Australian Democrats and no independent senator here to support the amendment. For that reason I did not seek to have a division in relation to it. I did not want unnecessarily to waste time, but I am disappointed that they were not prepared to support it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do not confuse the issue. You thought you would lose.

—I did not wish to have a division which, if they did not support the amendment, we would lose and thus waste time. I take this opportunity to point out those facts of life. We still reiterate that we think that the Government's action will disadvantage people who are already disadvantaged.

—I wish to speak briefly to the point just made by Senator Rae. Senator Rae has expressed his feelings and the Australian Democrats feel the same. In fact, I am a little disappointed that the matter did not go to a division so we could have a very clear expression of this Senate's opinion on that matter. I would like it recorded in Hansard that the wholehearted support of the Australian Democrats is with the Opposition and the amendment as it was suggested.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of the indication just received from Senator Jack Evans on behalf of the Australian Democrats, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That in reporting the consideration of the Bill by the Committee, the Chairman report that the Committee-

(a) condemns the Government for the discriminatory imposition of extra fuel costs on industries already heavily disadvantaged, such as remote area fishing, pastoral, mining and farming activities; and

(b) calls upon the Government to review this legislation, with a view to ensuring that industries in remote areas will not be made worse off as a result of changes to the Petroleum Freight Subsidy Scheme.
I thank the Democrats for their indication of support for that amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Rae gave a warm and emotional display on behalf of the disadvantaged, which I was pleased to note and acknowledge. I understand that. Senator Jack Evans also expressed the feelings of the Australian Democrats on this matter. But I really feel that those matters are all now recorded in Hansard. We know how the Liberals and the Democrats feel and, of course, it has been indicated in the course of the whole discussion arising from the Budget that they are concerned about particular matters. Of course, that is likely to be the normal course of events. I just indicate that the Government will not support the motion, because I think it is a sort of debating trick to have three bites at the cherry. It is a most cynical exercise. Essentially, the exercise is this: 'We saw the numbers as not being here, so it was not terribly important. We were not prepared to have a division. We were not prepared to display our feelings to the extent that they were recorded in Hansard with the numbers against us.' Now, because of the fortuitous arrival of Senator Jack Evans-I hope he has his friends here- who expressed his sentiments about the matter, there is a quite cynical attempt to get this motion resurrected, as it were, although the feelings have been amply displayed. If people say that this place is about argument, as distinct from numbers, it will come strangely from Senator Rae in the future if that is his view, and if he seeks this rather specious resort to this kind of motion in the Committee stage of debate on legislation.

—Senator Peter Rae, before calling you, if you wish to speak, could I suggest that I put the question 'that the Bill stand as printed'? The next question would be that the Bill be reported. If you wish to pursue your motion you could move it as an amendment to the question ' that the Bill be reported without amendment'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: -No, but I thank you, Mr Chairman. The point has been amply made that representatives of a majority of the chamber hold the view--
—And acknowledged, Senator.

—It has been acknowledged by the Government. I take it that the Government will bear that in mind in conducting the review. Therefore, I do not propose to pursue the matter further. Having received acknowledgment that a majority of senators support this view, and an acknowledgment from the Government that it will take it into account, nothing more would be achieved by putting the motion to a division.
—Senator Rae, do you wish to withdraw your motion, by leave?
—I seek leave to withdraw the motion.

SPEECH.PARA: Motion-by leave-withdrawn.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Button) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 16 November 1983, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Representation Bill is the first Bill to come before the Senate of a package of three Bills dealing with electoral matters. The Representation Bill is certainly the shortest and, one might think, the simplest of those three Bills, but it has given rise to considerable argument and public debate. The Bill, though short, is not without significance. I indicate that the Liberal Party will vote against this Bill for reasons which I will set out. The Liberal Party does not support the Bill and does not believe that its enactment would be in the best interests of democratic practice or parliamentary representation in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill seeks to do two things: It seeks to repeal and replace the two existing Representation Acts. Some of the provisions of the existing Representation Acts, I believe, are reappearing in the Electoral Bill which we will discuss tomorrow. At any event, the important thing is that the Act which is proposed to replace the Representation Acts, contained in this Representation Bill, will seek to increase the size of the Parliament by increasing the number of senators representing each State. Honourable senators will be aware that the size of the Parliament is determined by the size of the Senate and that the number of the House of Representatives can be no greater than twice the number of senators. Honourable senators will also be aware that an attempt has been made previously to alter this situation, to break this constitutional nexus which relates the number of members of the House to the number of senators. They will be aware that although my State of New South Wales voted in favour of that proposal in a referendum, it was the only State that did so, and the proposal was defeated quite resoundingly. The people of Australia at that time voted against breaking the nexus.

I think it is fair to say that they did so not on any well considered or deep constitutional arguments; they did it simply because they did not like the idea of more politicians. It was put to them that breaking the nexus would make it simpler to increase the number of politicians in Canberra. It was on that basis that the no case had such a resounding victory.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you adopting that as a persuasive reason against the legislation?

—I am merely relating what I believe to have been the thinking behind the rejection by the people some years ago of a referendum proposal which was put to them. This new Bill, if enacted, would have the dual effect of repealing the existing Representation Acts and putting in their place this new Bill which would increase the number of senators for each State. Members of the Liberal Party do not believe that increasing the number of senators is desirable. We do not believe that it is in the best interests of the Senate. We do not believe, therefore, that it is in the best interests of parliamentary practice in Australia, and for those reasons we will oppose it. There are really two sets of questions that need to be answered. The first is covered by the question: What are the reasons for saying that it is necessary to increase the size of the Parliament? That, of course, divides into further questions, including the reasons which would lead one to consider that it is necessary to increase the size of the Senate in particular. The second group is covered by the question: What would be the consequences of this proposal if it were put into effect?

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators will be aware of the first report of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform which was tabled in the Parliament I think in September. It was a mammoth work which represented the findings of a bipartisan committee which worked in Canberra throughout the winter and considered a large number of matters relating to electoral practice in Australia. It was a bipartisan committee representing all groups within the Parliament, except Senator Harradine, and on many, though not all, of the recommendations the Committee was unanimous. One of the areas in which it was not unanimous is the area before us now, the question of the size of the Parliament. Arguments have been put that it is necessary to increase the size of the parliament because it has not been increased for a long time, because the population has increased, and because each parliamentarian has to service a larger number of electors than he or she had to do in years gone by. From that basic argument people have developed a case for it being necessary to increase the size of the Parliament.

However, there are other arguments, and I draw the attention of the Senate to the dissenting opinion expressed by my colleague Senator Sir John Carrick at page 235 of the report of the Joint Select Committee. Senator Sir John Carrick, in a fairly brief dissenting report, dealt with some of the problems which he sees this question raising. He made the point that evidence to the Committee was that if there was to be an enlarged Parliament steps needed to be taken soon because in the normal course of events the 1984 redistribution was likely to prevail for two parliamentary terms. Whether the term is six years or seven years only the electors of Australia will tell us. The redistribution lasting for two terms may mean that if we do not increase the size of the Parliament the electorate will be even larger and that members of parliament will have even greater representational duties. Senator Sir John Carrick went on to acknowledge that many of the arguments for an increased Parliament are cogent. He acknowledged that the increase in population increases the demands upon parliamentarians, which the Joint Select Committee actually sets out in some detail. Those demands have become more complex. He acknowledged, as does the Joint Committee, the increasing complexity of parliamentary practice and parliamentary life in Australia.

All of these matters are acknowledged, but they do not represent the totality of the argument. The fact that the community puts enormous demands upon its parliamentarians, its politicians, and that it demands the personal attention and presence of politicians is also acknowledged. A number of questions raised by Sir John Carrick and set out in his dissenting report are questions which should engage the attention of the Senate in considering this matter. The questions are these:
Is there justification for a larger Senate, whether to fulfil its evolving responsibilities or simply to enable the enlargment of the House of Representatives?

Can I draw a distinction here. There are arguments for increasing the size of the Senate which have to do with the Senate and its functions-I have yet to see or comprehend or be influenced by arguments of that kind-and there are arguments for increasing the size of the Senate which relate not to the function or practice of the Senate but merely to the desire to increase the number of members of the House of Representatives who may be elected. Senator Sir John Carrick goes on to ask whether a Senate of 72 members, plus territorial senators -that will be of interest to Senator Robertson--

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Button

TALK.START.PARA: —Provincial senators.

INTERJECT.PARA: Seantor PETER BAUME-I am shocked to hear the Leader of the Government say that. I think they are full senators representing the Territories. Senator Sir John Carrick asks whether that is a workable figure, or would it incline to deadlocks . That is the question posed by Senator Sir John Carrick. Would it incline-for reasons which I will set out, and which are known to many senators-to three-all votes? Would it incline to the major parties each winning three seats of the six to be filled in most half-Senate elections? There would be 12 senators; six would go out for each half-Senate election. If this proposal tended to produce three-all situations as a routine we may end up with an unworkable Senate. This is an important and valid question raised by Senator Sir John Carrick, and one which must be dealt with by anyone who supports this particular enlargement. I recall that in 1948 or 1949 when the size of the Senate was increased, care was taken to make the increase for each State not from six senators per State to eight, which would have produced all the same problems we are facing now, but to make the increase from six senators to 10 senators. Because the half-Senate number then was an odd number they avoided the problems which are likely to arise whenever we have eight or 12 or 16 senators from a State. The likelihood is that, because of the way the voting is structured and because of the quotas which are established, with 12 senators per State, six going out at a half- Senate election, we might well tend towards three-all results.

Another question raised by Senator Sir John Carrick is whether it would make it easier or more difficult for minority groups, who nevertheless represent significant minority views in the community, to gain a place in the Parliament? My view is that it is much less likely that we would have, for example, the Australian Democrat presence in the Senate in anything like the same numbers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you complaining?

—I respond to Senator Button's interjection by saying that there are occasions when one has to balance the crude desires of party advantage with some wider public considerations. I say to Senator Button that I think there is some public support for the Senate's present position, where neither of the major parties has a guaranteed majority, where events in the Senate are argued out. While the fire and thunder may take place in the House of Representatives, all votes there are predetermined and absolutely predictable. Of course, one of the reasons there is no shouting and yelling in the Senate is that the votes are real and have a chance of altering what goes on. So there is some public support for a position in which the Senate is a real chamber of decision and where, as we saw today, one cannot predict with certainty that results will go one way or the other. Arguments on the floor of the Senate actually influences the result of votes. In parliamentary terms there is some advantage in having several groupings within the Senate, and there is a strong argument that says that will be less likely if we move to a position of having 12 senators per State. Senator Sir John Carrick went on to ask:

SPEECH.PARA: Would the public now support the breaking of the nexus between the two Chambers ?

That is a very important question, and one to which honourable senators will wish to address themselves. If the public would support the breaking of the nexus then this Bill is unnecessary. That is the wrong way to proceed. If there is a desire and a need to increase the numbers in the House of Representatives there may be an alternative means by which this can be done.
Debate interrupted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Criticism of the Northern Territory-Criticism of Tasmania

PROCTEXT.PARA: Criticism of the Northern Territory-Criticism of Tasmania

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 7.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not normally make a practice of speaking on the adjournment debate, but I feel impelled to do so tonight, very briefly, to refer to the latest example of the anti-Northern Territory stance of one of our major newspapers, the Australian Financial Review. Honourable senators will recall that over a number of years articles have appeared which were critical of the Northern Territory. The one I wish to refer to tonight is contained in the 16 November 1983 issue called 'Territory blues'. I seek leave to have that article incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The article read as follows-

The Northern Territory Government has called a snap election in the hope of capitalising on the inevitable unpopularity that recent Federal Government decisions affecting the Northern Territory will involve. They may very well benefit from popular reaction against these decisions.
The question is, as Mr Everingham, the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory has said, one of self-government. But he assumes that the Northern Territory has the right to self-government. Why?

The N.T. is not an original State in the Australian Federation. It is a tiny collection of people, most of whom subsist in the Territory only because of the generosity of the rest of Australia. The N.T. is heavily subsidised on almost every count and exists in its present form mainly because of the wave of popular sympathy that followed the cyclone of Christmas 1974.

The cyclone, which devastated Darwin, was a heaven sent opportunity to reduce Darwin to its proper function, a small port at the central-northern extremity of Australia serving a few military installations and a tiny hinterland. Instead the mistake was made of trying to develop Darwin, and the N.T., into an independent entity. The present population of Darwin, including most of the members of its parliament, are carpet-baggers, arrivals who followed the influx of funds after the cyclone.

The residents of Darwin who precede the cyclone are a minority of the present population. The same is true in varying degrees of the other towns of the N.T.. It is a dependent area, in which the only long term residents are a few whites and a few blacks of much longer ancestry and claim.

This is not to say that attention should not be paid to the N.T.'s welfare. But it ought to put in doubt the validity of the claims of the new rich of the N.T. to still further assistance from the Australian Commonwealth, while they claim the right to act independently of and contrary to Australian Commonwealth Government policy.

The three great offences of the Hawke Government against the NT, as perceived by the NT Government, are: first, the decision not to go ahead unconditionally with the rail link to Darwin; second, the decision to prefer uranium development in South Australia to uranium development in the NT; and third, the decision to hand over the Uluru national park, including Ayers Rock, to the Aboriginal inhabitants of the area.

The first of these decisions was simply a concession to reality. The Darwin rail link could never be justified on economic grounds. It would simply subsidise freight and passenger traffic, which could be better met in other ways . In short, it was one of the proposals of the previous Government which would have involved an unconscionable waste of Australian taxpayers' funds.

The second is more open to criticism. The preference for Roxby Downs against other uranium mines involves a waste of resources, in that it involves the choice of a relatively high cost uranium mine as against relatively low cost mines-there is a huge implicit subsidy to jobs in South Australia which should be questioned. Why are South Australian jobs worth more than NT jobs?

However, the decision was made in the form it was for reasons connected with the internal conflicts of the Labor Party, and the prejudices of white anti- uranium activists formed regardless of the interests of the Aboriginal residents of the NT who hoped to benefit from the development of uranium mines in their lands. It is a classical piece of racist patronising of the Aborigines: if they are to be granted land rights why should they not have the right to decide that those land rights include the royalties from the mining and export of uranium?

The third decision is that Ayers Rock should be handed over to the appropriate Aboriginal authorities. This one is contestable. Ayers Rock is as much a symbol of Australia in its present multiracial, multiethnic existence as it is of the original Aboriginal inhabitants. Both the existing Australian society and the original inhabitants deserve to be consulted on this matter.

But if the action was more than a one sided piece of patronisation by the Federal Government, and if the Aboriginal inhabitants are in fact committed to the maintenance of access to the Rock and its related surroundings, then the only harm done is a massive transfer of revenues from NT and federal authorities to Aboriginal land councils. How those funds are expended is another question but not a small one.

It is clear that the NT Government is going to present each of these three decisions as being an offence to the residents of the NT. The railway decision can be represented as depriving all of the facility to which they think they ought to be entitled, regardless of the fact that every man, woman and child, regardless of race and colour, in the NT is already a pensioner of the Australian nation.
The uranium decision can certainly be presented to the Aborigines as an interference in their rights and revenues. After that why should they vote Labor ?

The Ayers Rock decision will outrage the white citizens of Alice Springs and related towns such as Katherine, who see a similar fate looming over them. So the Federal Government might well have succeeded in uniting all the voters of the NT, white or black, to vote for Mr Everingham's Government.

After December 3, therefore, the fundamental issues will loom large once again. Do we need a pretentious local government in the NT, and should we continue to subsidise people to live there? Perhaps the solution will be to revert to pre- cyclone policies.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I sought leave to incorporate the document, firstly, to save time. It is necessary for the article to be incorporated to make the comments which I intend to make more meaningful. Secondly, it will enable people to fully appreciate the paranoia of the writer who penned the article to which I refer. I am told that the writer is a Mr Paddy McGuinness, who holds an editorial position on the Australian Financial Review. I am assured that this is his style. Certainly, the article itself is long on generalisations and short on facts. If that is his style, it certainly fits. In the second paragraph of the article this statement appears:

SPEECH.PARA: The question is, as Mr Everingham, the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory has said, one of self-government. But he assumes that the Northern Territory has the right to self-government. Why?

It seems the author finds it incredible that the Northern Territory should feel it has the right to self-government. He seems to feel that there is a certain impertinence on the part of the Northern Territory citizens, people who are of course citizens of Australia, that they should want to have the right to self- government. The arguments which he put against self-government were: Firstly, that it is not an original State. Of course, this is indisputable, but one would question the relevance of the argument. Certainly, the Constitution anticipated new States and made arrangements for them. Australian citizens, wherever they are geographically located, are entitled to expect self-government if they want it. I appreciate the proposition that the Australian Capital Territory poses a particular case which could be debated. I am speaking of the Northern Territory at the moment where the same conditions do not apply. The second point he made was that the Northern Territory is heavily subsidised. That is true. Certainly, it has been commented on; I have commented on it in this place. But what is so unusual about a mendicant State? Which of the States have not been mendicant at some time? Apart from New South Wales, most of the smaller States have been mendicant, at one time or another, since Federation. The taxpayers in the Northern Territory-they are just that, taxpayers, in the full sense of the word- pay their taxes the same as every other citizen of Australia. I might even put an aside here that they pay an additional tax in that they were required, until very recently, to pay sales tax on freight.

The next comment made was that the Northern Territory exists in its present form because of the wave of sympathy that followed Christmas 1974. He was referring, of course, to the cyclone of 1974. I do not know quite what the author meant by the phrase 'present form'. If it was the physical reference that he was making then certainly Darwin has been rebuilt, but it was rebuilt because of the Labor Government in Canberra at the time of the cyclone. The then Labor Government laid the foundations and started the process going. To the credit of the following government, this was continued. If the author was talking about the parliamentary system of the Northern Territory, once again, this was due to the initiative of the Labor Government, followed, commendably, by the Country- Liberal Party. If he was referring to the mendicant situation, due to the size of the Territory and its small population, it is simply the same as any other State in its early development. The article goes on to say:

The cyclone . . . was a heaven sent opportunity to reduce Darwin to its proper function, a small port at the central-northern extremity of Australia serving a few military installations and a tiny hinterland.
The area to which he referred as a tiny hinterland, I assume, is one in which the author's own State would fit more than once.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has places such as Jabiluka and all those sorts of potential developments, hasn't it?

—That is right. I appreciate the honourable senator's contribution. There was no mention of those things and things such as the cattle industry, mining and some of the most attractive country in Australia. There was no mention of the gateway to the north which is supposed to be so valuable and certainly has attracted so many writers. The article goes on:

SPEECH.PARA: The present population of Darwin, including most of the members of its parliament, are carpet-baggers, arrivals who followed the influx of funds after the cyclone.

It is not surprising that the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, Mr Everingham, called the author an ignoramus. I do not want to use such a harsh term, but I wonder from where he obtained his figures. The figures normally cited are that 60 per cent of the present population was there before cyclone Tracy. These figures are derived from the obvious comment that 40 per cent of those who left did not return. But the author was talking about the politicians. As far as I know, all the politicians are pre-cyclone. I cannot think of one who is not. At least two of them were born locally. They would have been there for some years. All the Federal representatives have been in the Territory for a long time, certainly well before the cyclone. But so what? What relevance has this comment to what we are talking about?

TALK.START.PARA: —No member of parliament in Tasmania is Tasmanian born. I am talking about the State Parliament, not Federal members.

—Perhaps the Ministers can make something of that in a later speech. Too much is made of this nonsense. It is the contribution that counts. Whether the person comes from Tasmania or the Northern Territory it is his contribution which is important. The article went on:

SPEECH.PARA: The residents of Darwin who precede the cyclone are a minority of the present population. The same is true in varying degrees of the other towns of the Northern Territory.

This is just not true. It is typical journalistic licence and falls into the 'do not spoil a good story' syndrome. The author then went on to talk about the Darwin-Alice Springs rail link. He called it the proposal of the previous Government. He did not indicate which government-which government from 1911, all of which indicated that something might happen to the Darwin-Alice Springs rail link. It certainly was not the Fraser Government. The Fraser Government promised several times that it would do something about the rail link, but I do not think it had any intention of keeping that promise. Certainly, nobody gave any significance to the promise which was made.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a bit unfair, isn't it?
—I suggest that the facts do speak for themselves. It was promised four times.
—That they had no intention of keeping it?

—One would think so, since they did so four times, had opportunities to do so and did nothing about it. The honourable senator's Government initiated no footage of railway, let alone mileage of railway, in Australia. Therefore, one would assume that it would not have gone ahead with the Northern Territory rail link. Nevertheless, we can make that up again. An effect of the Darwin-Alice rail link would be employment. We are told that in the first three years 737, 662 and 562 people would be employed. We are told that there would be 240 full time positions when the railway became operative. The Northern Territory Department of Transport and Works has suggested that 1, 200 jobs would be generated by the building of the railway. The tourism of which I hinted earlier would be increased, quite clearly, with the building of the railway. We know that for every $1m of overseas money spent, there is a rise of $2.5m in the gross domestic product. For every 44,000 tourist dollars spent, three new jobs are created. The South Australian Chamber of Commerce, when talking about the fiscal drawbacks, suggested that in the time of the building of the railway, $40m to $50m in wages and salaries tax would be returned to the Commonwealth Government, and $40m would be returned in company tax. In all, there would be a total return of $120m.

SPEECH.PARA: If we look at the unemployment benefit, we know that each unemployment benefit recipient adds $8,600 to the deficit. The suggestion has been made by those who have computed the figures that $103m would be saved over the six years through not paying the unemployment benefit to those people who would be working on the project.

I do not want to bore the Senate any further with elaboration on the information which I have raised, or on the other sections which I have mentioned . I notice that the two honourable senators who are present in the chamber are hanging on my every word. They are anxious to get away so I will cut my remarks short. It is unfortunate that this reputable paper has a blind spot. The Northern Territory is an integral part of Australia. The people who live there are not only citizens of the Northern Territory but also of Australia. I trust that the editor will appreciate these facts when he produces further articles and that he will check his facts to make sure that they are right because that does help, although most people who work on newspapers tend to pluck their facts out of the air to suit their arguments. I hope he will avoid his bias against the Northern Territory and he will see the Northern Territory as having achievements to date and potential for the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be extremely brief. I wish to support part of the general concept of what Senator Robertson has just said. Representing Tasmania, at times I become extremely annoyed at-at other times I am just patiently tolerant of-the misunderstanding of people who criticise, with an extraordinary view, the position of some of the smaller population areas, some of the smaller States or Territories. I give but one example. We hear a lot of criticism about the benefit that Tasmania receives in relation to the freight equalisation scheme, a benefit which amounts to just a bit more than the bounty paid to one industry in Victoria. The money for both comes out of the taxpayers' purse.
—Fibremakers.

—The senator interjects 'Fibremakers'. That is the company concerned. Last year the company in Victoria which employs about 1,100 people received $18m. The amount budgeted for this year for the Tasmanian freight equalisation scheme is $23m. That amount is for every industry and every person in the State of Tasmania.

SPEECH.PARA: Tasmania depends upon shipping for all of its transport other than a very small amount that can be brought by air. Government policy has been that the goods will be carried by ships built in Australia and this requirement has helped the South Australian and New South Wales ship building industries. These ships were probably the most expensive ships in the world; they were manned by probably the most expensive seamen in the world and they operated through the most expensive waterfronts in the world. It was nothing to do with Tasmania that we had to have all those things. It was all part of Commonwealth Government policy. The freight equalisation scheme is a form of compensation. Yet, people such as the editor of the newspaper to which Senator Robertson has just referred would write a similar type of article about the support and subsidy received by Tasmania as if we were a mendicant. In fact, it still costs us an awful lot of money, notwithstanding that bit of compensation, for what amounts to benefits received by people in other States of Australia.

I want to take this opportunity, following the remarks of Senator Robertson, to say that it is not only the Northern Territory that is sometimes misrepresented and maligned; this happens to my own State. There is a great tendency for those who live in the big centres of population to regard everybody else as somehow being dependent upon them. When one looks at those who receive the benefits of the protection system of its various nature one happens to notice that they mostly live in the big urban areas.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 7.43 p.m.

The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 24 August 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Why is service in Borneo during the 1960's not considered as service in a ' theatre of war' in relation to eligibility for a service pension, despite Australia suffering casualties, some fatal.
(2) Why is this the case when participating servicemen are eligible for the general service medal and the returned from active service badge.

(3) What are the terms of reference for the Minister's proposed investigations into the case of the HMAS Sydney and does he intend to widen this investigation to include other anomalous cases such as Borneo.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The question is based on an incorrect assumption. Service in the Northern Borneo areas of Sabah, Sarawak and Brunei is covered under the Repatriation ( Special Overseas Service) Act 1962.

For the purposes of this Act, Sabah, Sarawak and Brunei were designated as special areas between 8 December 1962 and 1 October 1967. Consequently, any serviceman who was allotted by the Department of Defence for special service in these areas during the above period is considered as having served in a theatre of war and is eligible to apply for repatriation benefits, including service pension, from my Department.

(2) The returned from active service badge and the general service medal ( Borneo Clasp) are provided to servicemen for service in operations in Sabah, Sarawak and Brunei over the periods 8 December 1962 to 30 September 1967 for the former and 24 December 1962 to 11 August 1966 for the latter. The period for which repatriation cover is provided to these servicemen for service in the same areas (8 December 1962 to 1 October 1967) overlaps the periods of eligibility for these awards. Hence, servicemen who hold these awards and were allotted for special service in a special area by the Department of Defence would be eligible to apply for repatriation benefits, including service pension.

(3) The investigation in relation to HMAS Sydney was directed at examining the exclusion of such servicemen from benefits under the Repatriation (Special Overseas Service) Act. The benefits are provided to eligible veterans who were allotted by the Department of Defence for special duty in a special area. Allotment was based on the concept of continuing danger to personnel from the activities of hostile forces. Advice I have received from the responsible departments is that existing allotment criteria are fair and cover the majority of personnel who served in the Vietnam area.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 4 October 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is there a danger to householders whose homes are constructed with fibro, duralex and asbestolux products that contain asbestos.
(2) Do fibro ceilings constitute a health hazard due to friction when they expand and contract in areas that experience temperature extremes, releasing asbestos dust and fibres.
(3) Does the extreme range of temperatures on duralex sheeting in bathrooms cause a similar health hazard.

(4) Can the Minister for Health assure pensioners and other householders whose homes are mostly, or partly, constructed with these asbestos products that they are safe; if not, will there be any avenues for compensation for householders who bought these products in good faith if they have to pay to have them removed .

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) It is considered that there is no danger to householders because any adverse effects of asbestos on health stem largely from the generation of harmful concentrations of dust caused through incorrect handling of asbestos- based materials in the working environment. Where dust generation is minimised, health risk is minimal.

(2) and (3) Expansion and contraction of asbestos cement materials due to temperatures encountered in domestic applications are insignificant and would not cause creation of asbestos dust or loose fibres: Indeed, a particularly useful feature of asbestos is its good adhesion and cohesion in a cement matrix and a high resistance to heat, moisture and abrasion.

Any health risk associated with asbestos cement sheeting is due largely to dust generated during manufacture, cutting and installation. Where asbestos cement products are installed in domestic buildings, they are normally sealed with paint and very little, if any, dust is produced.
(4) I draw the honourable senator's attention to the National Health and Medical Research Council Report on the Health Hazards of Asbestos and, in particular, the statements (page 8 of the report)-
that research findings do not support the frequently stated suggestion that slight, casual or brief non-occupational exposure of the general public to asbestos may lead to mesothelioma; and

that despite the high proportion of individuals, especially in urban areas, who have asbestos fibres in their lungs, there have been no substantiated cases of asbestos-related disease in the general public.
A copy of this report has been placed in the Parliamentary Library.

The expert sub-committee which prepared the report adopted the view that, at this stage, there is no evidence of a risk to the general public from exposure to asbestos in, for example, ambient air. I am not aware of any further evidence that would require modification of that view. In fact, asbestos fibres are found in the lungs of most people who have died of causes other than asbestos-related diseases, as a result of their having inhaled asbestos fibres that are found generally in the normal environment.
In the circumstances, the question of any government assuming responsibility for compensation related to the removal from private dwellings of material containing asbestos does not apply.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 2 November 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What short range air-to-air missile has been selected to arm the FA18 when this aircraft type enters service with the Royal Australian Air Force.
(2) Which medium range air-to-air missile has been provisionally selected for the FA18.

(3) Have arrangements been made, or will such arrangements be made, to secure missiles from early production batches, if the advanced medium range air-to-air missile has been selected for the latter requirement, in view of the fact that a production decision for AMRAAM will not be made till 1985 and the FA18 will enter service in 1986-87.
(4) Will the first order for the AMRAAM be placed in the fiscal year 1983.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Engineering Cadets: Royal Australian Air Force

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 3 November 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are women being recruited as engineering cadets in the Royal Australian Air Force.
(2) How many male applicants and how many female applicants were in the 1983-84 intake of RAAF engineering cadets.
(3) How many males and how many females were invited to attend the final selection board in the above intake.
(4) How many males and how many females were finally recruited into the RAAF as engineering cadets in the above intake.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(2) Applications for entry as RAAF engineering cadets in financial year 1983/84 were: 377 male, 48 female.
(3) 152 male, 14 female.
(4) 80 males and 4 females were recommended for entry into the RAAF as engineering cadets, but the entry of these applicants is still subject to their Higher School Certificate results.
